column333: of unresolved items that were in arbitration. So
column334: the only exposure we have is really just the underlying performance of the blocks of business going forward
column335: as with any block of business and we'll have to monitor as we go forward.\nAndrew Kligerman: And then the second question would just be
column336: in terms of your gross realized impairments and losses on sales. Could you give a little color as to what securities represented the biggest component and if you have specifics that'll be great too?\nFred Crawford: Sure. The largest component
column337: as I mentioned
column338: was really a mix of RMBS which included
column339: by the way
column340: a mix of prime and Alt A and subprime. And that was about
column341: if you breakdown the roughly $247 million of pre-tax and DAC impairment
column342: that was about $84 million of it. We then took about $34 million of pre-tax and DAC impairment on automotive-related exposures. These are tended to be a primary
column343: so called tier one suppliers to the auto industry
column344: which were falling on hard times and took impairment there. We took a sizable impairment in what we would call the gaming industry
column345: but more specifically
column346: it was on Harrah's Entertainment Inc of about $22 million. And then
column347: after that
column348: Andrew
column349: really a mix of small
column350: relatively minor impairments that were relatively spread out.\nOperator: We go next to John Hall with Wachovia.\nJohn Hall: I was hoping that
column351: Fred
column352: you might be able to take a look at April as it were
column353: and give us an idea of how the month of April has had an effect on the unrealized loss position in the bond portfolio
column354: and perhaps what it is done for the VACARVM?\nFred Crawford: In terms of unrealized loss
column355: what has happened in April is we've seen corporate spreads come in quite a bit from roughly 550 basis points to
column356: say
column357: 380 basis points for example. So
column358: in general
column359: that has been helpful from an unrealized standpoint. You've also seen
column360: though interest rates rise during that same time period
column361: and so I don't have the April ending pluses and minuses for you
column362: but that's by and large the movements that we've seen since the end of the quarter. In terms of VACARVM
column363: as I mentioned earlier
column364: we are still in the midst of doing some of the modeling and model refinements under various scenarios. Obviously
column365: we have seen a recovery in the market thus far in the second quarter
column366: and VACARVM tends to be particularly sensitive to the markets
column367: whereas FAS 133 type definitions tend to be sensitive to not only markets but also particularly interest rates
column368: and of course
column369: volatility. So I imagine the VACARVM estimates across the industry have recovered somewhat in the month of April
column370: but we are still doing all that modeling work.\nJohn Hall: Maybe I missed the spread
column371: but did you quantify the size of the DI block
column372: the DI assets and liabilities that you are going to be taking on
column373: and did you talk about what effect if any that this might have on the deferred gain that you carry?\nFred Crawford: Yes. We are taking on about $900 million worth of DI reserves in total across the three blocks that we're talking about
column374: that I mentioned. So
column375: over time
column376: you are not talking about a particularly sizable block of business in general when it comes to things like earnings and so forth. I'm sorry
column377: your second question?\nJohn Hall: Whether there is any effect on the deferred gains carried?\nFred Crawford: Yes. John
column378: what we are talking about is
column379: because we sold the business through indemnity reinsurance
column380: we booked a gain at the time of sale and had been amortizing that gain into our earnings. There will be really not a particularly material effect. In fact
column381: my Chief Accounting Officer is nodding his head
column382: none
column383: i.e.
column384: no effect related to the amortization of the deferred gains
column385: that's because we've amortized it?\nUnidentified Company Representative: As we didn't have any differed gain really associated with DI block.\nFred Crawford: If you heard that
column386: we didn't have much of a deferred gain on the DI block
column387: and [if it sells]
column388: that's part of the component of the component.\nJohn Hall: Great. You chose dividend of funds from the operating subsidiaries
column389: a couple of them up to the holing company. Why did you go that route as opposed to using some of that intercompany borrowing capacity?\nFred Crawford: The main reason
column390: John
column391: was we felt as if it was a more definitive
column392: clear
column393: statement of providing real cash liquidity at the holding company to pay down the debt because
column394: we found folks having a lot of questions surrounding the nature of it
column395: and understanding fully the intercompany lending arrangement. Frankly
column396: we had excess capital in the insurance companies and subsidiaries
column397: and felt that was the higher and better use of the money to just outright pay down debt. So
column398: it has a lasting effect of reducing the leverage and it creates more of a cushion for short-term liquidity needs
column399: including any liquidity surprises that could come with market conditions and what have you. So
column400: we just felt it to be a cleaner move
column402: and a better balancing of holding company liquidity versus insurance company and capital conditions. I might note it was an ordinary dividend also
column404: we did not need to or request any special approvals. This is within the ordinary dividend guidelines
column405: albeit as a matter of practice
column406: we spend time with the state
column407: whenever we take out a sizable dividend
column408: which we did of course.\nOperator: For our next question
column409: we go to Bob Glasspiegel with Langen McAlenney.\nBob Glasspiegel: I will stay on the TARP topic. Dennis
column410: bring me up to speed on where you stand on that? What you think the time horizon for decision is? How important is it that you get it
column411: and is there any need in talking to the government that you actually have to do transactions in order to qualify?\nDennis Glass: Bob
column412: those are questions that frankly most people don't know the answers to
column413: but let me from a big picture perspective
column415: at the time of the former administration
column417: the ACLI has been in discussions and making a compelling case to treasury that the insurance industry become eligible for TARP funds
column420: when Secretary Paulson was in charge
column421: I think he thought that including the insurance companies was the right thing. However
column423: the ACLI is driving conversations with Treasury
column426: both with respect to the decisions that they make as to eligibility of the insurance industry
column427: and the timing of those decisions Again
column428: I think the case being made by the industry is compelling
column429: particularly in that the same issues
column430: if the recession deepens and the stock market plunges again
column431: the same issues facing the insurance industry will manifest themselves that were manifested by the commercial banking industry. As an industry we have roughly the same relative asset-to-capital ratios as the bank industry does. So
column433: to me they are parallel situations
column434: and the insurance industry I think
column435: logically should have access to TARP. However
column437: I have no information with respect to whether it will be or what the timing of it is eligible for TARP
column438:
and when it would happen.
Bob Glasspiegel: A follow-up. I assume there's no comment relative to the Dow Jones story from a couple of weeks ago of a rumored asset sale and Goldman Sachs being hired?
Dennis Glass: We don't comment on either acquisitions or dispositions that we might be thinking about.
Operator: For our next question we go to Suneet Kamath with Sanford Bernstein.
Suneet Kamath: I had a couple of questions on the variable annuity business. As I think about the industry and the comments companies have made
column439: it almost seems like there are two groups. Companies such as yourself that are making changes to the in-force business in terms of price increases
column441: and then other companies that are just making changes to the new business that they write
column442: and sort of leaving the in-force business intact. I'm wondering as that plays out
column443: given that you are one of the companies presumably making changes to the in-force business
column444: is this going to have an adverse impact on your ability to sell-through third-party channels? That's question number one and then I have a second question.\nDennis Glass: Question number one
column445: I don't think the modest effect on the consumer of the changes that are being made on the in-force block are going to cause any difficulties with our distribution partners. We're quite clear about what flexibility for consequent changes that not only Lincoln but other VA providers have in their contracts. So
column446: I don't think that's particularly a big issue. And what was the second part of that question?\nSuneet Kamath: The second part I actually didn't ask yet
column447: but I will now. Hartford talked about two groups of VA writers
column449: one group being the simpler guarantees
column450: low cost kind of companies and the other group being the ones that still offer the richer benefits with higher costs. So I guess I'm wondering if you agree with that and then if that's correct
column451: where do you see Lincoln playing among those two groups.\nDennis Glass: First of all
column452: you heard on numerous occasions that we have been a less rich feature company and in the middle on pricing. So
column453: many of the product changes that are being discussed by the competition
column454: bring their rich benefits more closely to the benefits that we have in place today. We've always been able to compete and take market share
column455: not because we have the most aggressive product features at the lowest costs
column456: but the overall value proposition of a very sophisticated wholesaling force and very sophisticated retail distribution system. As we move forward
column457: and the changes that we make
column458: we'll be consistent with that philosophy
column459: which is continuing to reduce risk from the insurance company standpoint
column461: and combining a very good product with a good
column462: customer value proposition with the needs of our shareholders from a risk perspective
column463: and the significant capability that we had with our distribution organization.\nSuneet Kamath: Just last question on timing
column464: when do you think you are going to be rolling out some of these new products?\nDennis Glass: Probably in the third quarter
column467: we don't have to move as fast as other people have to move
column469: again just take our withdrawal benefits. The [Rachet] has been 5% and others have had 10% or 8% or 7% or 6%
column470: and so they've had to move more quickly and
column472: they have moved back to where we are in many instances already. So if you think we are going slower than the competition
column473: that's because we don't have as much need as some of the competitors to move as quickly.\nOperator: We'll go next to Steven Schwartz with Raymond James \u0026 Associates.\nSteven Schwartz: A couple of quickies and then more theoretical question. Fred
column475: I believe we're done in the second quarter; is that correct?\nFred Crawford: We actually had a small amount of merger-related expenses in the period
column477: but it is absolutely winding down. Total merger-related expenses in the quarter were just under $7 million. What I would say
column479: and I'm glad you asked the question
column482: we have put in place a fairly aggressive cost cutting program. Much of that is taking place in the second quarter
column483: and so you would naturally have a level of restructuring charges that come through. So you will notice in our statistical supplement that we had pre-tax about $5 million of restructuring charges that came during the first quarter as we started to get going
column484: but most of the notifications and actions were taking place in the second quarter. Our estimate right now is after-tax we would expect something in the neighborhood of $20 million or so of after-tax restructuring charges in the second quarter as our current estimate right now.\nSteven Schwartz: I think it was Dennis who said that he thought savings in the second half would be about $45 million on a GAAP basis
column485: presumably not including the restructuring charge offset. Could we see that maybe in 2010?\nDennis Glass: We'll hold off on that projection for a little while. That number would be likely double
column486: given the fact that most of it is coming in the second half. So
column487: I would say quick answer to that is $90 million to $100 million.\nSteven Schwartz: And then a theoretical question. I think historically you've kind of targeted to 375 of RBC. You are talking today about 350. I'm wondering about your thinking is that that you are at these ratings and that's where you're going to stay and that's 350
column488: or are you taking into account that VACARVM is going to move you there and it's simply changed an accounting as apposed to change in economics or may be both?\nDennis Glass: My view is that the 350% RBC is just a target that the company has meaning that that's what I think is commensurate with in and around the low AA-rated range of financial strength ratings across the agencies. This
column490: dependent upon the market environment that you are experiencing
column491: so the intention of the company would be to watch the various ins and outs of what moves your capital up and down and try to take actions in such a way that we manage in and around that range. We will drift above it at times
column492: as we did in the first quarter. We will drift below it depending on the timing of impairments and transactions that we look to take action on
column493: but I do not have a VACARVM estimate in that target. That's something that we still have under review. We are heartened somewhat by the fact that we maintained pretty substantial assets that back our VA business. As I mentioned during my prepared remarks
column494: we ended the first quarter with hedge assets pretty considerably or well above that of the current statutory guidelines
column495: but VACARVM will increase reserved. Those reserves do behave differently than the derivative valuations do due to interest rates and we'll have to monitor conditions
column496: as we go forward and make adjustments accordingly.\nOperator: Our next question comes from Eric Berg with Barclays Capital.\nEric Berg: Thanks and good morning to both of you
column497: and to Jim. It sort of felt like in the March quarter that while there were many companies
column498: several companies had liquidity issues. It sort of felt to me like Lincoln was scrambling
column499: that even though everyone was in a similar operating environment
column500: that somehow Lincoln was in a pinch and had to sort of borrow from here and take from there. We've heard have a lot about taking money from here
column502: Federal Home Loan Bank. I suspect you are going to think that the use of the word scramble would be an unfair characterization and it's perfectly fine for you to say that
column504: that's sort of how it's felt. What would be your view on that Dennis? The right characterization to the liquidity position and what happened to Lincoln during the quarter? And then I have a second question.\nDennis Glass: Yeah
column506: it seemed that a couple of things sort of combined to focus on Lincoln's liquidity a little bit more than other companies
column508: we immediately began to respond in the market place
column509: with the comments and actions that we've been taking. I think the decision to upstream the dividends and just take this issue of the financial flexibility off the table for quite a number of years
column510: probably helped to clear up in the minds of people what the real circumstance was. Fred's already mentioned why we've done that
column511: and I can tell you that
column512: I believe that liquidity is taken care of. We don't really have significant debt maturities
column513: they run in the $200 million range for the next three or four years. So
column514: we don't have anything on the horizon that's not manageable. The other thing is so
column515: if you just say to yourself
column517: they are taking care of financial issues at the holding company are in good shape and a lot of resources. We can now focus entirely on all of our efforts to be sure that even under our stress scenarios
column518: that we have action that we can pull the trigger on to maintain adequate RBC. So
column519: that's where our focus is as a management team. And
column521: I'm quite confident that even under the stress situation that we will manage through the challenges of 2009 from the capital perspective.\nEric Berg: Thanks. My second question is much a narrower and technical one. Fred
column522: you mentioned that during the quarter the non-performance risk
column523: there was change in the addition to your GMWB liability related to the non-performance risk. Can you go over whether that was a benefit or a detriment and what the earnings impact would have been
column524: you discussed this. I'm just hoping you can review it
column525: what the earnings impact would have been absent that change? Thank you.\nFred Crawford: Yes. We refined our estimate really to lessen the sensitivity of the NPR to our particular spreads at the holding company level. On the view that insurance company liabilities are generally less sensitive to our credit default swap-type issues
column526: at the holding company. And so that was our view and that's what gave rise to the change. Now
column527: the reason the NPR was actually a negative in the quarter was really more volume-related
column528: meaning that the overall size of the FAS133 liability actually came down in the quarter
column529: due predominantly to interest rates and volatility coming down a bit
column531: we were applying the NPR to a smaller base and therefore ended up having the reduction. Now
column532: had we not made the change
column533: I mentioned that we would have taken a sizable gain. That gain would have been about $300 million in the quarter
column534: had we not made the change. But
column535: as we continue to refine our estimates and work within the accounting guidelines and what we think makes sense
column536: as you look at the nature of the liabilities
column537: we felt the refinements were good on our part
column538: albeit a negative in the quarter.\nOperator: We go next to Mark Finkelstein with FPK.\nMark Finkelstein: I guess one follow-up question
column543: I just want to make sure I got these right. I think you said stat net income was negative $53 million
column544: and that is with the benefit of the $150 million reinsurance gain. Would that mean that without that stat net income would have been negative 200 or do I have the numbers wrong?\nFred Crawford: Yes
column545: the net income on the stat basis includes is the actual stat earnings generated naturally of the book of business recognizing carbon reduced earnings in the annuity line and strain from continued good production on the life side. But it also includes the impact of the ceding commission that comes in from the reinsurance transaction. And then what it brings it into the negative category is really all of the impairment activity
column546: the roughly $250 million odd worth of impairment taken in the quarter on securities. There also tends not to be as greater tax offset to those impairments when you bring them through on a stat basis. So that in part
column547: weighs it down.\nMark Finkelstein: I just want to understand the holding company a little bit
column548: and maybe just help in terms of reconciliation
column553: intercompany borrowings exist? And then also what is the cash of the holding company? Really what I'm trying to get at is what are those balances and how do you get those down to the $500 million
column554: by the end of the second quarter? And if there is needed cash coming to get you there where does that come from?\nFred Crawford: Sure
column555: it's actually a good time to walk through this
column558: we retired a pretty sizable portion of the so-called c-puff commercial paper
column559: this would be the government commercial paper. I think we retired something in the neighborhood of $300 million of that. So
column560: in other words we are starting to settle in to or towards more normalized levels. As we sit here today
column561: we have about $270 million of commercial paper outstanding
column562: about $60 million of which is under the government program. So
column563: we've been actively issuing in the tier two commercial paper market between $200 and $300 million
column564: pretty routinely. It took us about a couple of months or so to really initiate a new list of investors
column567: investors in the tier 2 commercial paper and we have been quite successful in placing that paper. It tends to be in smaller chunks
column568: but you can also issue it fairly long
column570: 60 days and rolling it without trouble at this point. We also though have borrowed from our internal CMA or really our overnight sweep accounts and the liquidity accounts that we have across the company to the tune of $350 million or so. Now
column571: if you do the math on that
column572: that brings you upwards of a little north of roughly $600 million
column574: we have the second tranche of our ordinary dividend coming later in the quarter at about $100 million. That will then bring you down into the short-term position around $500 million. Now
column575: a couple of things I want to comment on here. We are a large company that naturally has sizable ins and outs on any given day from our cash flow perspective. We have interest payments that are quarterly and semiannually. We collect dividends from our insurance and non-insurance subsidiaries. We also have tax proceeds that are moving in or moving out of the company depending on our tax position. So
column577: these liquidity positions will move around. When we as a company talk about our liquidity position at around $500 million
column578: that's what we believe to be more of the steady state
column579: managing of our liquidity position on a go-forward basis.\nMark Finkelstein: Okay. Great. Finally
column582: a securitization structure. Is that an external transaction or is that internal?\nDennis Glass: External in the sense that we would be working with a third party or third party investors to secure that financing.\nFred Crawford: One other thing while I have you here on the topic of this cash management account or cash sweep account. Recognize that we have got several subsidiaries that participate in that arrangement
column583: upwards of 10 to 15 different subsidiaries that will park their daily liquidity and overnight liquidity or extended liquidity into that facility. I say that only because it's not always the case
column584: particularly when we are not leaning very heavily on it that we are borrowing from Lincoln Life Insurance company of Indiana. Now
column585: granted most of the subsidiaries are much smaller
column586: and our core insurance company would be the largest source of liquidity potentially
column588: but it's not always the case that we are directly borrowing from Lincoln Life.\nDennis Glass: I would just add to that
column589: that the sweep account is exactly what it says. It collects funds that we would otherwise invest overnight
column590: and a company our size is likely to have a couple hundred million dollars of funds every night. So
column591: if you subtract a couple hundred funds of float that we have every night from the $500 million
column592: we only really need $300 million from the commercial paper market to handle the $500 million. I would also say and reinforce that the reduction in interest expense due to the debt reductions that we have made
column593: the additional comment about the $400 million of holding company needs
column594:
really suggests there shouldn't be any pressure at all on that $500 million getting higher for the foreseeable future.
Operator: For our next question we go to Darin Arita with Deutsche Bank.
Darin Arita: Thank you. I guess the first question is for Fred. You had mentioned that the dividends coming out of the insurance subs is really based on you seeing some excess capital there. What's your estimate as to where the excess capital is for your onshore and offshore insurance subsidiaries?
Fred Crawford: The way I would describe excess capital at the moment is
column595: if you describe it as having a target of 350
column596: and recognizing the dividend actions we have taken in the second quarter
column597: what we have effectively done Darin is shift that access capital to the holding company. So
column598: while you could argue that we have taken the excess capital that is defined by risk-based capital cushion
column599: and moved it into a delevering position at the holding company
column600: where we would have excess capital in that regard. So that I think is really the way to think about it. I think right now we have to be conscious of the steps that we can take on the capital front if we were to see continued capital deterioration due to realized losses and impairments in the general account. So
column601: that's the way I would describe the excess capital position at the moment. The dialogue around excess capital across the industry frankly is
column602: it is really only one you can have when bouncing it up against stress conditions for the general account in the market. So
column603: what you are finding with the rating agencies
column604: and I think implied in some of their actions is not really the absolute RBC
column605: but rather what that RBC looks like when bounced up against potential loss conditions. I think where we have tended to hold up reasonably will
column606: albeit with some downward pressure is our overall general account
column608: and then the risk manager practices on the annuity business.\nDarin Arita: That's helpful. How do we think about it for the offshore reinsurers. You can take the [$300 million] out there.\nDennis Glass: The offshore captive had built up pretty substantial asset value with their derivatives position
column609: and we ended up in really an excess asset position as we came off the year end and into the first quarter
column610: primarily a result of being over hedged on our income benefits. We had taken more of a pure economic 133 derivative like approach to income benefits
column612: there's a very real mortality element to that which brings about more of an SOP type reserving regime on that business. So
column613: that afforded us the opportunity to monetize some of the hedge assets
column614: and move that excess capital or excess asset position out of Barbados to pay down debt. Again
column615: simply a decision as to where best we want to hold that capital.\nDarin Arita: Okay. Thanks. One for Dennis
column616: I guess. On the variable annuities
column617: can you talk about the rationale for Lincoln continuing to de-risk? I mean
column619: it sounded like the hedge programs has performed well. The hedge assets are in line with the economic liabilities and also Lincoln didn't provide us benefits that are [right] as the competitors and now the competitors are scaling back more in line with Lincoln. Why does Lincoln have to make any changes?\nDennis Glass: The market is going to permit changes and the competition
column621: that we have always been from feature standpoint
column623: the competition is coming in and
column625: when you step back and look at the total franchise value of what enables us to be successful with the sales of variable annuities for all of our other products
column626: it's the combination of a lot of things
column630: we have the opportunity to de-risk the product because the industry is moving in that direction and we're going to take advantage of it.\nDarin Arita: Okay. Is that any statement on your view of the profitability of the business that you wrote?\nDennis Glass: It is a statement on the fact that we want to reduce the tail risk and that we'll take some reduction in the expected internal rate of return on the product in order to eliminate or not eliminate
column631: but reduce the tail risk. So it's a rebalancing of expected returns and expected risk.\nOperator: Our last question comes from Tom Gallagher with Credit Suisse.\nTom Gallagher: I just wanted to follow-up on the holding company to make sure I have the numbers right
column633: the $600 million of balances between [CP] and the internal CMA borrowings
column634: should we compare that to the $700 million of dividends that were taken
column635: so you would essentially have a net cash balance of $100 million or have you used some of the cash from the dividends to date?\nFred Crawford: The current CP and CMA balance is after having moved the $300 million out of Barbados and roughly $300 million out of Lincoln Life. We have another $100 million of the ordinary dividend to move in and that's what we'll bring that a little over $600 million down to a little over $500 million. We don't really hold what I would call much idle cash. We do have some corporate securities that we hold at the holding company
column636: but we really manage to a cash flow neutral environment at the holding company
column637: and that's how we manage the liquidity. Does that answer your question?\nTom Gallagher: Yes
column638: it does. You have used up the dividends to pay it down and you will have a rough balance of $500 million between the CP and the CMA?\nFred Crawford: That's right.\nDennis Glass: Let me add
column640: we have always borrowed short in the marketplace
column641: probably north of the $500 million. So this is not unusual the way we manage our investment portfolios and our long/short positions and long-term rates versus short-term rates to be comfortable with the $500 million short-term position. Again
column642: it's somewhat less than we have held on average over the years.\nTom Gallagher: So
column643: as we think about it prospectively
column645:
which I believe you can go upwards of $1 billion of borrowing from the subs if need be.
Dennis Glass: Right.
Tom Gallagher: Then prospectively we should be thinking about $300 million of annual interest expense plus an extra $250 million of debt due in 2010?
Fred Crawford: Yeah
column646: and your interest expense at the holding company is supported by normal dividend flows out of the life insurance company
column647: surplus net interest payments out of the life insurance company
column648: and income or dividend flows from non-regulated subs like the UK
column649: Delaware etcetera.\nDennis Glass: I don't think we'll have to dividend off much more than $150 million or so from the subsidiaries over the next couple of years to maintain that $500 million.\nTom Gallagher: That is helpful. This is a little further out
column650: but I just want to understand the mechanics. I believe your $2 million of LOCs mature in 2011. A lot can obviously change between now and then
column651: but if we assume debt markets are still frozen by then
column652: how would that play out? Would you have to pay those down or I believe those support a Triple X reserves. So it would just be a stack capital strain of some sort or can you expand on that a bit?\nFred Crawford: The letter of credit facility that matures in 2011 allows you to extend your letters of credit out of 2012. So it allows a bit more time on the letters of credit. Now what we have to do is really manage to the various alternatives that are available to support the redundancy going forward or any excess reserves financing we need. That would include probably reduced capacity on letters of credit. Going forward
column653: although we would have to see how the markets play out. Longer term securitization transaction and our product modifications that would hopefully help the reserve carry as we go forward. So right now
column655: we're very actively engaged in looking at the planning exercise around how best to finance these reserves going forward. Now
column656: at the end of the day
column657: if you have to carry more reserves
column658: the other aspect of this is you simply need to do the kind of internal work
column659: actuarial work to show that you are carrying excess reserves back in your business and that may be weighing down on your RBC. So I think ultimately at the end of the day
column660: that actuarial work on what the appropriate economic reserves are on the whole remains important irrespective of how you finance it. I might also add that you got to be thinking about product
column662: in terms of the outright costs of that financing.\nTom Gallagher: Fred
column663: just one last follow-up. Would you have an estimate of what the RBC strain that was relieved related to the $2 billion
column664: just even ballpark would be helpful?\nFred Crawford: Well
column665: over the course of the last couple of years
column666: we have done reserve securitizations between $200 and $300 million type range using letters of credit or securitization type vehicles. So
column668: it's probably helped out our risk-based capital
column669: in and around 20 to 30 points on annualized bases from what otherwise would be greater strain. Obviously
column670: it depends on the size of the reserve securitizations you do. We've done larger and we've done smaller.\nDennis Glass: I would just add to that
column671: I know that you are looking forward a little bit
column673: we are doing these reserve transactions in today's markets. And the reason we are able to do that is because they are generally secured by the excess reserves in the form of future cash flows. So
column674: these are secured financings and that's why they are even doable today.\nTom Gallagher: So Dennis
column675: you are still able to do those types of deals in this kind of market. So we should be thinking about
column676: although these sound large in the future based on today's market
column677: you'd still be able to essentially roll those over?\nDennis Glass: As I said in my comments
column679: they are more expensive and they are more challenging to execute on. But
column680: we continue to review and look at ideas and alternatives for where to execute them and how best to execute them. So
column681: clearly the market is a bit different right now
column682: of course to do these things. But

column257: 000 members.  We purposely try to create a product continuum that encourages folks to go from the Private Fee-For-Service to the network based options
column258: be it regional PPO
column259: local PPO
column260: or HMOs.  We saw some good movement this past open enrollment period and we anticipate well see increasing levels of movement in 2010 and 2011.  We feel very well positioned for the CMS rule regarding the elimination of the Private Fee-For-Service on January 1 and were very pleased with how this is all beginning to set up for us.\nTom Carroll: So increasing levels in 2010
column261: maybe it is too early to say right now in terms of your strategy
column262: in terms of bidding for next year
column263: but is it going to be more so in 2010 than 2011?\nJim Murray: I would anticipate that 2010 would be slightly higher than 2011.  2011
column264: as I sit here now
column265: we are obviously in the process of going through the market-by-market evaluation of what your benefits and premiums are going to look like.  My goal and our goal will be to try to get as much done in 2010 as possible with 2011 being the finalization of that process.  Again
column266: we saw some nice movement this past open enrollment period and as we create our product continuums market-by-market that will be a major goal.\nTom Carroll: Thats very helpful
column267:
thank you.
Operator: Your next question comes from Charles Boorady with Citi Investment Research.
Charles Boorady: I am wondering how much of the impact in your Medicare Advantage loss ratio expected improvement this year is coming from the revenue benefit of the risk score issue that you discussed versus an improvement in underlying cost trends or other factors?
Mike McCallister: Charles
column268: I mentioned two things
column269: I mentioned the PDP and that was lowering benefit expenses and of course
column270: your question again suggesting the Medicare risk adjustment.  The two things together were probably about $0.10 in the first quarter and theyre about a 3:2 ratio
column271: so again
column272: we kind of expect that to play out through the year.\nCharles Boorady: Okay and again
column273: you underlying cost trend assumptions though
column274: are they unchanged versus what you thought when you [interposing].\nMike McCallister: Yes.\nCharles Boorady: Okay
column275: I have it. Then in terms of looking out to 2010
column276: you mentioned the 4% to 5% cut that you hope to have mitigated
column277: but assuming it goes through
column278: if we were to assume it goes through and trying to assess what the impact will be in 2010
column279: do you have any information that you can share with us to help us make our own estimates of what the impact would be?  For example

column282: presuming you have to put through additional member increases or cut benefits then?\nJim Murray: As I mentioned to the earlier questioner
column283: were in the process of going market-by-market evaluating benefit designs and premiums that well likely put into place.  There is a benefit cut level that were trying to align around and trying to evaluate how many members we would likely have moving back into the Medicare program or perhaps to competitors.  We feel very confident that the offerings that weve evaluated so far are going to be competitive and they are going to provide the members with a substantial value proposition.  So
column284: were not prepared right now
column285: obviously
column286: because we are bidding against ourselves
column287: if you will.  Well know more in October when we see what some of our competitors do
column288: but were cautiously optimistic that when we get done our benefit plans are going to be very
column289: very competitive and we feel
column290: again
column291:
cautiously optimistic that next year well see some growth.
Charles Boorady: You imposed first time premium this year and seem to hang on to a preponderance of your lives.  Do you have any data on people who might have left because of the premium you imposed versus the percent you kept?
Jim Murray: Help me understand what you are specifically looking for.
Charles Boorady: Essentially
column292: how do members respond when you impose a monthly premium on them.\nJim Murray: The membership
column293: we broke it into the different premium increases and we saw a persistency issue at some level of premium increase.  We believe that there is a premium level that people begin to evaluate their choices and thats one of the reasons that I mentioned earlier.  We are going to look at that particular premium level and evaluate what we want to do with benefit cuts and premium increases
column294: given what we saw last year about that specific premium level where again
column295: it looks like people look around a little bit more than other increases.\nMike McCallister: Let me add to that. There are some things we did learn relative to premiums and what we do know is that we can sell a product with a premium to seniors with our distribution capability
column296: because there is a value proposition there that they can sell.  What we had happen
column297: as you know
column298: is we had people out there with zero premium products.  We sold a lot.  We had some churn because of the zero premium competitors and we dont know what people are going to do next year
column299: but I would find it incredible that anyone would be out there with a zero premium product in 2010.  So
column300:
we are going to be premium against premium here as opposed to the stark reality of a premium versus nothing.  I think overall we have to feel pretty good about where this is going to come out.
Regina Nethery: We are going to need to move on.  We have a number of people in the queue.
Operator: Your next question comes from Joshua Raskin with Barclays Capital.
Joshua Raskin: My first question
column301: Mike you have talked for years
column302: and year
column303: and years about a targeted 5% overall Medicare margin.  Obviously things are going slightly better than that
column304: so I am curious as you think about 2010; one of the components you are not talking about in terms of changes would be potential margin change i.e. getting back to that 5%.  I am just curious if that is in the plan as well. Then
column305: Jim
column306: the favorable development
column307: obviously a big number $169 million
column308: but it was actually down a little bit on a year-over-year basis.  Based on what was recognized last year in the first quarter I would have thought it might have been up this year.  Is there anything in the favorable developments that could spike up?\nJim Bloem: Again
column309: we used our same conservative reserving methodology that we always use.  Again
column310: it is based on all the actuarial information that we have.  We continue to think that people over think this
column311: so we give them all of the information that is in the press release regarding how it works and youve picked up on the piece of development to date.  I would go back and say that weve
column312: again
column313: booked to a constant level of margin.  We continue that margin. So
column314: again
column315: we feel very good about our reserves and we look at it.  By the time we get to the end of the year
column316: again
column317: there has been a lot of consistency in the last couple years and I think well see that again this year.\nJim Murray: To your first question the goal we have each and every year is to increase our profitability year-over-year so as were evaluating on a market-by-market basis were trying to determine what we think the competitive landscape looks like market-by-market and making decisions around a specific market level contract level plans that we have in some of those that it makes sense
column318: perhaps to attempt to grow membership in others it looks like its more appropriate to maintain the higher margins and so when we put all of that together the end goal for us as a company is to make more money year-over-year as you might expect. So
column319: it is a very
column320: very evolving process and we feel very good about where we sit right now.\nJim Bloem: I will just add to that Josh.  I have said 5% for a long time and that is still where we work.  I mean we go into this whole process every year with the idea that for our entire Medicare book of business we think about 5% is where it ought to be.  Now there are a lot of moving parts associated with that.  We have to look at the total company
column321: as Jim said
column322: it is a huge variation based on location and geography and where we think we are relative to medical cost management and a lot of different things.  I think generally we are staying in that range and it has been a little higher
column323: it has been a little lower.  Last year it was a little lower
column324: right now it is a little higher

column326: we struggled to make 4% least year.\nJoshua Raskin: Right
column327: fair enough.  I guess I was just asking

column329: relative to your competitors

column334: so we evaluate that pretty in depth and again
column335: lots of moving parts
column336: but again
column337: as we sit here right now

column340: as Jim says
column341: the dollars that we earn

thats the part were trying to move up.  The 5% is a year-over-year long-term moving average.
Operator: Your next question comes from Matthew Borsch with Goldman Sachs.
Matthew Borsch: I have a question about the potential expected fix to the physician SGR.  What do you think about the time frame in terms of when that would need to get done in order to still be able to roll through something to the 2010 rate potentially?  Is there a time frame that you think this has to get done by?
Jim Murray: Weve provide Mike and Heidi Margulis
column343: our Senior VP of Government Relations some dates that would make the most sense.  We would love to see something done before the CMS finalization of rates in August. If it happens later than that
column344: we will obviously stand ready to do whatever it takes. That fix is worth $25.00 of benefits and premiums and from my point of view it saves some significant disruption in the senior population and it is something that a lot of people in Washington ought to be focusing on.  So
column345: we will do whatever it takes to get it in time and we would ask that the folks in Washington feel the same.\nMike McCallister: Weve put a lot of energy as weve gone through building out each of these benefit and premium proposals and there are thousands of them that have to go in and prepared ourselves for scenarios around what would happen if we get a late change to this so that we could quickly react. So
column346: we are prepared.   Congress will do what its going to do and we cant drive the timeline.  Well have to see how that plays out.  I know there is significant pressure out there to get something done about this
column347: because it is kind of an outrageous concept that were going to put the seniors though all this
column348: this next year and then turn around and reverse it by formula in the following years.  So it is kind of an awful lot of wasted energy.\nMatthew Borsch: If I could just ask on your slide presentation you showed on page 7
column349: you showed the PPO product compared to Med Supp plan with stand alone PDP.  Is that sort of what is never going to be completely apples-to-apples
column350: but is that pretty close?  In other words that sort of implies that the product is providing effectively about $60.00 a month in additional value
column351: if Im reading this correctly.  Would that be inclusive of the 4% to 5% rate cut thats on the books for now?\nMike McCallister: Yes
column352: the answer to all of your questions is yes.\nMatthew Borsch: Okay.  All right
column353: Im good for now
column354: thank you.\nJim Murray: And remember that is the PPO.  The HMO
column355: obviously
column356:
has significantly more value than that.
Operator: Your next question comes from Justin Lake with UBS Investment Research.
Justin Lake: You gave us some color around the PMPM Medicare Advantage premiums that you reported.  Can you give us just a little more color on the break down?  It was up 10% year-over-year; that is a big number.  I am just curious how much of that is 1x catch up on those risk adjusters versus what we can expect to continue as the year-over-year increase in yields going forward.
Jim Bloem: Actually it is very little.  You are right that the Medicare per member per month Medicare Advantage premium is up 10%
column357: but that is driven by a lot of factors
column358: and the one that I mentioned that changed the guidance was a very small change.  Here are the kinds of things
column359: and I am sure you know a lot of these
column360: but if you think about us they particularly apply.  First of all you have the base rate that you get from CMS. Then
column361: as we have talked about
column362: we are one of the few companies that added a premium this year for 2009
column363: so that increased it.  Then we did a number of acquisitions in the last three quarters of 2008 gave us a lot more members.  Then we also got a mix of business issues
column364: again
column365: weve got HMOs
column366: Private Fee-For-Service
column367: PPOs and then the geography of where things are changed and then finally the demographic mix
column368: the age
column369: the gender of our members etc.  So all of those things go into that 9.9 increase for the premium per member per month and the amount that made the guidance change
column370: again the guidance went up $0.15 and as I said that has the investment income reduction and the commercial reduction in Small Group membership
column371: but again it just takes a very small change in that MRA thing to produce the change we did today.\nJustin Lake: My second question
column372: I just want to follow up on Joshs question on the 5% target.  Mike
column373: specifically
column374: you went through a lot of time last year on the first quarter call going through the steps you were taking to get the 4% margin back to 5%.  When we fast-forward to 2010
column375: are you going to be talking to us about getting 6% back to 5% and what youll be doing there? Then to take that a step further
column376: if we dont get a change in these rates
column377: is there any possibility that Humana would be willing to accept lower than even that 5% margin target for 2010 in order to maximize their benefit designs with the expectation that rates will bounce back in 2011 and you will kind of smooth it out?\nMike McCallister: First of all
column378: let me tell you how we think about this.  You are going to start with the entire company and we ask ourselves what can all of our product lines produce; where are our earnings
column379: what do we think is a reasonable growth potential off of those earnings; then we start looking at all of our products
column380: including in this case Medicare
column381: to continue to try to find a way to continue to grow the company.  None of these things are etched in stone.  If I could find a way to significantly grow earnings on the back of a 3% margin would I do it
column382: of course I would.   So it is all about working with a number of moving pieces.  We generally shoot at this 5% number for Medicare
column383: because it has been fitting how it works our company for a while
column384: and as we get further into the year we will think about that.  As we know more where were going to stand against competitors
column385: as we see what we think we can do with all of these various proposals and bids
column386: all of that is going to come together.  We intend to grow earnings next year; whether it is going to be 5% or 5.5% or 4.8%
column387: at this point it is too early to say.\nJustin Lake: Great
column388: thanks for the color.\nOperator: Your next question comes from Greg Nersessian with Credit Suisse.\nGreg Nersessian: My question is on the commercial business.  Last quarter you pretty much brushed off the potential impact of the slowing economy on your Commercial Group membership and obviously you have changed your view on that point.  So
column389: I was wondering what specifically did you see change
column390: since you reported the fourth quarter numbers
column391: that has caused you to change that view. Then if you could help us understand as to how the seasonality might change this year in your high-deductible health plan products from the impact of the slowing economy.\nJim Murray: I was the person who brushed it off
column392: as you so aptly put it and I own that
column393: so.  Here is what happened from the time we talked last until today.  We did a number of things.  One of the things I talked with you about last time we spoke was that we were going to increase our pricing on our
column394: particularly our Small Group business and we did that.  That was one thing that went into the membership issue. Another thing that we did was we chose for the Small Group is made up of 2 to 25
column396: and 51 to 99 case sizes.  For the 51 to 99 we werent pleased with where our medical expense ratios were running and so we change our underwriting approach from an employer question approach to an employee question approach.  We tried to understand more about the particular pieces of risk in those groups that we were looking at
column397: and that went over well in probably 60% of our markets.  In 40% of our markets the competitors didnt follow suit and so that caused a little disruption
column398: more so than we had anticipated. Finally
column399: when we last talked we have a thing here called Other Group Movement
column401: net effect of lay-offs and individuals deciding to drop coverage.  For all of 2008 that Other Group Movement for the Small Group block was averaging around 1
column403: 000 members for month.  When January hit the number was closer to 6
column405: January has a little bit higher enrollment activity than other months.  Unfortunately for us that stayed at around 5
column407: 000 in February and March. All of those three pieces added together caused the change in the way that I looked at our Commercial membership.  Were obviously identifying a number of fixes to get after.  Specifically its a Small Group issue.  We did talk about some ASO cases that left us and that was okay
column408: because some of what happened there was competitive situations that we werent willing to accept.  So
column409: we have some things that were doing on the Small Groups side to get after it. Around new products
column410: we have our new consumerism products in the second half of the year that were going to roll out.  When we roll out products we do market visits and we will
column412: so that we will get in front of a lot of brokers.  We are going to expand some of our value propositions.  Some of our
column415: where we have under writers meet face to face with brokers.  We are doing some things around bonus programs. So
column416: we anticipate that towards the tail end of the year that the Small Group losses that I just referenced will start to mitigate
column417: but weve tried to be conservative with our reductions. As it relates to the question that you asked regarding the high-deductible health plans
column418: we saw some benefit for that in the first quarter and well likely see some negative in the fourth quarter.  But overall
column419: some of the pricing that we did
column420: that I referenced at the beginning of my response
column421: is driving the improvement in the medical expense ratio for the overall commercial block up 100 basis points or perhaps even a little bit  more so.  We are pleased with the way that the commercial profitability is starting to be positioned for the year
column422: and this Small Group enrollment issue is something that
column425: sorry that we werent as on top of this as we should have been when we had our last call
column426: but we are all over it now.\nGreg Nersessian: Great
column427: thank you very much.\nOperator: Your next question comes from Christine Arnold with Cowen \u0026 Co.\nChristine Arnold: In regards to Medicare Advantage
column428: could you give us a sense for the churn that you ultimately saw in the first quarter kind of gross adds
column429: gross losses?  Then how much of that increase PMPM of
column431: was going to risk adjusters that you either have received first quarter or expect to receive later in the year?   Finally
column432: can you talk about the loss ratio?  Given the churn
column433: how confident are you that youre seeing the underlying trends and what kind of metrics do you look at there?\nJim Bloem: Let me start with the last two.  We are very confident that
column434: we continue to watch weekly and daily the trends and everything
column435: so we know that the expenses that were booking are the expenses that are actually being incurred. As far as how much of how much of the 9.9 is risk adjustor
column436: again it is not a very large amount
column437: because think about what I said before.  We introduced a member premium.  Weve got the base rate from CMS.  Weve got the acquisitions that we did and then everything else it really goes in terms of the lines of businesses
column438: how we expand the network product over the Private Fee-For-Service
column439: so not a very big number.\nMike McCallister: I have a couple of follow-ups to your questions.  On a gross basis our sales were $367
column441: 000 of plan-to-plan changes; so net MAPD sales were around $254
column442: 000.  Our market pool agency had an absolutely incredible year and we appreciate all the good work that they do.  One of the things that I would follow up with
column443: some of Jims remarks that as he said in his remarks
column444: are the risk scores for the new members that weve got were very similar to the risk members that we got last year and the risk members that we got the year before that.  The improved risk scores are for our persisting members where we are getting paid the amount that we should be based upon the risk that were assuming.  So
column445: this isnt an issue about any kind of surprises in the new membership that we received. The increase here is a function of the documentation and again
column446: being paid for the risks that were assuming.  And
column448: lots of metrics around here at Humana.  We look at claims almost on a daily basis.  Particularly the drug claims and we are very pleased with what we are seeing not only in the PDP
column449: but also the MAPD claims.\nChristine Arnold: Okay
column450: my final question is on cash deployment.  Why so little repurchase with all this cash and the shares where they are?\nJim Bloem: We have adopted a philosophy for the last year now
column454: that we are going to prudently have a bias towards conserving cash
column459: things like that.  Weve got a very solid financial position
column460: as I mentioned.  Our credit facility doesnt expire until 2011 and the first of our senior notes not until 2016.  But
column461: we are being very cautious about the use of cash right now
column463: it would be wildly accretive to do.  It is still a matter of a lot of companies that have done that
column465: but everywhere that have used up their cash have sort of regretted doing it; so we would like to see further evidence of stability in the credit markets and in the cash markets
column467:
before we continue repurchasing.
Christine Arnold: Thank you.
Operator: Your next question comes from Scott Fidel of Deutsche Bank.
Scott Fidel: Can you give us your initial impressions on this new swine flu outbreak and do you know if any of the initial 20 cases in the US have been Humana members?  Can you give us a sense of what type of impact on this could have on the business if it continues to spread around the US?
Jim Murray: I read about the swine flu over the weekend for the very first time and weve got a lot of folks who are looking through to assess the issues
column469: it is early in the process.\nMike McCallister: I would say there is homework that gets done around subjects like this
column470: whether it be this one or any other pandemic kind of issue out there and in fact natural disasters.   So
column471: it is not like we have never thought about this.  We have folks who have spent a lot of time with plans and preparations for these kinds of things
column472: but it is way to early to have any idea whether this is going to have any impact on us or any of our members.\nScott Fidel: Then a follow up on health reform and maybe now with it looking like there will be a reconciliation provision included.  I would like your thoughts around timing
column473: will it potentially not be until Fall now
column474: so we really have a good sense of this.  Then I would like your updated
column475: what you are hearing just the conversation around the public plan and how that could be framed and the chance of that actually coming out including something like Medicare rates as compared to it being based more on commercial competition.\nMike McCallister: It is a little hard to say at this point.  Even though you are starting to see a little more clarity about what people are thinking the process might look like
column476: I would say that the devil is still going to be in the details around all of this.  I will tell you that the public plan option
column477: which is nothing but a government run health plan is a real lightening rod and could disrupt everything
column478: so it will be interesting to see how committed some folks are to such an idea. Our industry has done a nice job of preparing for this both from the standpoint of having really positive
column479: solid policy positions that we put forward that are really structurally different.  It is surprising to some folks up there.  We will see.  We have a good grass roots capability that will be applied when and if and where necessary.  So
column480: I think we are prepared to argue the points and the policies as well as play the politics if it is necessary to get to the right place. But
column481: I think there is a lot of time left here before we have anything to really work with.\nOperator: Your next question comes from John Rex with JP Morgan.\nJohn Rex: Just back a minute towards thinking of managing through 2010 and assuming that we dont get any benefit from the physician fee fix and the rest.  I mean how willing are you to be the smoother for the senior as you go from 2010
column483: think of the business kind of over that two-year cycle.  And
column484: you kept saying if we could take lower margins a long with the net earnings growth
column485: but I guess coming back to more
column486: would you be willing to take no earnings growth to be that smooth
column487: as long as you could see your way to the fact that in 2011 this gets fixed and gets back into the rates?\nMike McCallister: Well what we can never count on is a long-term thing
column488: from the standpoint of the political side of this.  That idea is clearly one thats on the table.  We look at that sort of thing all the time and I think we owe it to ourselves to do that.  Because
column489: we have said all along we plan on being on Medicare over the long term.  We think it is a long - term business opportunity even with some of the clouds that are out there.  So yes
column490: we have to think about that
column491: but I would also say that there is no guarantee that it would go the other way in 2011
column492: because someone may step in and intervene in that formulary process. So the formula would say it comes back in 2011
column493: but one of the real judgment calls is whether you trust it will actually happen or not.  So
column494: these are all what we get paid to think about and try to make decisions around and I can tell you our bias going in is we anticipate growing the companies earnings every single year.  As like in 2010
column495: we plan to do it again. So we will have to work through it. Quickly
column497: there are other lines of business that are a part of our ability to make money. So
column498: those are parts of the levers that we constantly evaluate.  It isnt just MA that we do here
column500: do you think it is completely unfeasible?  So
column501: say you got there and you had confidence on the 2011
column502: its coming back: is it completely unfeasible to think about 2010 as being a flat to modestly down earnings year?\nMike McCallister: It is way too early
column504: to talk about that.  I mean
column506: the principles we operate around here is early earnings
column507: we still have that as our bias.  We have work to do on all this Medicare bit work. We have to see what our competitors have done in October
column508: before we will even have a good yield
column509: no matter which way we go.  So we are always in this cherry because of the way this business
column511: has been and the timing around it. You know
column512: we put our cards on the table and we dont know how theyre going to play until we turn them all over in October and then we have a really good view of the following year.  Generally we have done a pretty good job of being able to look at that point forward and have a pretty good view of it.  So
column513: I dont see anything different at this point.\nJohn Rex: Okay
column514: but you wouldnt dismiss it out of hand. That is a possibility at least.\nMike McCallister: Well
column515: I mean we have an obligation to think about whats best for the company long term and clearly that could be one of the decisions
column516: but Im not here to tell you that it is.  We would be irresponsible
column518: not to think past just one year.\nJohn Rex: Right sure and can you just remind us in the longer-term
column519: again.  When you look at a Medicare member
column520: what kind of a differential do you think you have to have longer term?  What kind of differential does a senior need to perceive in terms of value in MA versus being in the traditional plan?  Also
column521: how much extra benefit do you think is the break point to get
column522: especially to get new seniors to enroll in MA?  Is it 10% do you think roughly when you look at your membership and success there?\nMike McCallister: I think that is a function.  We know the seniors fall into various segments.  Some are going to be motivated by a different inflection point around that than others are
column523: so there is no single way to think about that.  Some are more focused on benefits versus premiums.  I think it is overly simplistic to think of this as a homogenous crowd
column524: because they are not. We put a lot of work into trying to find out where those inflection points are among the various segments to try to get the right balance between premiums and benefits to appeal to as broad a population as we possible can. Because
column525: we think we can meet all of them at some point in some product array.   So
column526: there is no single way to think about that.\nJohn Rex: I guess I was thinking when you think about their all end costs and traditional versus regular.  Do you assume that seniors would still enroll if you couldnt score any kind of cost save between MA and Private Medicare?\nMike McCallister: Well if it was a perfectly flat environment we would have a less compelling of a value proposition
column527: but we do have some things just beyond the benefits.  I mean we have the simplicity of having a single insurer with an umbrella coverage that covers everything from Part A
column529: C and D.  All of that is valuable.  We have better information flows than a traditional line up of Medigap.  I mean if any of you had parents that are sick and you have all of these separated plans
column530: it is a nightmare just to do the paperwork. So the value proposition goes beyond just the benefits and the premium
column531: but those are obviously the most powerful ones.\nJohn Rex: Great
column532: thank you.\nOperator: Your next question comes from Carl McDonald with Oppenheimer \u0026 Co. Inc. Carl McDonald - Oppenheimer \u0026 Co. Inc. Assuming status quo on the Medicare rates for 2010
column533: do you anticipate from an industry perspective enrollment will be flat
column535: or down relative to the million plus lives that have been added the past couple of years?\nJim Murray: Based upon where everything is being discussed now
column536: I would anticipate that there would continue to be some growth.  As we talked earlier
column537: when you array us and our products against a traditional program and a Medigap policy to go with that

column153: the management of endometrial and cervical cancer has been one of our largest and fastest growing areas of focus.  The clinical value of converting these predominantly open high invasive operations to a minimally invasive da Vinci procedure has become widely accepted.  The surgeons at Northwestern University Medical Center in Chicago reported the impact this shift was having on fellowship training at their university.  Dr. Anna Hogstra and team authored a paper entitled
column154: Robotic Surgery in GYN Oncology: The Impact on Fellowship Training which was published in the May edition of the Journal of Gynecologic Oncology.  Prior to the adoption of da Vinci hysterectomy for both endometrial and cervical cancer
column155: Northwesterns fellows predominantly participated in open surgery which represented 94.4% of their surgical oncologic training.  This percentage corresponded with the level of open cancer surgery within their practice
column156: but three months post da Vinci implementation
column157: the fellows participated in robotic procedures was up to 45%.  After six months
column158: 72%; and after 12 months
column159: it was up to 92%.  The author summary was as follows
column160: and I quote
column161: Fellows surgical training underwent a dramatic change with the introduction of robotic surgery program.  The management of endometrial and cervical cancer was impacted the most by robotics.  Robotic surgery broadened fellowship surgical training
column162: but balanced surgical training and standardized fellow training modules remain challenges for fellowship programs. The transition from open surgical oncologic management toward Da Vinci is not limited to US borders.  In the May edition of the Journal of Minimally Invasive Gynecology
column163: Dr. Magioni and Piretti from the European Institute of Oncology
column164: a teaching hospital in Milan
column165: Italy
column166: published a paper which outlined their significant shift toward the robotic approach to endometrial and cervical cancer surgery.  The authors reviewed patient data from 80 consecutive da Vinci hysterectomies for endometrial carcinoma.  Data collected included BMI

column174: we observed a substantial change in our surgical activity.  For endometrial cancer

Weve always believed that patients evaluate their surgical treatment options using an equation that balances efficacy and invasiveness.  There is perhaps no clear example of a more favorable score than that associated with a Da Vinci cardiac procedure.  Even though the growth of cardiac category has not mirrored urology or gynecology
column182: the relief from postoperative pain and suffering probably exceeds them both. In the April edition of the journal Cardiology
column183: Dr. Bonatti and team from Innsbruck Medical University in Innsbruck
column184: Austria
column185: and the University of Maryland in Baltimore set out to evaluate postsurgical quality of life at 3
column187: and 12 months
column188: comparing open revascularization to da Vinci revascularization.  The study included 120 patients split pretty evenly between open sternotomy and Da Vincis endoscopic approach.  Nine patients were converted from an endoscopic approach to a sternotomy which were also assessed postoperatively.  The comprehensive analysis evaluated several factors
column189: including but not limited to hospitalization
column190: operating time
column191: postsurgical pain and discomfort
column192: time to resuming normal activities such as taking shower
column193: gardening
column194: riding a bicycle
column195: driving a car
column196: and shopping.  The result of the comparisons was pretty dramatic. Hospitalization for the da Vinci patients was approximately half as long when compared to the open patients.  The time to take a shower was reduced from 9.8 days for an open approach to 3.7 days for the da Vinci approach.  Gardening was reduced from 54.2 days to 22.2 days
column197: driving a car from 35.5 days to 16.4 days
column198: walking outdoors from 15.5 days to 6.2 days
column199: and riding a bicycle was shortened from 67.2 days to 28.2 days.  I think you get the picture.  Virtually all quality of life metrics improve significantly incorporating the da Vinci approach.  In their conclusion
column200: the authors remarked
column201: and I quote
column202: TCAB using robotic technology leads to improved physical health
column203: shorter hospital stay
column204: and more rapid restoration of daily activity.  Conversion from TCAD to sternotomy does not lead to a quality of life impairment as compared with primary sternotomy. Regarding our urology business
column205: we continue to see a tremendous adoption of da Vinci prostatectomy
column206: nephrectomy
column207: and partial nephrectomy
column208: pyeloplasty
column209: and da Vinci cystectomy taking place on a worldwide basis.  The agenda at this years AUA Conference held in Chicago was a Da Vinci testimonial in and of itself.  Presentations
column210: clinical abstracts
column211: live surgeries
column212: postgraduate robotic courses
column213: and booth presentations dominated this years conference.  The mass global appeal of da Vinci-based procedures within the specialty of urology is truly material.  During the 4-day conference
column214: we registered over 1000 urologists at our booth
column215: representing nearly 40 countries.  The most popular area of inquiry remained DVP; however
column216: Da Vinci partial nephrectomy
column217: cystectomy
column218: and pyeloplasty are all procedures that are being rapidly adopted. Among the more interesting abstracts at this years AUA pertained to prostate cancer mortality rates following radical prostatectomy
column219: external beam radiation
column220: and primary androgen deprivation therapy.  A large multicenter series was derived from the CAPTURE Registry which accrues patients from 31 practice sites prospectively and follows then under a uniform protocol regardless of treatment and follows them through death or withdrawal from the study.  8321 men with localized disease at the time of the diagnosis with at least 6 months followup after radical prostatectomy
column221: EBRT
column222: or PADT were analyzed.  The study was authored by Dr. Matthew Cooperberg and the Urologic Oncology Group from the University of California at San Francisco.  The study used CAPRA scoring which is cancer of the prostate risk assessment which is a well-validated instrument incorporating PSA
column223: Gleason score
column224: age
column225: percentage of biopsy cores positive
column226: and caner stage.  A parametric survival model was constructed to compare outcomes among different treatments adjusting for CAPRA score and age. It was a very comprehensive and statistically relevant approach toward assessment the various treatment methods.  The results: 261 men died of prostate cancer at a median 6.4 years followup.  Adjusting for age and risk
column227: the hazard ratio for cancer specific mortality was twice as high for an external beam radiation therapy than for radical prostatectomy and 2.3 times as high for primary androgen deprivation therapy versus radical prostatectomy.  The authors conclusion
column228: and I quote
column229: Surgery for localized prostate cancer is associated with a significant and substantial reduction in cancer-specific mortality relative to EBRT and PADT.  Although not a randomized study
column230: the analysis was adjusted for clinical risk and age
column231: and it is unlikely that the unmeasured cofounders would account for the large observed difference in survival. Our strong belief has always been that the removal of the cancerous prostate through surgery is the most effective treatment for patients with localized prostate cancer
column232: especially so when taking into account long-term survival.  As patients are diagnosed earlier in life and better informed on their treatment options
column233: we would expect our DVT opportunity to further expand. This concludes my summary
column234: and I now will turn the time over to Ben.\nBenjamin Gong: Ill be providing an update on our forecast for 2009 based on our results in Q2.  First and foremost
column235: procedure growth which is the primary driver of our total revenues continues to be strong.  Procedures grew approximately 52% in the second quarter.  In our last earning call
column236: we forecasted procedures to grow more than 40% for the year.  We are increasing our forecast on procedures to grow more than 45% for the year.  This will continue to drive significant growth in our instrument and accessory revenues; however
column237: as we have mentioned previously
column238: variations in initial stocking orders and customer ordering patterns can cause our instrument and accessory revenues to fluctuate and difficult to forecast on a quarterly basis.  Therefore
column239: we will not be reinstating guidance for instrument and accessory revenues at this time. Likewise
column240: while strong procedure growth continues to drive high demand for system sales
column241: the general slowdown in hospital capital spending makes it difficult for us to accurately forecast how many systems we will be selling in the near term.  Therefore
column242: we also will not be reinstating guidance on system revenues at this time. Our service revenue model has been very consistent
column243: and we expect it to remain as it has in the past.  Were generating an average of about $148
column244: 000 in service revenue per system per year.  Since our revenue is driven largely by the installed base
column245: we continue to expect service revenue to grow approximately 35% this year. With regard to gross margin

column250: we estimate that gross margin for the year will be approximately 71%. With regard to operating expense

column252: we estimate our stock compensation charge for the year to be approximately $98 million compared with our previous estimate of $95 million.  Secondly

column257: and approximately 700
column258: 000 shares were added to the diluted share count for calculating EPS in Q2.   For the balance of the year

column454: I got the devastating news I had cancer.  In a whirlwind
column455: I was referred to an oncologist who determined I needed surgery which I had on January 22
column457: my gynecologic oncologist and I had decided to use the da Vinci surgical system because we felt it was the safest and the most likely to provide satisfactory results.  I went to sleep
column458: and when I woke up my worst postoperative issue was nausea from the anesthesia.  Around 8:30 a.m.
column459: my doctor happily discharged with simple but important instructions.  Days 1 through 3 postop were spent mostly in bed
column460: except fro a few important walks.  By day 7
column461: I no longer was taking even the mild pain pills I was prescribed
column464: I was back on my treadmill
column465: starting slowly of course.  My surgery was an amazing success on several fronts
column466: first because my surgeon had the freedom of movement and visibility
column467: he was able to be sure that he removed all the cancer.  I went from having stage 1b grade 3 endometrial cancer to no evidence of disease.  By mid February
column468: I formed a cancer advocacy research company.  We provide research grants to medical students in our area.  I speak to about 2000 people each month
column472: and about the da Vinci robotic system.  It not only saved my life; it saved my quality of life. The second is Beths story.  I am 30 years old.
