column35: while making gradual but meaningful improvement in persistency. In terms of quarter-over-quarter growth
column36: net revenues grew 12% with the following components of growth. Underlying demand is measured by bottles dispensed and accounts for approximately 7%
column37: net price accounted for approximately 2%
column38: and inventory accounted for approximately 3%. Channel inventories remain within a consistent normal range of 3 to 3.5 weeks. In the quarter we continue to add new patients at a steady rate. Roughly half of new patient starts came from new prescribers
column39: with the remaining half coming from repeat prescribers. We continue to make inroads with our target physicians. We believe later adopters are motivated by an increased awareness of the overall survival data presented at ASH
column40: while exiting prescribers are motivated by the impressive improvement in spleen volume and constitutional symptoms they are seeing in their MF patients. Through the first quarter
column41: more than 40% of our target prescribers have prescribed Jakafi at least once and about one-third of those have written for two or more patients. We expect breadth and depth of prescribing to continue to expand
column42: driven by one
column43: educational programs to help physicians identify appropriate new patients
column44: including those who do not carry the JAK2 V617F mutation. We continue to reinforce the fact that Jakafi is targeted to the JAK pathway and not necessarily any particular mutation. Number two
column45: programs including direct to patient and allied health professional activities to assist MF patients in communicating their symptoms to their physicians; and finally three
column46: positive experience as a catalyst to treat more patients. Turing to persistency
column47: we continue to see increasing use of lower dosage strengths
column48: which is driven by physicians individualizing treatment
column49: in particular by starting patients at appropriate doses and titrating downward if medically necessary. In the first quarter of 2013
column50: five and 10 milligrams strengths represented approximately 44% of dispensed bottles
column51: versus 37% in the first half and 41% in the second half of last year. Absent the use of dose titration or lower doses
column52: patients with low baseline hemoglobin and/or platelet accounts are at the highest risk for discontinuation in the first eight to 12 weeks. The use of lower doses in these populations is increasing and we expect the trend to continue as a result of (1) rapid and appropriate follow-up by our field base sales and medical teams with new prescribes; (2) enhanced outreach to patients through Incyte cares and specialty pharmacies; (3) increased awareness by prescribers of additional dose titration data from ASH. Additionally
column53: we now have data from our studies of patients with low platelets and we expect expanded dosing guidance in our label sometime in the second quarter. To assist physicians in titrating patients appropriately
column54: we introduced the Jakafi dose modification program late in the first quarter
column55: which enables physicians to order a lower strength bottle of Jakafi free of charge
column56: for any patient requiring a dose titration in 21 days or less from receiving their last prescription. The objective of this program is to make it as easy as possible
column57: both financially and administratively for a physician to down titrate to the most appropriate dose for a given patient. While early in its implementation
column58: we are seeing active utilization of the program and it is serving as an effective tool to highlight the importance of dose modification
column59: especially during the first eight to 12 weeks of treatment. In summary
column60: our first quarter performance is consistent with our expectations for steady growth in dispensed bottles
column61: largely driven by new patients and a realistically achievable improvement and persistency. We remain confident in our ability to deliver our guidance of $210 million to $225 million in net sales in 2013. In a moment Paul will talk about our pipeline
column62: which had near
column63: mid and long term catalysts. Im especially excited about the PV indication for Jakafi. With the response route fully recruited
column64: the commercial team is actively preparing for a potential approval and launch by the end of next year. Now Ill turn it back to Paul.\nPaul Friedman: Okay
column65: thanks Jim. Ill start with Jakafi. While abstracts for ASCO havent been posted
column66: the titles are now public and there is an oral presentation involving Jakafi
column67: entitled Exploratory Analysis of the Effect of Ruxolitinib on Bone Marrow Morphology in Patients with Myelofibrosis. The lead author
column68: professor Hans-Michael Kvasnicka
column69: a world recognized hematopathologist from [Agartha] (ph) University
column70: Germany
column71: is exploring the effects of treatment on bone marrow fibrosis in this patient population. While its not appropriate for me to provide detail about the ASCO presentation
column72: I can tell you that the preliminary findings originally presented by European leukemia net chair
column73: professor Tiziano Barbui
column74: at a closed session of the EON Annual meeting in February
column75: suggests that long term use of Jakafi
column76: slows the rate of advancement of bone marrow fibrosis compared to matched historical controls
column77: and with some patients can result in a reduction in the amount of bone marrow fibrosis. So were looking forward to this presentation at ASCO in June. Our most advanced programs in Jakafi are in polycythemia vera and pancreatic cancer. We expect to see results from response to PB trial were conducting in partnership with Novartis in early 14
column78: which keeps us on track to file a supplemental NDA in the first half of 14. Our second trial in PV called RELIEF is evaluating symptomatic benefit
column79: and while this study is not part of the SPA
column80: the Special Protocol Assessment agreement with the FDA
column81: and is therefore not required for FDA approval. When completed we do plan to submit results to support labeling claims on symptomatic benefit in PV. In the second half of this year we expect to have results from recap
column82: the double blind Phase II trial in patients with pancreatic cancer
column83: in which overall survival is the primary endpoint. As we previously mentioned
column84: the trials drug safety and monitoring board conducted a pre specified interim analysis of safety
column85: as well as efficacy at the end of 2012 and recommended that the study continued to completion. As there is ample evidence suggesting this regulation of the JAK pathway plays a key role in a variety of malignancies
column86: including solid tumors beyond pancreatic cancer. Its of interest to evaluate the therapeutic potential of ruxolitinib
column87: as well our other JAK inhibitors in additional malignancies. In particular
column88: given the importance of cytotoxic chemotherapy to many first and second lined solid tumor treatment regiments
column89: weve initiated an open label Phase I trial of ruxolitinib in combination with chemotherapy
column90: in patients with advanced solid tumors
column91: to better understand the tolerability of ruxolitinib when combined with myelosuppressive agents. From the results anticipated in 2014
column92: we expect to establish the maximum dose of ruxolitinib tolerated when used in combination with given chemotherapeutic regiments. Our first proprietary JAK1 inhibitor
column93: INCB39110 is being studied in proof of concept trials in myelofibrosis
column94: rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis. Results from these trials should help us select the most appropriate indications for further development. We plan to share these results at appropriate scientific meetings in the second half of this year. Now we have a second JAK1 inhibitor
column95: INCB47986
column96: which has now entered Phase I clinical development. Having two distinct JAK1 inhibitor compounds gives us a greater number of options with the program
column97: including the opportunity to pursue both oncologic and chronic inflammatory indications
column98: but with distinct molecules. We are planning to start a study this summer with one of our JAK1 inhibitors in combination with chemotherapy to better understand how JAK1 inhibitors could be used in this setting and were going to be able to compare the results with what weve seen with ruxolitinib in a similar patient group. Our second JAK 1
column99: JAK2 inhibitor baricitinib
column100: licensed to Lilly
column101: is in Phase III for rheumatoid arthritis. There are also two ongoing Phase II trials evaluating baricitinib as a treatment for psoriasis and for diabetic nephropathy respectively. In addition to our JAK programs
column102: theres several other compounds in clinical development such as our c-MET inhibitor
column103: as well as an indoleamine dioxygenase or IDO inhibitor. The c-MET inhibitor
column104: INCB28060 is licensed to Novartis and they recently initiated a Phase II clinical trial
column105: evaluating the compound as monotherapy in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma. Our IDO inhibitor for immunologic treatment of tumors is in Phase II development for melanoma and for ovarian cancer. The results of a Phase I study of the compound will be the subject of poster presentation at ASCO. The program has also generated interest among other researchers
column106: with three investigator sponsor trials being readied for initiation. Beyond these programs we have several early stage programs that address attractive oncologic targets
column107: that link well with ruxolitinib and our current development pipeline
column108: and Id expect to see some of these programs enter the clinic this year and early next year. With that operator
column109: lets open the lines for questions please.\nOperator: Thank you. (Operator Instructions). Our first question comes from the line of Matthew Roden with UBS. Please proceed with your question. Mr. Roden
column110: your line is live. Our next question comes from the line of Ian Somaiya with Piper Jaffray. Please proceed with your question.\nDo Kim: Hi. This is actually Do Kim in for Ian. A couple of questions; we were wondering if you saw any sense of seasonality in the Jakafi sales number
column111: given the sort of general weakness reported by most of the other pharma and biotech companies and also as we look ahead to the dose titration label update
column112: how should we think about its impact on second half sales in terms of growth persistence and new patient adds? Thank you.\nPaul Friedman: Yes
column113: on the question with respect to seasonality
column114: as you indicated
column115: the first quarter is usually the most difficult for a couple of reasons
column116: particularly from products that are relatively expensive and have a significant percentage of reimbursement through Medicare Part D
column117: because you have patients reentering the donut hole and you have deductibles being reset. As we look at the fourth quarter prescriptions and compare them to the first quarter prescription
column118: we probably had a small level of what we call shoebox prescriptions
column119: where patients may try to get their last prescription in December after they are through the donut hole and after their deductible has been fully met
column120: and so there is a slight drop off in the first quarter
column121: but I wouldnt say it was significant. As you see
column122: our underlying demand remained strong in the first quarter. So I think we were able to power through that. The other issue is that we simply had a reduced number of shipping days in the first quarter. The first quarter had 52 shipping days versus 64 in the fourth quarter. But despite that
column123: I think we had a very solid first quarter and we carried good momentum in to the second. Regarding the persistence trend and the new patient start trends for the rest of the year
column124: we are not going to quantify those beyond what we said in the prepared remarks
column125: but we are encouraged by the fact that the new patient starts remain strong
column126: consistent with previous quarters
column127: and we are seeing gradual
column128: but important improvement in persistence
column129:
and those two drivers give us the confidence that well achieve our guidance for the year.
Do Kim: Great. Thank you very much.

we do expect the 5 and 10 to increase as a share of total doses. So we would expect to see that 44% grow over time.

column165:

Our best quantification of persistence right now is seen in our ability to drive titration and use of lower doses and we are seeing that happening. Again

column172: great. Thank you.\nOperator: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Abrahams with Wells Fargo. Please proceed with your question.\nBrian Abrahams: Hi. Thanks for taking my question and congratulations on a good quarter. Given the recent rejection of zelgen in Europe
column173: I was wondering if you and your partner had any changes to the way you might approach the development of Baricitinib. Any tweaks you might make to the development program? And how confident are you in the differentiation of baricitinib from zelgens
column174: such that you dont believe you would necessarily fall into the same pitfalls that they did. And I have a quick follow-up.\nPaul Friedman: So
column175: this is Paul and then Ill ask Rich to add anything that he thinks I didnt cover or didnt make clear enough and I really think at the end of the day
column176: the question is best posed to Lilly
column177: but we certainly can pine on it and there is some very important aspects to the question that you asked. In particular
column178: we all listened to the advisory committee that was conducted with Pfizer
column179: and based on what we learned during that
column180: and knowing what Pfizers Phase III study was
column181: we used the learnings from the Pfizer structure study to do a couple of things. One is to increase the sample size
column182: and the second
column183: very importantly
column184: was to enrich for patients more at risk in the RA population for structural deterioration in the absence of effective treatment. And so we
column185: and I believe Lilly remained quite confident in the ability to demonstrate an improvement in structure in the target population. Beyond that
column186: and I think importantly
column187: although the proof will be in the pudding when Phase III is complete or that the Phase II data with baricitinib
column188: its a JAK inhibitor that spares JAK 3 in contrast to tofacitinib. The Phase II has not been associated with opportunistic interactions
column189: other than a few cases of uncomplicated zoster
column190: shingles for example or with malignancies. And while the Phase III data will be important to confirm this profile
column191: we may well see a better risk benefit profile than we have seen with tofacitinib. And so we remain confident in the potential approval for Baricitinib for RA in the EU
column192: as well as in the United States and around the world. Rich.\nRich Levy: Yes
column193: the only thing Id add is
column194: I think that because tofacitinib is going to potentially be approved with the 5-milligram dose and not the 10
column195: and they had their positive structure data at 10
column196: I think that also had an effect. And with respect to Baricitinib
column197: the 4-milligram dose
column198: it was at the top dose that Lilly is studying
column199: is looking really good
column200: looked really good in Phase II from a safety perspective
column201: as well as from and efficacy perspective. They have MRI data
column202: even though they havent had x-ray data to support that it was going to have effects on bone. They have that data from their MRI studies. So as Paul said
column203: we think its going to be safe enough to have the top doses go through
column204: and that should with the enhanced design of the structure study come out positive. So I think in some ways we are looking at this as an opportunity.\nBrian Abrahams: Thats very helpful
column205: thanks. And then just one quick follow-up and Ill hop back into queue. With the trials
column206: the Phase II for 110 and continuing to move along
column207: can you give us any more clarity on which of those trial readouts we might expect in the back half of this year? Thanks.\nPaul Friedman: Yes. So the psoriasis study may very well get presented at EADV
column208: I think which is in October in Istanbul I believe. The rheumatoid arthritis data may very well get presented at ACR
column209: and the myelofibrosis data may very well get presented at ASH. But all of those
column210: none of them have been  either some of them have not even been submitted yet and others have not heard back until theyll be accepted for presentation. Should any of those not happen
column211:
well think about backup plans or potentially just top line fairly than otherwise expected.
Brian Abrahams: Great. Thank you.
Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Salveen Richter with Canaccord. Please proceed with your question.
Andrew Jappy: Hi
column212: this is Andrew on the line for Salveen. My question is on the pancreatic cancer
column213: kind of how we should think about the expectations there
column214: and what you need to see in that trial to maybe get a label expansion. If theres any significant improvement in OS that would be necessary or would you need to go to Phase III. Thanks.\nPaul Friedman: Okay. So the study was designed as clearly a Phase II study
column215: one that where we did not have expectations
column216: but this study by itself would lead to any type of approval
column217: accelerated or otherwise. In pancreatic cancer would be the idea of being that wed mostly likely need to go Phase III. Is there a possibility that the results could be so robust that we might actually approach FDA
column218: trying to get an accelerated approval on this
column219: based on a commitment to do a second study later? Its possible
column220: but I wouldnt suggest that thats our expectation. And in terms of things like what does the hazard ratio need to be
column221: it has to be in a range where we feel comfortable that its worth doing another study
column222: that wouldnt be so large
column223: and I think theres a good chance that that will be the case. But in terms of a hazard ratio that would be necessary for FDA to consider this as a basis of approval by itself
column224: I really wouldnt want to try to predict that. Things are changing a little bit. At FDA
column225: theres more emphasis on breakthrough drugs. The oncology divisions have been calling a lot of things
column226: breakthrough drugs lately
column227: so I dont know that you can necessarily just go on past experience
column228: given the changes that are going on down there right now.\nAndrew Jappy: Okay
column229: great. Thank you very much.\nOperator: Our next question comes from the line of Ying Huang with Barclays. Please proceed with your question.\nChristina Zhang: Hi

column237: I believe three or four different doses plus placebo. The study is not big by any means. These are not meant to be studies that would go directly to Phase III

column241: the results of the one-month data
column242:
as well as the updated three-month data.

Rachel McMinn: Yes
column271: I have two questions. As we go into ASCO
column272: I wanted to try to pick your brain Rich or Paul on how to think about the fibrosis remodeling data that were going to see for Jakafi. A couple of years ago there was no improvement in fibrosis and that was considered a bad thing and now that we are seeing it
column273: there is some discussion about
column274: oh Im not sure how it matters
column275: because fibrosis is not correlated to survival outcomes. So it seems like a circular argument to me
column276: but I wanted to pick your brain on that. And then just secondarily

column279: in order for you to really invest in two inflammatory programs
column280: and I wanted to again get your sense of

Thank you.\nPaul Friedman: Okay. So first on this fibrosis. I mean in the past what we have seen was that we were not seeing a lot of reversal of fibrosis. As you can see
column282: if you do a bone marrow transplant and then within six months to a year
column283: you can often see less fiber in the marrow. So its really only when you got to compare to a matched historical control of patients who had received HU
column284: that we realize the main finding is that you are seeing less progression. Its progressing more slowly than that much control
column285: and also that there are some patients and I cant release the percentage of patients that actually had decreases in the amount of fibrosis in the marrow. So is that a game changer? I dont really think so. I mean
column286: as you said
column287: I dont know that that changes the view on  we know we have data out there saying theres an improvement in survival. It was dependent or independent of fibrosis
column288: not sure it really makes a difference there. But I think that probably some physicians out there that would be swayed by that sort of data that may have not been swayed by survival from studies that were not exactly planned around survival and that symptoms was one thing
column289: maybe there will be some patients
column290: maybe some physicians will start patients who are not as symptomatic
column291: but I dont think its a game changer by any means and we can talk about it more when the data is actually presented. With respect to the second question on differentiation
column292: I mean its not just a question of differentiated from Baricitinib. Its a question of differentiation from the range of new competitors that may exist at the time
column293: and so we are not going to get into what we may or may not know about our results at this time. We are saving that until we have more complete data and give some of those presentations at the meetings I talked about earlier
column294: in both psoriasis and RA on the inflammation side. But I will say that these are large investments and to bring these drugs to markets for these indications and I would not see us going forward just to have a late entry need to. So they would need to be some level of differentiation.\nRachel McMinn: And just one quick one for me. Assume that PML is not going to be reported in the FDA label for Jakafi. Have you had your discussions with regulatory agencies

column298: but since weve actually proposed something there
column299: I can give you a clear view that there will be something there
column300:
because they are not going to say dont put anything in.

column132: thanks. Two questions please. Could you talk about thoughts on monetization of Instagram and maybe just potentially how you think about the ability to monetize that versus your core Facebook asset? And then secondly
column133: Sheryl
column134: could you talk about on the vertical basis where you think the biggest wide space opportunities are for advertising revenue for Facebook and the particular industries that you look at that they are materially underrepresented on Facebook where you could have the greatest growth going forward? Thanks a lot.\nMark Zuckerberg: Sure. I'll answer the Instagram question. Kevin has always been clear that we're building Instagram to be at business and that we expect that over time we're going to generate a lot of profit from it and probably through advertising. Now that all said
column135: right now it's just growing still quickly. I mean the number that we just said was 130 million monthly actives. Video product is growing really quickly. There are so many directions to expand this in that we think that the right focus for now is to continue just focusing on increasing the footprint of Instagram. And when the right time comes then we'll think about doing advertising as well
column136: but I think that's going to be a really big opportunity.\nSheryl Sandberg: In terms of growth opportunities
column137: I think in terms of vertical categories
column138: we have big growth opportunities across the board. There are certainly verticals that were stronger than others which were very strong
column139: for example in CPG. But even though we've grown spend significantly
column140: we're still a tiny portion of the spent that CPG advertises. And even in the verticals where I think we've done very well
column141: starting to penetrate
column142: there's a lot of room for growth. I think as you think about different industries using the power of online marketing
column143: we see different levels of adoption but I'm a believer that over time this is where people are spending their time and any marketer who's trying to reach people is going to spend their resources there as well.\nOperator: The next question comes from the line of Jordan Rohan with Stifel
column144: Nicolaus. Your line is open.\nJordan Rohan: Thanks so much. I think it's fairly easy too when talking to advertisers to access that there has been this latent demand for advertising on Facebook. But when you look across the globe
column145: it's a little bit harder to address the advertising community. Can you talk about the growth of the ad sales force and the ad ops and all the people required to really bring that outside of the major U.S. and Western European markets? And specifically is there a chance that you believe that Asia-Pacific and rest of world markets can see a meaningful continued and sustainable shift higher in ARPU than where we are today? Thank you.\nSheryl Sandberg: Yes
column146: I'm a big believer that revenue opportunities exist all over the world and our gross was very strong across regions
column147: including outside of the U.S. for this time. We're up to over 40 offices and we have sales teams on the ground in over 40 offices and we're seeing really good adoption and really good growth across. You mentioned Asia
column148: I was actually in Japan and Korea meeting with advertisers just a few weeks ago and we are seeing companies that really weren't doing much with us a year ago increasingly adopt us as part of a core part of their spend. So I remain very optimistic about our growth across Asia and the rest of the world.\nOperator: The next question comes from Youssef Squali with Cantor Fitzgerald. Your line is open.\nYoussef Squali: Thank you very much. Two questions please. Can you talk about the mix of growth in direct selling versus programmatic selling for you guys and where do you see that going forward? And in terms of just on the cost side
column149: I guess looking at the investment and by the way David
column150: thanks for the color about operating expenses and guidance for the second half
column151: but as you look at longer term
column152: how far can you see that 50% increase in operating expenses still being sustained as you
column153: I guess just looking at 2014? I know you're not guiding to 2014 right now
column154: but just as we look at the model going forward how far do you think you can sustain growth in operating expenses faster than growth in revenues? Thank you.\nDavid Ebersman: Yeah
column155: thanks for your question. Your first question about direct selling versus programmatic
column156: the mechanism that most people buy from Facebook is through the option that we offer
column157: but that doesn't mean that we're not  we don't have a sales force that's out calling on clients. Sheryl can expand on that if you want.\nSheryl Sandberg: Yeah
column158: we sell both directly to our sales team so it's in-person and online. And what I think you mean by programmatic which is through third party such as DSPs and other  one thing worth noting is that FBX which is part of that programmatic selling is actually a very small part of our business and I think sometimes people don't understand that. So that piece is quite small. We are expanding both our direct selling efforts both to sales teams and online as well as the third parties we work with
column159: and we think having a healthy and growing ecosystem on both sides is really good for the development of our business.\nDavid Ebersman: You asked about investments looking forward to next year
column160: I think philosophically is the easiest way to answer that which is we still think we're early in the journey of building the service that we want Facebook to be and there's lots of work ahead of us to do and lots of things to do. And our plan will continue to be to invest aggressively in the areas that we think are important to improve our strategic positioning and to drive our ability to grow revenues and profits over the long run. We also know that to be the great company that we want to be
column161: we have to be disciplined in everything that we do and focus our spend on the areas that are really most important. So
column162: the challenge for us just by any company is finding that right balance. I really can't comment on 2014 yet honestly just because we haven't  I don't know what 2014 is going to look like. We tend to plan in six-month blocks and I think have our act together pretty well for what we're going to try to do in the second half of this year
column163: but haven't been on the conversation about next year yet.\nOperator: The next question comes from the line of Anthony Diclemente with Barclays. Your line is open.\nAnthony Diclemente: Thanks a lot. I have one for Sheryl and one for David. Sheryl
column164: I'd be interested in hearing a little bit about the relative progress of impression-based selling versus performance-based and you mentioned the ecommerce  the doubling from ecommerce from direct response and I guess I just wanted to know if you've increased the amount of inventory that you're selling on an impression basis versus performance? And then David
column165: I had a follow-up on the CapEx. It just seems like an interesting time for CapEx to be coming in when video usage and video uploads could be growing\nSheryl Sandberg: We may have lost the question
column166: but I'll take the first half while we wait for the second piece to come back. On the first piece
column167: our system works that you can buy by CPM or CPC and we let advertisers choose. I think both parts of our business are healthy and growing. I think when people talk about impression-based purchasing or buying
column168: what they're really trying to get at is brands. And brand is a very important
column169: one of our four segments and one that's growing. When you think about what brand spenders are doing
column170: they're trying to get discovery. And I think we've made a lot of progress there. We now work with every one of the global AdAge 100 over the past year. Now that said
column171: people are in different parts of that spectrum. We have brand advertisers who are looking for discovery who have advertised with us for a long time
column172: proven the value and are really expanding and these others that are newer
column173: that are experimenting that aren't as convinced yet and it's our job to get there and convince them. I think what people are increasingly seeing is we have a big brand opportunity. We have a massive engaged audience
column174: 88 million to 100 million people in the U.S. during primetime hours who are on Facebook. We offer discovery and we have a unique opportunity to take people all the way through the funnel. In one example
column175: a recent one that I really like is T-Mobile did an ad campaign with us to attract people to sell new phones. They used our offer ads to do it. 9% of the people who claimed the offer converted to T-Mobile within 10 days and they had over 20 times return on their ad spend which is just incredibly strong in the industry and I think that shows the power of what we can do with impressions
column176: taking people all the way through the funnel.\nDavid Ebersman: Anthony
column177: I'll try and answer your question about CapEx as best I could. You got cut off as you probably know
column178: so I only got about  well
column179: I don't know how much of it I got but I got enough to give it a shot. And really the best way I can think to answer it is to describe for you the variables that influence what CapEx requirements are for the company. So clearly the number of users is near the top of the list
column180: and also the time at which the users use the service. So adding users who are off peak -- the Facebook peak provides less of a burden for our infrastructure than people who are using at the same time as our peak hours
column181: because we can leverage what we built to peak. A second thing is definitely the level of engagement with those users and that seem to be where you were going with your question about video. That is and will continue to be
column182: we hope something that drives up requirements for our infrastructure because it means people are really engaging and finding new ways to use the service. What has helped us I think is the two variables that come next. One is just the cost of the equipment itself and the datacenters and over time Moores Law and other things and competition in the market have helped us to really be able to bring down the cost for each unit of equipment we use. And then the next variable which I mentioned in my remarks which I think is a really important one is just the efficiency of what we build. So over time I think Facebook has impressively succeeded at making the hardware we use more efficient and the software that we run on it more efficient in terms of how much compute power that is needs. The last variable of course probably the hardest to predict is product development
column183: is just what we build and how that influences what the computer requirements are. So clearly the variable you emphasized which was engaging with higher content things is one of the things that will influence the CapEx over time
column184: but it's a pretty complicated equation
column185: but I think right now were managing well. I think were pleased with how 2013 is coming together in that regard.\nOperator: The next question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch. Your line is open.\nJustin Post: Thank you. As we look back since mobile ramp back in 3Q last year
column186: it's been pretty lumpy and it bounced around quarter-over-quarter

column189: I really appreciated the Time Spent metric

column191: but can you tell us how that compares to say a quarter ago or a year ago? Thank you.\nDavid Ebersman: So in terms of the progression of mobile
column192: and were really pleased overall that on newsfeed ads in general and on mobile in particular are working so well in terms of the performance theyre providing to marketers and how users are engaging with them. For a new product like this
column193: I dont think we should be that surprised at the sort of quarter-to-quarter progression it's going to be harder to predict than it would be for a more mature product. I think one of the things that happened in the second quarter is that as the investments weve made started to really come together. We had a lot more demand in our system that met the quality bar that we set for feed
column194: so were able to place that demand intelligently in a manner where it performed well and didnt have a meaningful impact on the user experience. So I think that more feed eligible demand was a big part of the story. And I think one of the really good pieces of news for us is how well the price held up as we did that
column195: as we increased the number of ads we showed in feed. So for many of our ads as you know marketers are bidding for clicks in an auction and the auction determines the price for supply both demand
column196: the cost per click price. And in the second quarter and this specific
column197: Im going to give you is relative to the first quarter of this year because it's hard to do a year-over-year for mobile and for newsfeed because it just didnt really didnt exit a year-ago. Q2 relative to Q1
column198: the number of clicks in our system went up a lot and we might have assumed that price would decline as click number increased because were basically pushing out the supply curve and changing the point where supply would meet demand. And thats not what happened. Cost per clicks for feed ads increased and really demonstrating to us that demand was growing rapidly as well as were increasing the supply of ads we were showing. So it's not a perfect comparison because Q2 is seasonally stronger than Q1
column199: but it's -- I dont think the seasonality explains the agenda I just provided. And I think thats a really encouraging metric for us. And your second question was \nJustin Post: Time spent.\nDavid Ebersman: Time Spent. We just -- unfortunately we dont have a lot of longitudinal data for Time Spent. It's not something that we had instrumented well going back more deeply in time because it's hard -- well it's hard on every interface and it's particular hard on mobile. We feel pretty good about where we are now in terms of the quality of the instrumentation. It is up on a per user basis. As you would imagine it's not -- it's gone quarter-over-quarter sequentially on a per user basis
column200: it will be growing slowly. On an aggregate basis of course it's benefited from the fact that we have such a nice and consistent increase in the number of daily users of this service.\nOperator: The next question comes from Ross Sandler with Deutsche Bank. Your line is open.\nRoss Sandler: Great
column201: thanks guys. David

column207: users

Your question about what drove the increase? I think everything contributed. I think thats one of the things thats encouraging about where we're
column218: is we do have more users. We have more demand that enabled us to share more newsfeed ads. Were really pleased with how click through had held up

The strategy for that has  we shifted a bit to focus on building more business tools for developers than a lot of work were seeing is folks have shifted towards using products like mobile app installs and originally we were  we had a little bit of skepticism about how happy developers would be with a system where they would pay to get more distribution. But what weve actually found is that the NBS is really high for this
column235: because its just more stable than anything else that theyve had. In the past its the most stable way that they have to grow their app. So were basically focused on doing now is  we think about advertisers in terms of these used cases that folks had on this local businesses. They are great brands. They are developers

column241: we have a question from Scott Devitt with Morgan Stanley. Your line is open.\nScott Devitt: Thanks. I had a bigger picture question for Mark. column242: but it will be interesting to hear your views on the company's performance against the longer term aspirations and core values that you've put in the letter? Thanks.\nMark Zuckerberg: Yeah
column243: I think we're early. And one of the interesting things over the past six months or so is reaching 1 billion people was this big rallying cry for the company for a long period of time. And I think as we've passed that
column244: we've seen the ambition that the company has grow. And reaching 1 billion users was a great first thing to focus on because no one had ever built a service that had 1 billion active people who were signed in and had real identity before. But in a way it's actually kind of just an abstract
column245: there's nothing magical about 1 billion. The real goal is to connect everyone in the world and help people map out everything that there is. Well
column246: I think what we're seeing is as some of the products succeed is just the ambition increased to be able to do more of these and taking on more longer term things. At the same time
column247: I think what you have is we weren't happy with the quality of our mobile experiences
column248: rewinding 18 months. So we had just a lot of foundational work to do and I think coming into this year
column249: we kind of could tell internally that we were turning a corner on that. We were in good shape and could start to play a bit more offense. But as I think the numbers from this quarter suggest
column250: I think we're really starting to see the upside of some of the investments that we've been making over the last period.\nOperator: The next question comes from Mark May with Citigroup. In terms of pricing I think  we were pleased with the pricing growth in the first quarter too. The net across the world was a 3% average in the first quarter but that was much higher in the U.S. and Canada

So it's there in one side of the comparison going forward.\nSheryl Sandberg: In terms of where the growth is coming from in terms of ad units
column260: in terms of our market segments direct response marketers are a very big contributor to the growth. That's why I started with them in the remarks and in the Q\u0026A. Ecommerce doubled year-over-year and they're doing that by using a bunch of our different ad products; everything from post to offers to other things
column261: but it's really about looking for those contributions. We've also seen a lot of growth
column262: as I said
column263: in mobile app install ads; small market but growing rapidly and it's a market where we offer a product that there is almost nowhere else to get the kind of returns and opportunity we offer.\nDavid Ebersman: I'm just going to add one more thing just in case I
column264: in anyway
column265: created any confusion and I have no evidence that I did yet. But the price per ad that I was talking about in this question reflects not the same thing as the cost-per-clicks that I answered in a question earlier because price per ad will also incorporate the click-through rate as well as the cost-per-click for click-based ad and also includes ads that are purchased on an impression basis. So most of the pricing metrics we provide are per ad inclusive of click-through rates and impression-based ads. The CPC metric I gave earlier was just
column266: I think
column267: a specific and useful metric in understanding how much strong demand contributed in the second quarter.\nOperator: The next question comes from Ken Sena with Evercore Partners. Your line is open.\nKenneth Sena: Hi. So just maybe if we could drill into the comment around ecommerce spending doubling and it seems as though FBX and third party effort
column268: its growing fast but its small and the same with the app install effort. But can you talk a little bit about what drove that doubling in Europe year-on-year? Thanks.\nSheryl Sandberg: I think direct response marketers have had more opportunities to use our system
column269: use our product and we've also made a very major investment in helping them measure returns and helping them connect what's happening both online and as well as throughout the system. So direct response marketers tend to be buyers when they have an ROI metric. They're looking for that ROI metric and their budgets are flexible around those ROIs. So as they've invested with us and hit their ROI metrics
column270: their budgets go up and they make those adjustments very quickly. That's why when they start using the products and see the value they create
column271: they are able to grow very quickly even within a quarter or within a week or within a month because they adjusted their budgets.\nOperator: Your next question comes from Rory Maher with Hillside Partners. Your line is open.\nRory Maher: Thanks. A couple of quick questions. First on hiring

column274: retail
column275: telecom
column276: that kind of category mix? And are there any that have grown particularly well the past year?\nMark Zuckerberg: Yeah

But I mean there was a systemic issue where our country doesn't produce the volume of engineers that the companies would want to hire. And I think that that's a lot of what you hear these companies talking about. We're doing really well competitively right now. We have a really strong program on colleges where we can continue to attract a lot of best people who are graduating. We do really well at hiring senior engineers from across the valley as well. But it's just something that we invest a huge amount of time and it's really important.\nSheryl Sandberg: In terms of where we're growing by category; I've mentioned CPG

column281: there. Great numbers
column282: you guys. Congratulations. Two questions. One on

column284: Custom Audiences is small but growing and important. We doubled what I said as we doubled the number of marketers using the product Q2 over Q1
column285: and that also has included getting us to 50 of the AdAge 100. As I've talked about as a large brand advertisers the AdAge from 100 have a long sales cycle and it takes a lot of work that happened to adapt products and so seeing adoption this quickly of something

column23: comparatively strong mortgage banking revenues and above average credit quality. We took advantage of favorable market conditions by executing prudent balance sheet actions that enhanced our liquidity

column30: we took advantage of some -- of the stronger risk appetite from investors in the current low interest rate environment by selling over $1 billion of private label mortgage-backed securities previously held in our available-for-sale investment portfolio. The after-tax loss on the sale amounted to $28 million or $0.22 per common share. This transaction resulted in higher liquidity and capital and removed a risk-sensitive asset
column31: which had been generating substantially all of our other-than-temporary impairment charges
column32: from our balance sheet
column33: and assists us in preparation for entering the 2014 CCAR process. Also during the quarter

column36: following the second anniversary of the Wilmington Trust merger

column38: having an after-tax impact of $15 million or $0.12 per common share. Taken together

column192: we made a slight increase in prices of our product at the beginning of the year. Some of that was a result of the new medical device tax and so forth. But at this point in time
column193: we haven't really made any further adjustments on pricing since then. So the effect that I think you're seeing
column194: from an external standpoint
column195: has really more to do with mix shift than anything.\nThomas M. Prescott: And Robert
column196: if I could just pile on
column197: the slide that Shirley and the team have put in here
column198: on the very last slide in our webcast slides really try to break out those effects net of mix. And if you look at that in general
column199: I would say pricing is stable net of mix and other factors. And so it's not so much a comp issue. We're actually -- pricing is pretty stable.\nRobert P. Jones: Got it. And then if I could just move over to the case guide
column200: the 3% to 5% increase sequentially
column201: seems like a big guide up
column202: especially in light of some of the uncertainties that seem to be surrounding the consumer as we sit here in October
column203: maybe more of a qualitative question
column204: but was just wondering if you could talk a little bit of how you're factoring in some of the uncertainty in the marketplace and some of the pressures around consumer sentiment into your fourth quarter outlook?\nThomas M. Prescott: Let me maybe start and then may be a pull-up for David
column205: since this is his first-cycle with us. I think his objective view might be useful here. But I guess what I'd first start with is that we have the same kind of visibility we always have in our business cycle
column206: about 30 days or so. And what you're seeing is a fundamentally solid business today
column207: with initiatives that are working for us. And I'd take you back to earlier in the year. We made investments exiting 2012 in headcount and coverage in our geographies: Europe
column208: North America. We've made investments in new consumer programs. We spent a little more money. We've told our owners what we're doing purposely
column209: our goal was to generate volume as we exit the year and we're starting to see that
column210: so we're gratified by that. But it reflects what we're seeing in the business. And we're not smart enough to break apart all of the elements going on. But with that said
column211: I think there's -- we've seen other data that patient traffic is stable to improving. Dental consumables are improving a bit. And when there's traffic in the offices
column212: patients are willing to do a more expensive procedure
column213: an implant
column214: a restorative
column215: then that means there that the road's wide open for us to get Invisalign growth. Maybe with that
column216: I'll pivot -- let David build on his first-cycle here
column217: preparing the guidance.\nDavid L. White: Thanks
column218: Tom. Robert
column219: I guess I would -- when I first joined the company
column220: I would've thought that given 25
column221: 000 customers that we ship to in a quarter
column222: that forecasting the business would lend itself to some econometric model. But as you kind of look under the hood
column223: what you realize is we have a small number of doctors that have a very healthy practice with us that is fairly stable and relatively predictable. But on the other flipside of that
column224: we have a lot of doctors that do a small amount of business with us
column225: and that particular segment of our business tends to be more difficult to predict. So when I look at the process and so forth
column226: we have a process that kind of does a bottoms up view from the field
column227: in terms of where -- what our territory managers and so forth are seeing as they talk to their customers. We have a view from the tops down of the company
column228: which takes a look at our own statistical correlation of trends and so forth. And then as Tom was saying
column229: we also look at patient traffic and so forth and some of these other external data points
column230: and we triangulate across all of those to come up with our best view of the world. It's -- from what I can tell and
column231: I think
column232: from what some of you have experienced
column233: it's not perfect. We'd like it to get better. But I think what I can tell you
column234: at least from what I've seen and observed and so forth
column235: is I think we have a robust process. And I'd say it's representative of best practices across many industries.\nRobert P. Jones: All make sense. Just a last one David
column236: I'd slide in just on the back of that. Any thoughts
column237: I know kind of early days for you
column238:
but any thoughts about extending the outlook that you guys do provide? I know it's something that us on the sales side and I'm sure investors would appreciate very much.
David L. White: Not at this point. We give a long-term operating model. I think our operating model is where we are steering the company towards and those are the results we're trying to head towards. So probably not at this point.
Operator: Our next question comes from John Kreger from William Blair.
John Kreger: David
column239: maybe just a quick follow-on to Bob's question. Any early thoughts on 2014? Obviously
column240: you're not in the mode of providing full year guidance
column241: but are there any kind of key issues that you think we ought to be thinking about that could be key swing factors
column242: particularly around margins?\nDavid L. White: Well
column243: John
column244: a pleasure talking to you again. I guess what I would -- what I've observed and
column245: I think
column246: what you've observed as well is our business does have some degrees of cyclicality in it. Our business
column247: certainly
column248: from a revenue standpoint
column249: has seasonality. Q3 perhaps being the largest manifestation of that. But further than that
column250: there's other elements of our business that had cyclicality to it as well. Our media expenses
column251: for example
column252: might run counter seasonal. Then we make investments in the business that sometimes tend to be bulky and done on an as-needed basis and are not -- don't follow a pattern of repetition. So when you look at our Q3 performance that we've just announced and our Q4 guidance
column253: I guess
column254: the thing I would comment on is that I wouldn't use those 2 data points to extrapolate going forward. Because of that seasonality and because those 2 quarters alone do not manifest
column255: I think
column256: all the cyclicality that our business deals with. I think more representative of that -- of our business
column257: however
column258: there's our annual operating results. And I think that's probably the best guide because our annual results include -- incorporate all of those cycles in them. As you think about
column259: going forward
column260: as I said on the prior question
column261: our targeted operating model is 25 to 30 points. And I think at some point
column262: as we get to being able to consistently land within that operating model
column263: at some point
column264: we'll then update the model. But at this point
column265: I think that the best guidance I can give you is the operating model we've already talked about.\nJohn Kreger: Just one last one and I'll stop. Could you give us an update on how realign is faring with the Henry Schein salesforce?\nThomas M. Prescott: I'll take that one
column266: John. We're in very early days there. It is -- the Schein team and the Align team are working hard to ensure that the kind of the early customers and the field reps that are moving this have great experiences and we learn a lot from those cycles and make sure the product works perfectly for the patient. And Dr. Phil is creating the practice. So we kind of thought about the first year at startup. And we're right in the middle of that learning cycle
column267: we're collectively about to head off to a trade show
column268: the ADA
column269: there's greater New York
column270: there's some important cycles where Align will be out there in the market and Schein will be out there in the market
column271: and we're going to have a chance to have that discussion with customers. So very early days
column272: not going to be material for a significant amount of time
column273: but way more strategic than kind of tactical. I don't know if that's what you're looking for. That's where I'll stop.\nJohn Kreger: And are you still comfortable
column274: Tom
column275: that the margins on that product can be consistent with the rest of the business?\nThomas M. Prescott: Yes. Short answer is yes. When we -- if we stack up the take out in marketing
column276: professional marketing demand creation
column277: go-to-market
column278: our contribution margins will be similar to
column279: on a net basis
column280: similar to
column281: say
column282: an Express product for example
column283: where we got direct sales and marketing involved.\nDavid L. White: At the operating level.\nThomas M. Prescott: At the operating margin level
column284: below gross margin for sure
column285: yes.\nOperator: Our next question comes from Chris Lewis from Roth Capital Partners.\nChris Lewis: First
column286: I guess
column287: Tom
column288: you mentioned the North American Ortho case volume strength was driven partially by new ortho submitters. So I guess
column289: can you just talk a bit more about what's driving those new orthos coming on board?\nThomas M. Prescott: It's really a couple of things. We've got more of those coming out of their graduate programs
column290: maybe didn't get enough Invisalign in their program and as they're coming to a practice
column291: they're very interested in
column292: just trying to do Invisalign
column293: that's 1. Two is we have some great established ortho practices that maybe got trained 10 or 12 years ago. I would say back in the early days
column294: we weren't ready for prime time. They didn't have a great experience with the product. Couldn't address very complex needs. And as they've seen our progression
column295: they have come to the view that they need to get on board. And so we've had a number of terrific kind of market-leading practices
column296: want to reengage. In our mind
column297: those are new practices
column298: we haven't had business with them for years. And so that's the other part of the mix. Both are very positive
column299: small numbers
column300: but I think what's more important is what those kinds of practices represent over the next 3 to 5 years.\nChris Lewis: Okay. Great. And then
column301: just on the gross margin side for the fourth quarter guidance
column302: it's down sequentially. I think
column303: you had mentioned some product mix
column304: lower-priced products there
column305: but can you just discuss a little further what other factors might be planned into that? And then
column306: longer term
column307: as we look on to 2014
column308: how should we think about that gross margin trend unit?\nDavid L. White: Chris
column309: let me see if I can give you a little color. As you look at our margins in the third quarter
column310: they're
column311: I think
column312: almost a record
column313: if they're not a record for the company
column314: on the Invisalign side of the business. As we shift into Q4
column315: however
column316: though
column317: we're going to see a lesser mix of you might say
column318: the top end of our product line and that's going to get displaced with more volume in the lower end. So that mix shift is going to bring margins down to some extent. Then in my prepared comments
column319: I made a comment that we had this mid-course correction that caused an adjustment to our deferrals
column320: which is about 0.7 points of margin effect sequentially to Q3
column321: but that's nonrecurring in Q4. And so we don't have the benefit of that in Q4. We also -- we'll have more training events this quarter. And when you -- we don't -- our training business is not an 80-point margin business. And so that will tend to drag the margins down a little bit as well. And offsetting those 3 is the fact that we -- is our scanner margins should improve quarter-over-quarter as well. And so the net of that is that margins should be down sequentially a little bit. As it relates to '14
column322: again
column323: I guess
column324: the best guidance I could give you would be to look at the full year results
column325: look at the trends
column326: look at the -- and look at the operating margin
column327: the targets or the business model that we talked about and I would plan off of those things.\nChris Lewis: Okay. Great. And if I could sneak one more in. Tom
column328: just going back to the visibility into the business
column329: I was hoping you could talk about how maybe that's evolved over the past
column330: say
column331: 12 months. Seems like
column332: I think
column333: you're talking about improving that visibility in recent quarters
column334: some office surveys and other initiative to gauge more of a month-to-month trend in patient traffic and other market trends. So how has that evolved over the past year compared to third quarter of last year? And then
column335: how that contributed in the fourth quarter guidance that was given today?\nThomas M. Prescott: So I'll take my shot with -- while I'm knocking on wood
column336: we're glad to have the positive results. I think
column337: the starting point for all this is: A
column338: we have the same kind of visibility we've always had in the core flow of the business; and then
column339: B
column340: our customers don't forecast
column341: so asking them forecasting questions doesn't necessarily lead you to a factual framework you can count on. What is different
column342: there are a few things different. The evolution of business this Q3 and Q4 from last year is fundamentally different. Patient traffic started declining in U.S. dentists office in the middle of Q2 last year
column343: as we reconstructed all that. Procedures started falling with them
column344: and mix shifted to lower value procedures
column345: that really wasn't visible well into Q3 and we didn't really see it until summer didn't kind of bounce back. So that's different and that's why we keep stressing that stable to slightly improving patient traffic
column346: mix in procedures is a really good thing for us. It's a good thing for everybody
column347: but it's really good for Invisalign. To your second point about what we're doing differently
column348: we do a lot more differently
column349: a lot of things differently. When you get it wrong or you get humbled or you get surprised
column350: you ask yourself a lot of questions about what can we do. Everything's on the table. We have instituted a whole series of what we internally call poll surveys. And it's not so much of forecasting
column351: I just call it observational. We haven't been at that even a full year yet now in detail. And I would say we're far short of predictable kind of results. Our goal over time is going to be able to correlate some of that with other external factors like patient traffic. Empirical data we can observe. But boy
column352: we're well short of what I'd call predictive capabilities. So what is reflected in our outlook
column353: what is reflected in our results is good execution of business and everything we can control and a very solid environment out there in the countries that matter for us. And then
column354: maybe the third fact is we have this very low penetration for Invisalign into a pretty big darn space and we still have a lot of headroom.\nOperator: Our next question comes from Steve Beuchaw from Morgan Stanley.\nSteve Beuchaw: I wonder
column355: Tom
column356: if we're far enough along that you could give us a little bit more granularity on what you're seeing with SmartTrack? Have you been able to get a view of what kind of impact that's having in practices that were maybe early adopters or beta testers
column357: any discernible or hopefully quantifiable impact on how the mix of ortho cases there is impacted in terms of the percentage of cases that are going to Aligners in those practices?\nThomas M. Prescott: Sure. Simple answer is for the most frequent users of Invisalign
column358: including some of those that were in the pilots
column359: even a year before we released
column360: and others that just see
column361: most quickly see the benefits
column362: they have virtually all expanded case complexity and gotten most of the benefit out of it. We are still
column363: I would say
column364: working through our complete customer base. For a customer that does
column365: even a great orthodontist that's only doing 10 or 15 a year
column366: it's taking them longer to see the benefits because they generally are treating simpler cases. And they're just -- they don't have the at-bats that a high-volume doc doing 200 or 300 Invisalign cases a year would. But on those higher volume practices that are -- their progression has been towards greater complexity and earning a bigger part of their practice. And they say kind of yes to Invisalign more often when that patient asks
column367: that's the short answer.\nRobert P. Jones: Is there a case for 5 points of mix shift over some horizon
column368: can you quantify any of this for us?\nThomas M. Prescott: It's not -- I wish it was as simple as that. We actually have some internal ways we measure it. And we look at the kind of the incidences
column369: what presents with a -- at an average orthodontist or dentist office for the malocclusion and put them into categories
column370: and then we look at what that incidence is and then what they treat against that mix. That same chart varies widely by the practice and how much they've adopted Invisalign. So we have 2 things. In our most ardent supporters
column371: we get the biggest chunk of their Class 1 crowding cases
column372: adult and even teens. And again
column373: teens are harder cases to fill because everybody's aiming for absolutely perfect. And if they think they're making any clinical tradeoffs
column374: they're going to be more resistant using Invisalign. But at least for adults
column375: we're doing very well there. As you get over towards more straightforward Class 2 or even hard Class 3
column376: the doctors that have got the greatest confidence and have had the greatest results with Invisalign are much more comfortable offering that to an adult patient. So there's a temporal framework that goes along that opportunity. The least frequent users are the least penetrated to those indications would be most around Class 1. And the most frequent users who have the greatest confidence are doing it on much more complex cases. So it's not as simple
column377: I'm sorry to say
column378: I wish it was
column379: to say there's a projection of growth or share
column380: but both are being driven by evolutions like SmartTrack and G4 that give us both greater confidence and because they're getting better results with those tools.\nSteve Beuchaw: Got it. And then
column381: as my follow-up
column382: I wonder if you could give us an update on your thinking around partnerships in the world of inter-oral scanners. I wonder if there's any new thinking there? And I wonder
column383: now that you have a relationship with Henry Schein that's expanded
column384: if that might be a gateway
column385: if some of the Henry Schein partnerships might be more logical for you? And then
column386: I'll drop.\nThomas M. Prescott: Sure. Thanks
column387: Steve. The update is when there's news to talk about for interoperability
column388: we will be happy to do so. We think it's strategically valuable. You saw we keep going up around 250 to 300 basis points quarter-over-quarter in cases coming
column389: just with the iTero base among our customers. And we know there's interest out there. So it's in our best strategic interest to have those partnerships and you ought to assume that we're interested in doing that. But until we get there and can actually validate appropriate high quality scanners
column390: I don't want to project.\nOperator: Our next question comes from Chris Cooley from Stephens.\nChristopher C. Cooley: Could you help us think more towards gross margins and specifically
column391: when we think about the contribution of fourth quarter and out in the '14 for more value-oriented product offerings like Express 5
column392: how do we think about that in combination with the ramp of Realine
column393: which I realize is still in early days right now
column394: but assuming it has to become a bigger part of the mix
column395: how do we kind of weigh that when we kind of think forward on the gross margin guidance? And I have a quick follow-up.\nDavid L. White: Yes. Again
column396: we've had a few questions about 2014
column398: it's not surprising given our results in Q3 and Q4. As Tom said earlier
column400: it's really too early to call
column401: to put a vector on that and to give any guidance as it relates to how that product will impact overall mix. As it relates to gross margins
column404: that as we look over the long term
column405: that the percentage of cases that we treat
column406: particularly for simple cases with adults and so forth will increase
column407: and that will potentially drive down margins -- drive down ASPs
column409: our margins are influenced by product mix. But given that we're still growing well into double-digits year-over-year
column410: while that may have some bearing on the directional indicators for margins
column412: I don't think they'll necessarily have an indication of an effect
column414: on operating margins. So going back to
column417: I think the best guidance for '14 is
column419: going to be our operating model that we talked about.\nChristopher C. Cooley: Fair enough. And then
column420: maybe just as a quick follow-up. When we think about the scanner business
column424: could you give us a feel there in terms of the mix
column425: what's being placed versus what's actually being sold into the channel and how that may or may not be changing?\nThomas M. Prescott: I'll see if I can take that one
column426: and David can pile on if he wants to. First of all
column427: the reported gross margins are nowhere near where we want them to be or where we expect to get them over time. If I understood your question
column428: in terms of new systems going in versus services stream
column429: was that the question?\nChristopher C. Cooley: Yes.\nThomas M. Prescott: I think
column430: we spoke about roughly half and half in terms of the mix of services against new scanner placements.\nDavid L. White: I would just add to that
column431: as our scanners -- as we continue to penetrate the market with more and more scanners
column432:
that mix should go more favorably towards the service and licensing sides of that over time.
Thomas M. Prescott: With higher margins.
David L. White: Over time with higher margins.
Christopher C. Cooley: If I could
column434: just to follow on or to clarify that
column435: when the actual system is placed
column436: is the system sold outright or they placed early on
column438: I'm just trying to tease out why the margin's at 22%?\nThomas M. Prescott: Well
column439: the margin's at 22% because our build material and cost of goods
column440: we have the best scanner in the market and we don't make money on them. We -- and with pricing that has come down over the last 1.5 years
column442: with a lot of competitive entries
column444: pricing is actually stabilizing a bit in the scanner market
column445: have raised -- coming up a little bit. And we do think scanners will be ubiquitous. We think it's critically important for us to be at chair-side in the middle of a clinical discussion with the patient right there
column447: creating advantages for our Invisalign franchise and other things we intend to do over the long term. So with that said
column448: the gross margins aren't anywhere near where we want them on the scanner. We intend to fix that over time. The services stream is better and we think we've actually got some strategic advantage there over time. But it's just the build material that's expensive
column449: and it's the best scanner in the market
column451: but we'll fix that over time.\nDavid L. White: Yes
column452: and just to add to that
column454: just to make it maybe clearly
column456: that service element should grow against -- it's in proportion with the install base
column457: and not in proportion to the number of systems we're selling in any particular quarter. The other thing
column458: as you talk about the 22% gross margins in the second -- in the third quarter
column459: some of that was also the result of the fact that we were selling
column461: some of our older scanners. So that had -- that promotion to kind of move some of that inventory had a dampening effect on margins in the third quarter and that's one of the reasons why the margins in that business should be up in the fourth.\nThomas M. Prescott: Chris
column463: I didn't answer a part of your question. You were theorizing maybe there was placements instead of sales
column464: we really don't do that. So those are all sales. Whether there was a financing involved
column466: but whether it was financed for us
column468: period.\nOperator: Our next question comes from Jeff Johnson from Robert W. Baird.\nJeffrey D. Johnson: All of my questions have largely been answered here
column470: Tom. I want to make sure I understand the timing comments on the DTC
column472: your DTC spending may be down this quarter
column473: I know it had kind of flared up in the second quarter as you launched some of these new programs. And so is that just kind of a normal kind of ebb and flow of that spending? How are you thinking about maybe DTC spending given that it seems to be generating some nice top line
column474: how are you thinking about that spending over the next several quarters to couple of years?\nThomas M. Prescott: Sure. I think
column476: the broader issue of the timing and mix of spending isn't always in the same cycle with volume expansion given cyclicality
column477: seasonality et cetera. And the example
column479: was summertime is typically our strongest media
column482: everything else. And it's often a softer quarter
column484: people out on holiday in Europe
column486: where we advertise most. So in general
column487: there is a general consistency to our program spending on consumer and that is light in Q1
column490: setting up for the summer season
column491: heaviest spending exiting Q2 into the summer
column492: and then pretty strong through all the summer
column493: slowing as we exit Q3 into Q4. And you probably shouldn't see us by the time Christmas advertising is on in general just because there's so much noise. That is -- and now there's a whole -- there's a parallel mix of digital PR. Again
column495: if you see for every TV commercial that you might see on one of the -- Bravo or one of the channels we work with
column496: there's probably 10x that activity through multiple other platforms
column498: whether it's gaming and other things. So that's the visible part in traditional media on TV. But again
column499: there is generally the same profile for that spending in North America. Does that get at your question?\nJeffrey D. Johnson: Yes
column502: you had obviously some timing shifts or some fall off probably to that normal cyclicality
column503: just given the Olympics and that
column506: nothing on the horizon we need to be thinking about that might shift that timing
column507: at least in the near intermediate term?\nThomas M. Prescott: The Winter Olympics is nowhere near the media frenzy of Summer Olympics. We don't have an election year. There's a lot of things that you have to engineer around in the media world. This should -- I don't know what normal is in the dental industry but if we had to imagine a normal
column508: this feels like more of a normal. Now the second thing is we were off the air a bit more exiting '12 because we were getting ready to launch a whole new campaign. And I think
column509: when we spoke about our guidance in January for the year
column510: we were talking about investing in new assets
column511: a creation of new creative and materials and all the associated elements that go along on the digital side and everything else. So all that
column513: it wasn't necessarily visible media that was part of the first half year -- first half of the year profile in greater spending. So again -- but in general
column514: you should expect stepwise expansion investment and the same kind of impact that we expect to get for payback year-to-year.\nShirley Stacy: Operator
column517: we've got time for 2.\nOperator: Our next question comes from Brandon Couillard from Jefferies.\nS. Brandon Couillard: David
column518: just curious if you could give us an update on where we stand on the NOLs and when you expect to have to begin paying cash taxes
column519: whether that's anytime soon?\nDavid L. White: So I'll say
column520: we do pay -- I'll be clear here
column521: we do pay some cash taxes. Typically
column522: those are in foreign jurisdictions and in states here in the U.S.. As far as our U.S. federal return is concerned
column523: we do have NOL carryforwards. And currently
column526: we're making money here in the U.S.. Those taxes
column531: we do have the benefit of R\u0026D tax credit
column532: which offsets that to some degree
column533: we also have the benefit of stock exercises and the ability to deduct some of that off of it. And so it means that we use up less of our NOL than what we might have otherwise in the absence of those credits. Altogether
column534: our estimation is that our NOLs will probably run sometime into or through around 2015.\nS. Brandon Couillard: Great. And then
column536: given this is your first conference call as the new CFO
column537: I would be curious to hear your view around how you think about capital allocation and share repurchase in general with cash building on the balance sheet pretty substantially here?\nDavid L. White: Well
column541: that if a company is accumulating cash and doesn't have a need for that cash to either grow its business and just to run the business
column543: there should be a plan to figure out how to return that to shareholders. That said
column544: we just finished here in line
column546: $150 million stock repurchase plan in the June quarter. 95 -- $93 million of which was spent in that quarter. And so we just completed one of those plans. We haven't really quite come up for air yet. I would tell you that as we kind of look at our annual plan for next year and our 5-year strategic plan
column547: we are right now pulling together what we think our investment requirements are going to be for the company. And clearly
column550: are going to mean added manufacturing capacity
column552: we're going to have both domestic needs
column553: as well as international needs. And at this point
column554: we haven't really assimilated how all that's going to fit together. But at some point
column555: we will in the not-too-distant future here. And to the extent we come to a conclusion
column557: that we have excess cash that we don't need as a company. We'll figure out what plan we're going to do with it. But right now
column559: we're just not ready to declare what that next step will be. But I think
column560: if you can be patient with us
column561: we'll probably have more to say about that in the not-too-distant future.\nOperator: Our last question comes from the line of John Block from Stifel Nicolaus.\nJonathan D. Block: Maybe I can just slip in 2 or 3 questions. I guess
column564: and I'm also guessing people are going to stop asking if you're staying by your long-term margin guidance
column566: you've done a ton in the past 12 months
column569: you did some work in the international side
column570: and then you're starting to obviously post a leverage. I think
column572: the spend has been very lumpy. And so
column574: can you just speak broadly about incremental investments from here
column575: maybe not detailing what exactly they're going to be
column577: will you pull back at all
column578: will they be as lumpy as they've been in the past? Any color would be great.\nThomas M. Prescott: I guess
column579: I have to start with the word lumpy. From our perspective
column580: the business cycle itself here in the dental industry is cyclical. Maybe use that instead of lumpy. And in many areas
column582: it doesn't make sense to line up investment choices that are multiyear in nature and have a strategic value to fit them perfectly
column585: but not fit them perfectly into that kind of annual cycle we see. Q3 being a great example of one that's softer. So where we choose to make investments that during a quarter or 2 would take operating margins down a little bit
column586: as we did in Q1 when -- or into Q2 as well where we talked about it with the yearend results in January of this year
