column248: and you did have gross margins up with merchandise margins from the 10-Q saying that
column249: that was kind of up 60 basis points. And your inventories weren't too out of whack. So I guess I'm just wondering as well
column250: if you're doing any kind of bar setting as a new CEO coming in or -- because the numbers look good overall
column251: at least for Ulta
column252: to what you had issued in terms of guidance.\nMary N. Dillon: Well
column253: that's an accurate reflection of our performance relative to guidance. And really
column254: what we're doing today is just what we think is our best view of what to expect in the fourth quarter
column255: given the environment as well as our preliminary view of 2014. Ulta is and will still continue to be a high-growth company
column256: and the 2014 look that we're giving
column257: which isn't guidance
column258: but the early view
column259: is still a very high-growth company. But it is different than what was stated before. I would say this isn't about bar setting
column260: but it is about -- as Scott said and I said in my comments
column261: this is also a great time for us just to take a step back and really create a 10-year view of Ulta. It's been a very successful company for many years
column262: but like any business
column263: the environment changes
column264: whether it's the consumer environment
column265: the categories we compete in
column266: the competitive environment. So we really want to take a very thoughtful and deep view of our strategic planning. There's going to be plenty of choices we believe we have for future growth. We want to prioritize those and then come back with guidance based on that work.\nOperator: The next question is from Gary Balter of Credit Suisse.\nGary Balter: Mary
column267: the tone that we're hearing is different than on your last quarter. So is it -- could you walk us through kind of -- in the last 3 months or maybe it's longer than that
column268: what are the elements within the company that you felt aren't executing
column269: that require the investments that you're talking about that kind of say
column270: let's slow the growth
column271: let's reinvest
column272: let's pull out with a better company? Where is the focus right now for where you need to make those investments?\nMary N. Dillon: Well
column273: I guess I would say a couple of things. One is we're also in an environment that's changing and fluid in the marketplace. So as we said in the third quarter
column274: we did see a change in our trend towards the end of the quarter
column275: and we're reacting to that. So I feel very optimistic and upbeat about our prospects. And again
column276: we're going to come out of this year with a very top performance in terms of top and bottom line. But it's somewhat different than what we would have guided
column277: even really just coming in -- out of the -- in the middle of the second quarter. So that's different
column278: and that would give us a reason to say let's look at our preliminary view of 2014 and provide the best transparency to that
column279: that we can. Beyond that
column280: I feel very optimistic about our future growth prospects. I'd say the only thing that's different is
column281: as I learned about our business
column282: I continue to be very optimistic. But I think we're going to have to be choiceful in terms of how we pick our spots for future growth. There's investments that will continue to be required as we look at a competitive environment that's increasingly omni-channel. Consumer views are changing
column283: categories are evolving. So it's really not anything more than -- regardless of how this quarter performed
column284: we would have been doing the strategic planning
column285: frankly
column286: and really want to come out in the future with our best view of what that future growth looks like. And I continue -- we very much expect Ulta to continue to be a high-growth
column287: high-performance company. That stance has not changed.\nGary Balter: Okay. And just following up and then I'll get off
column288: the -- you mentioned a few times
column289: including in this answer
column290: competitive environment is changing and got tougher. What -- could you be a little more specific on what's changed from expectations? Because everybody kind of expected a difficult Christmas period.\nMary N. Dillon: I was talking about [ph] more of a long term view which was that as we know that there's more people competing in beauty and really the need to be able to really operate in a very omni-channel environment
column291: which is part of what our investment in our supply chain and ITs are going to allow us to do. In terms of the short term
column292: I would just say
column293: as we saw some impacts on our traffic -- I mean
column294: our transactions
column295: is that -- towards the end of the second quarter relative to our promotional changes
column296: we felt that it's probably a little bit more promotionally sensitive than we might have thought going into the fourth quarter. But not dramatically so.\nOperator: The next question is from Evren Kopelman of Wells Fargo.\nEvren Dogan Kopelman: I wanted to ask in terms of the slowdown you saw at the end of the quarter
column297: is it primarily a nail and fragrance category issue that you mentioned? Or did you see a slowdown in the growth rates of even the outperforming categories like the prestige skincare fragrance and salon?\nScott M. Settersten: Yes. Hey
column298: Evren
column299: a couple of data points again for people who follow the industry fairly closely. If you look back over the last couple of years
column300: so 8 to 10 quarters
column301: you would notice that both prestige and mass color cosmetic categories were really at the high-water mark at the end of fiscal 2011. So both of those categories were just into the double-digit year-over-year growth rates at that point in time
column302: and they've both been on a slow deceleration over the course of the last 2 years so that we ended our Q3 -- I think mass color year-over-year was flat
column303: and prestige color was low to mid-single-digits. So we're bucking those headwinds as well overall in our box besides the category -- the nail and the fragrance deceleration that has been talked about in the open marketplace here for the last couple of quarters. So there's a number of headwinds that we have category-wise that
column304: to this point in time
column305: we've been able to mitigate fairly well
column306: even with the pullback on some of the promotional things that we're doing for the business. So people are curious as to the timing of things. Coming out of Q2
column307: we felt really good about where we were. Our plans were working
column308: we felt comfortable with where we were through the guidance phase of the last quarter's call. And really
column309: this transaction trend went south on us late September and really heavily into October. So we're taking a really close look at that both from an internal view on what did we do that could have changed the guest perception or shopping patterns
column310: or was it more macro kinds of things that have kind of stacked on top of each other here over time. So again
column311: we're deep into the investigation process on all of those things
column312: and you can -- rest assured
column313: we're working hard to try to find the answer.\nEvren Dogan Kopelman: Great. That makes sense. The other question is your younger stores typically comp stronger than your older ones as the younger ones mature. Have you seen any changes to that historical trend? Or can we expect that to continue?\nScott M. Settersten: No. The comp stack for the third quarter is pretty similar to what we had back in the first quarter so you can remember back
column314: we did a 6.7% all-in comp in the first quarter. We're doing a 6.80% or so. By and large
column315: the stores look the same. Still the stores from 0 to 5 years
column316: that comp ramp looks exactly the same as what's reflected in our model. When you get beyond year 5
column317: years 6 through 15 is roughly in the -- it's in the solid low-single digit range. And then when you get beyond the 15-year range
column318: it's more or less a net 0. So consistent with what we would expect at this kind of comp level. So again
column319: we feel -- we're pleased with the 2013 slate of new stores and no change in the ramps.\nOperator: The next question is from Ike Boruchow with Sterne Agee.\nIrwin Bernard Boruchow: I guess my question is the last time we heard from you
column320: you were guiding a 5% to 7% comp for both Q3 and the year
column321: which I think essentially implied a 5% to 7% comp for Q4. So to guide it now a 7% to 9% comp for Q4 with sales that are so far below the Street is just a little confusing. So I guess can you just help us understand the Q4 top line outlook and how does that compare to your view of what the Q4 sales number was going to be 3 months ago?\nScott M. Settersten: Yes. We tried to give you a realistic view of the business. Again
column322: I mentioned in my prepared comments that there's 200 basis points in that 7% to 9%
column323: Ike
column324: that's really just a basic measurement
column325: the arithmetic measure versus last year. So it's not really reflective of the core of the business. The core business is still operating at a 5% to 7%.\nIrwin Bernard Boruchow: But when we think about the outlook for Q4 coming down
column326: is that a function -- I mean
column327: you said more promotional environment. So obviously
column328: margins lower than you had planned. But are the sales -- the total sales dollars
column329: are those also -- where you're putting them now
column330: are they lower than where you thought 3 months ago? Or is that not -- is that somewhat unchanged?\nScott M. Settersten: They are somewhat lower. I mean
column331: we did see a dropoff in retail sales late in the third quarter
column332: which we mentioned here
column333: driven by transaction deceleration. So we have taken down our internal view of what we expect retail sales to be in the fourth quarter. So yes
column334: that has been taken down somewhat.\nOperator: The next question is from Daniel Hofkin of William Blair.\nDaniel Hofkin: Just to follow up on that question
column335: I guess still not completely clear. Like
column336: where -- if you have -- I totally get that last year's comparison was affected by Sandy. That ought to benefit your comp growth and your total sales growth
column337: it would seem
column338: this year. So we're just trying to understand what appears to be
column339: and again
column340: maybe it's just the calendar shift that you described
column341: but what appears to be a mismatch between the comp that you're projecting and the total sales growth
column342: which has a much smaller spread relative to the comp than we're used to seeing. That's the first question.\nScott M. Settersten: Dan
column343: I don't think I really have anything more to share on that one other than the 200 -- we're calling it 200 basis points roughly of the year-over-year comparison. And we have taken down our retail estimates
column344: our retail comp estimates for the fourth quarter that are really -- really
column345: it's the competitive environment and the conservative view that we're taking on the fourth quarter and what the margin rate investment is going to be to maintain those sales levels.\nDaniel Hofkin: So are you implying that you're expecting a moderation in new store performance or
column346: let's say
column347: non-comp store performance in the balance of the year that's maybe more significant?\nScott M. Settersten: No. I don't think so. I mean
column348: our stores are continuing to perform at the levels that we expect them to. We may not see an overperformance kind of environment
column349: like maybe that you've seen in the past or have been reflected in models just through the delivering of actual results. Historically
column350: stores have -- our new store program has way overdelivered what our initial expectations were. So naturally
column351: in an environment where comps are a bit more challenged
column352: there's going to be some kind of headwinds on those new stores. I mean
column353: they're not immune to what's going on with the macro consumer environment. So that might be a bit [indiscernible] if you're looking at it from a modeling perspective.\nOperator: The next question is from Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.\nMatthew J. Fassler: First question I would ask
column354: you talked about severance and some changes that you're making in supply chain and HR. Could you give us any more details on the changes that you made there?\nMary N. Dillon: Yes
column355: sure. That was related to 2 changes at the executive team level in terms of the HR and the supply chain functions and just my judgment about capabilities that we needed there for the future. So we've got a great strong team here
column356: we made a couple of changes and we're moving forward.\nMatthew J. Fassler: So
column357: Mary
column358: did you replace the senior executives in those roles with internal people at this stage?\nMary N. Dillon: One was internal and one was external.\nMatthew J. Fassler: Okay. My second question relates to the real estate plans. So this year
column359: obviously
column360: you were in the -- you're going to end up in the low to mid-20s. You were pretty close to that last year. And I guess in '11 and prior to that
column361: I guess you had peaked at 15%
column362: but that was sort of coming out of a downturn. So I guess as I combine the move to 15% next year with your discussion of developing urban and smaller store prototypes
column363: what's your sense of the blue sky footprint potential for the existing format as you have it? And would you say that's changed at all from perhaps what you guys have talked about prior to the time you came to the company?\nScott M. Settersten: No
column364: Matt. Our view is on the 1
column365: 200-store potential for our 10
column366: 000 square foot box. Nothing's changed with respect to any of that. Again
column367: what we're faced with here in the near term
column368: we think
column369: is just -- it's whatever
column370: a pendulum swing that will come and it will go
column371: and consumer and category itself will bounce back here. Again
column372: over the long term
column373: we feel really good about our model and about the category overall. As we look at next year
column374: it's really a balance. I think we've said before that 125 stores this year was kind on the outer reaches of what we felt like we could do comfortably
column375: both supporting it with operating disciplines and training and all the other things we have to do with our new store associates. As we look to next year
column376: we want to do a few more remodels
column377: so that's kind of -- again
column378: those are more or less like a new store
column379: so that kind adds in -- gets you to your total buildout. And then there's a few more things internally that we want to do
column380: kind of in-store projects with planogram changes in the mass area and a few other things we want to do. So all in all
column381: we feel really comfortable with where we are
column382: and it's more of a balanced approach next year.\nMatthew J. Fassler: Got it. And one last quick one. So if you think about the promotional environment
column383: I guess
column384: last year in the fourth quarter
column385: the gross margin had a bit of a setback. It almost seems like there are other seasonal entrants into the business or some of your competitors choose to turn up the juice at this time of year. It seems to be a recurring pattern. Is it the year-round players who you find aggravating the competitive backdrop? Or are there more seasonal players
column386: be it general merchants or others
column387: who tend to refocus on this around holiday
column388: who seem to be gumming up the works a bit from a margin perspective?\nScott M. Settersten: Well
column389: one thing I do want to point out is that in the fourth quarter
column390: even though we're guiding gross profits flat year-over-year
column391: we are expecting merchandise margin to expand by roughly 50 basis points. So our plan of trying to balance the promotional environment here whilst continuing to drive a great value orientation for our customer is still in place. What we've seen here develop recently -- again
column392: everybody sees this in the news
column393: right? Our mailboxes are full every night
column394: our e-mail accounts are full. We see the fashion and soft good guys out there with 50% off the whole store on the first week in a holiday. I mean
column395: that -- nobody really expected that. I mean
column396: we knew it was going to be competitive
column397: but we didn't know it was going to be to this extent. So looking at it again objectively
column399: we said we need to compete here to maintain our gains. But when I think back -- and this is one of the benefits
column401: for being around for a while
column403: analogizing back to really -- the last time we saw discussions about inventory levels with these soft good players and the need to get through this stuff before the end of the holiday season was back in 2008
column404: and that was a tough environment for everyone. And we'll take the same view this year as we did then
column405: a balanced view between investing margin and chasing the comp number. So we'll be very mindful of that.\nMary N. Dillon: Yes. I just want to add one thing
column406: which is that up until a recent shift in trend
column407: these tweaks to our promotional strategy were encouraging to us. So in no way
column408: shape or form did we step back from that as a longer-term way for us to continue to drive top line and bottom line
column409: because we know we're getting smarter
column410: we can test and learn. And yet
column412: we can respond to it. But we're going to continue to drive that over the long haul.\nOperator: The next question is from David Wu of Telsey Advisory Group.\nDavid Wu: First
column413: in terms of next year's square footage guidance of 15% growth
column414: which obviously -- that's at the low end of your long-term target range of 15% to 20%
column415: and I understand that you're planning to do more remodels next year. But can you talk about whether -- or why you're not opening up more stores next year and if you're perhaps seeing any real estate limitations out there
column416: and if you're still sort of sticking to your long-term 15% to 20% square footage growth target range?\nMary N. Dillon: Well
column417: let me just start by saying that 125 stores this year
column419: is probably about the peak in terms of really just executing with excellence. Every time we open up new stores
column420: we do a great job identifying real estate and constructing those stores. We also have to hire folks and staff them and train them and have them ready for our guests. So we feel good about that number and really believe that
column422: is really just a way for next year to make sure that we're striking that right balance. We're not concerned about our ability to find the right real estate and to build those stores
column423: and we're not concerned about the productivity of our store model. We just think this is a better pace for us right now.\nDavid Wu: Great. And can you talk more about your strategy for the brand boutiques
column424: including your initial plans for next year and what the longer-term opportunity could be?\nMary N. Dillon: Well
column426: we are really thrilled with the fact that our assortment continues to evolve. Our team here has done a great job partnering with really great vendors and iconic brands
column427: and that's been part of the magic of Ulta
column428: frankly. And it's great. So as I said in my prepared comments
column429: we've gone to 100 Clinique store boutiques and 105 Lancme boutiques this year
column430: which is great. Benefit boutique doing exceptionally well
column431: and we're going to continue to build out that strategy. So I can't tell you specifics today
column433: that's high on our hit list of things to continue to build on.\nDavid Wu: Great. In terms of the higher promotions
column434: are you expecting this to impact your non-prestige business? Or are you becoming more promotional also on the prestige side?\nScott M. Settersten: No. By and large
column436: when we talk about promotions and discounting
column437: that is non-prestige kind of business. So prestige product
column440: there is no discounting allowed. It's an SRP out the door.\nDavid Wu: Got it. So in terms of then the slower traffic and sales that you saw towards the tail end of September and into October
column441: did that mainly impact then sort of the non-prestige side? Or did you also see a little bit of a pullback on prestige as well?\nScott M. Settersten: No. The promotions itself
column444: prestige becomes part of the mix with some of the offers that we give our guests. But by and large
column446:
it was non-prestige-related categories.
David Wu: Where you saw the pullback?
Scott M. Settersten: Yes.
Operator: The next question is from Mark Altschwager of Robert W. Baird.
Mark R. Altschwager: I wanted to touch a bit more on the supply chain side. Mary
column447: I was hoping you could talk about your long-term vision there. You made some changes
column448: so what is your assessment of the supply chain today? And where does it need to go in order to support the type of growth that Ulta is capable of?\nMary N. Dillon: Sure. Well
column449: I -- we'll just answer that really at a macro level. But our supply chain today
column451: is performing very well for us
column452: yet we know that we need to do more
column454: we're a growing business. So we need more infrastructure to support our multi-year growth plans. We also know that we need to continually increase our ability to compete in an omni-channel way. So we're thrilled with our e-commerce performance
column455: but we want to make sure that we have the capability at a minimum to be able to have our guests
column457: understand if they can order online and pick up in our stores. Whether or not we ship from stores is a different question
column458: but we're really looking at the range of capabilities. And as I'm sure you imagine
column459: that's not the -- you need to have the right systems in place to allow that kind of capability. And we also know that we have opportunities just in end-to-end efficiency in our supply chain. So we've taken some time to really build a robust view of that. We're -- the first stage of that is really building a new distribution center in 2015
column460: which we're planning. But beyond that
column461: there's also plans to invest in the right systems and in people and capability and capacity to support our long-term growth ambitions. We plan to get to 1
column462: 200 stores and continue to be a very high-growth retailer
column463: so we need a supply chain that supports that.\nMark R. Altschwager: Okay. And then on the services side
column464: where do you see the biggest opportunities? And how do you think about allocating the space in the store? And then as the environment gets more competitive
column465: how do services fit with the long-term vision of building brand awareness and customer engagement?\nMary N. Dillon: Right. I think it's a perfect example of -- we sit back and think about our 10-year view of Ulta and how we want to really differentiate Ulta. That's exactly the kind of question we're asking ourselves. Ultimately
column466: we really have a differentiated proposition today because of the one-stop shop ability
column467: the exciting assortment that we offer
column468: but also the fact that you can get services in our stores
column469: which I don't think anybody can get online yet and hopefully never. But anyway -- so we've got a really differentiated concept that we believe is going to really be the place that allows us to win for the long term. So we're going to examine what we think about trends
column471: anti-aging -- an example might be skin health
column472: right? So there's ways that we can think about. Is there more we can do there? But that's just one example. But we'll put all those under the
column474: sort of the examination lens here as we think about places that we'll continue to invest to grow. So -- but for sure
column475: services will continue to be part of our long-term proposition.\nOperator: The next question is from Kayla Berg of Piper Jaffray.\nKayla Berg: First
column477: could you share your thoughts about approaching holiday from a digital marketing perspective versus last year? And also
column478: how do you guys feel positioned for holiday in fragrances here across the price points and newness?\nMary N. Dillon: Okay. Can I ask you guys to take those for us? Janet and Jeff
column479: you want to take the marketing? We have our team here.\nJeffrey Severts: Sure. Well
column481: I would say that our digital marketing efforts will be pretty consistent with what you've seen from us for the balance of the year. So as we've talked through the first couple of quarters of the year
column482: we're a lot more focused on the digital space than we have been traditionally
column483: and you're just going to see that continue. Not going to give you much more detail than that because I'm sure the competition would love to hear it.\nJanet Taake: And in fragrance -- this is Janet. Basically
column484: we have our exclusive gift with purchase that we started in November and continue through holiday
column485: and that is exclusive to Ulta and something we have done for many
column486: many years. And we're very excited. We've improved the quality of both of those. One has already been in the stores
column487: and the second one hit this week actually. But we're also encouraged by some of the newness that we have seen at the end of third quarter. Just to comment on One Direction
column488: out of the box was very strong
column489: along with Honey from Mark Jacobs and a few other things. So gift sets are strong. And also
column490: I think that we feel very good about some of the opening price points in purse sprays or roller balls
column491: if you will. So from a fragrance perspective
column492: we're ready for holiday.\nKayla Berg: Okay. And one last quick follow-up. Where do you guys expect to end the year in terms of inventory levels?\nScott M. Settersten: We expect to end the year in line -- similar to where we ended the third quarter. So it'll be well below what the comp increase is for the year. We feel very
column493: very comfortable with our inventory position. Again
column495: there's very little in the way of fashion risk in our inventory
column496: so very low obsolescence risk. So again
column497: very comfortable we're on plan and expecting to hit our targets at the end of the year.\nOperator: The next question is from Krystyna Metcalf of Oppenheimer.\nKrystyna Metcalf: Most of my questions have already been asked
column498:
but I was just wondering if salon comps were still above product comps this quarter?
Scott M. Settersten: They were indeed. They were -- they added roughly...
Mary N. Dillon: 10 basis points.
Scott M. Settersten: 10 basis points to the comp for the quarter. So still performing very strong.
Krystyna Metcalf: Great. And then I'm not sure if you answered this already
column500: you said that you were expecting e-commerce sales to go down just because of the new website rollout? And obviously
column502: they were pretty similar. So what are your expectations for 4Q?\nMary N. Dillon: Well
column503: yes. We were very happy with that transition
column504: and we were being cautious about that. So that's better than we expected. The first 3 quarters still
column506: were benefiting from some pretty high-ticket products that we were selling that were hot products and -- I mean
column507: supplements and some tools. We're excited about our continued growth
column508: but the comps do get tougher going forward. So we're going to continue to grow. I'm not sure if we're citing a specific number
column509: but it's -- we're going to continue to have tough comps
column510: but we also feel more optimistic with the transition going better than it did
column511: I might add.\nScott M. Settersten: And I would add
column512: we picked up steam at the end of 2012 with our e-commerce site. They had a really good fourth quarter
column513:
so I wouldn't expect the 70% growth for the fourth quarter year-over-year.
Operator: We have time for one more question from Jill Nelson of Johnson Rice.
Jill R. Caruthers: A quick one on fourth quarter gross margin. You did mention that merchandise margins are planned up. Could you talk about maybe the pressures in that line item you're expecting?
Scott M. Settersten: On the gross profit line?
Jill R. Caruthers: Yes
column516: it'd be flat.\nScott M. Settersten: Right. So we are happily expecting to see merchandise margin expansion with product mix and the prestige mix being richer as part of the overall business. We do have headwinds with fixed store cost. That's really the primary offset there
column517: Jill. So it's really the accelerated new store program
column518: especially with 125 new stores now kind of entering into the chain here late in the third quarter. So that's the headwind that's offsetting the merchandise margin gains.\nJill R. Caruthers: Okay. And then kind of big-picture question into 2014. Clearly
column519: you need to put in more investments into the business. And could you maybe just talk about some of the big buckets? You've mentioned supply chain
column520: but maybe if you could put them in order? Or just some type of magnitude of where you feel like the company has underinvested and what needs to help grow the business for -- into next year?\nScott M. Settersten: Yes. I wouldn't use the term underinvested
column522: there is -- I think we've talked to many of you
column524: over the last year. Right? I mean
column526: there's always things we'd like invest in
column527: but you need to have the proper team in place and the proper third parties to help coach you along in some of these more complicated kinds of things. So I would just remind everyone
column528: the biggest investment we're making is in the new store program. So big acceleration in 2012 and into 2013. And even next year
column531: do the arithmetic. That's no small feat for us. And that's still -- the best investment produces the best shareholder returns that we currently have. So in the current term though
column532: that creates some headwinds for us on fixed store cost. Again
column533: we don't get the leverage with all those stores going in place that we have in recent years
column534: so that hurts us a bit. Some of the investments are more certain things. Mary talked about supply chain. We're going to get a lot of new capabilities there
column535: which are going to be very helpful for us down the road. There's things in IT. Again
column536: they're primarily customer-facing kinds of investments. So in-store POS systems that will allow us to do more mobile and all that kind of flashy iPad stuff
column537: which everyone does now and we need to invest in as well. That's what the guests expects. There's other investments like brand awareness
column539: training for store associates to make sure we give the right guest experience in places like skin category
column540: which is high touch and high impact. So those things -- those are one of the things that we're talking about as part of the strategic planning process and how far do we need to go and to what extent do we need to do those kinds of things. So -- and then there are other things I'd call kind of compliance costs
column542: but will be a drag on earnings next year around health care. So some of that stuff is starting to kick in now. And I can tell you
column544: it's more expensive than anybody really thought initially. So that's kind of the short bucket list for what we're looking at for 2014.\nOperator: That is all the time we have for questions. I'd like to turn the floor back over to Ms. Dillon for any closing remarks.\nMary N. Dillon: In closing
column545: I'd like to thank all of our Ulta Beauty associates who worked very hard to deliver solid results in a tough environment in the third quarter. I'm very proud of the team for driving strong store sales while delivering on elements of our longer-term initiatives to position the company for success over the long haul. While we're acknowledging some of the challenges we're facing in the near term
column546: I know the long-term opportunities for Ulta still make it one of the most exciting growth stories in all of retail. Thank you for your interest in Ulta Beauty
column547: and I look forward to speaking with you soon.\nOperator: Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen
column548: this does conclude today's teleconference. You may disconnect your lines at this time
column549: and thank you for your participation.

column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: and welcome to the Under Armour
column4: Inc. Fourth Quarter Earnings Webcast and Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder

column304: what would this mean for us?\"" We looked at 3 basic criteria when we decided

column309: so absolutely not. We want to be agnostic

So those will be things that -- the 3-year planning process is rolling into its second year right now. You should start to see some benefit of that as we probably start working towards the back half of this year but even more so in 2015. We did talk about some system changes we've done on the supply planning side last year

column515: our commercialization team to build a better zipper. And no more the zippers

column518: when you're wearing a big pair of gloves

For the first quarter of 2014 we expect system-wide RevPAR to increase between 4.5% and 6.5% on a comparable currency neutral basis. In the U.S. and UK we expect the weather we have experienced so far this year to marginally affect Q1 RevPAR growth. However this should be somewhat offset by the lapping of the beginning of the U.S. government sequester during the first quarter of 2013. We expect adjusted EBITDA for the quarter of between $480 million and $500
column224: which include a one-time benefit of approximately $25 million from the reversals and the accrual related to the conversion of our prior cash based long-term incentive compensation plan into a restricted stock plan for our Vice Presidents and below. That benefit will reverse itself by year-end in the form of share based compensation expense. Further detail on our fourth quarter and full year guidance can be found in the earnings release we distributed earlier this morning. This concludes our prepared remarks and we're now interested in answering any questions you may have. Matthew

roughly that should be available for debt reduction in the year.

There's no question that full service and luxury we still have pretty good momentum in China

column329: not because we didn't know how to do it but because our debt structure really didnt allow us. So our attitude right now is other than as I say some very minor sales

column346: but with goals of being investment grade and we think we can achieve that over the next two to three years. We finished the year at 5.2 times net debt to EBITDA. column36: I'll start by providing some context around the board's decision to make the leadership changes that we announced earlier today
column37: and then I'll turn the call over to Joe White to discuss our results for the quarter. In light of the company's disappointing financial performance and after careful consideration and analysis
column38: the board determined that a change in leadership was necessary in order to drive profitability through operational improvements and other initiatives. The board believes that now is the right time to bring in new leadership to capitalize on Molina's incredibly strong franchise and the opportunities we see for sustained growth going forward. To be clear
column39: these changes represent targeted and deliberate actions to enhance the company's focus and improve our competitive position within the industry. We're pleased to have someone with Joe's experience
column40: institutional and industry knowledge capable of serving as our Interim President and CEO at this time. Joe has over 25 years of financial management experience in the healthcare industry
column41: and served as Molina's Chief Accounting Officer since 2003. He has led the company's most recent operational improvement initiatives and is a widely respected leader both within the company and in the greater healthcare industry. Separately
column42: I'm honored to have the opportunity to serve as Molina's Chairman and lend my experience to help guide the company forward. The board remains sharply focused on ensuring an orderly leadership transition and is commencing a search process for Molina's permanent CEO. In the meantime
column43: we're grateful to have Joe at the helm. I would be remiss if I did not say the board appreciates Dr. Mario and John Molina's leadership and contributions for more than two decades
column44: and looks forward to their continuing insights as directors. I want to assure you Molina's business remains strong. The company has an outstanding brand and franchise built over three decades
column45: based on a focused commitment to mission. The board is committed to continuing this mission

column48: 000 employees and our over 4 million members. We believe we can capitalize on Molina's strengths to build significant shareholder value. Now

column52: we reported net income per diluted share of $1.37 and adjusted net income per diluted share of $1.47 for the first quarter of 2017. This compares to net income per diluted share of $0.43 and adjusted net income per diluted share of $0.51 for the same period last year. First quarter results includes a $75 million pre-tax benefit from the receipt of our Aetna-Humana break-up fee. This break-up fee added $0.84 per share to both net income per diluted share and adjusted net income per diluted share for the quarter. Today's results which are consistent with our expectations represent a notable step forward for the company. Now
column53: I want to speak to some of the line item details in the financial statement. Premium revenue increased over 15% in the first quarter of 2017 compared to the first quarter of 2016
column54: while membership increased nearly 13% during the same period. We added more than 500
column55: 000 new members in the first quarter

column57: we think that
column58: as of today
column59: both the operational and the financial performance of our Marketplace product is better than what we saw in 2016. Of course

column61: we can expect our Marketplace enrollment to decline during the remainder of the year. Our medical care ratio in the first quarter of this year was 88.4% compared to 89.8% in the first quarter of 2016. This 140 basis point decline in the medical care ratio was a result of higher percentage margins in our Marketplace and Medicare products. Our consolidated medical margin measured in total dollars increased by more than 30% to $537 million this quarter when compared to the same period last year. Our general and administrative expense ratio increased to 8.9% for the quarter
column62: a 110 basis point increase from the prior year. But as we outlined during our Investor Day presentation back in February
column63: these results are in line with our expectations for the full year. As a reminder
column64: we do not provide quarterly guidance. As we've said on past calls
column65: we adjust guidance only when we believe that there is a material change to the business from what we have previously communicated. As we announced in today's press release

column67: while also updating that guidance to reflect the break-up fee associated with the Aetna and Humana acquisitions as these were not included in our original outlook. column68: please note that our outlook does not include an estimate for severance charges associated with today's announcement. Looking beyond 2017

column2: everyone
column3: and welcome to The Kroger Companys First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. All participants will be in a listen-only mode. [Operator Instructions] After todays presentation

column7: please go ahead.\nKate Ward: Thanks
column8: Jamie. Good morning and thank you for joining us. Before we begin
column9: I want to remind you that todays discussion will include forward-looking statements. We want to caution you that such statements are predictions
column10: and actual events or results can differ materially. A detailed discussion of the many factors that we believe may have a material effect on our business on an ongoing basis is contained in our SEC filings
column11: but Kroger assumes no obligation to update that information. Both our first quarter press release and our prepared remarks from this conference call will be available on our website at ir.kroger.com. After our prepared remarks
column12: we look forward to taking your questions. In order to cover a broad range of topics from as many of you as we can
column13: we ask that you please limit yourself to one question
column14: and one follow-up question
column15: if necessary. Thank you. I will now turn the call over to Krogers Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
column16: Rodney McMullen.\nRodney McMullen: Thank you
column17: Kate. Good morning
column18: everyone
column19: and thank you for joining us. With me to review Krogers first quarter 2017 results is Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
column20: Mike Schlotman. As we all know
column21: there is a lot of change in the food retail industry  both in terms of the operating environment and competitive landscape. The best thing that we can do is to stay on the offense by continuing to focus on our customers  what they want and need today and what we anticipate they will want and need tomorrow  and executing our strategy. We continue to manage our business for the long-term and to deliver earnings growth on a three-year to five-year time horizon. We are making meaningful investments in our digital and online growth. We believe that customers of the future will want to shop with us for anything
column22: anytime
column23: and anywhere. In the first quarter
column24: we saw more than 30% growth in new digital customers and a more than 30% increase in digital visits  with faster growth in mobile compared to last year. We are also building on our personalization expertise to benefit our customers. An example of this is My Magazine
column25: which delivers personalized content like recipes to loyal households based on their shopping behavior and interests. In fact
column26: we delivered more than 6 million unique My Magazine offers in the first quarter alone. This also allows us to offer personalized lower prices to our loyal households in addition to the low prices everyone can see. This is another example of how we leverage 84.51s expertise. We are investing in our people. We are improving customer service by both increasing labor hours in certain areas and increasing starting wages in certain markets. Taken together
column27: these steps will improve the customer experience and improve retention. I share these examples to demonstrate that we are laser-focused on providing our customers with the right value proposition. This is our Customer 1st Promise - our commitment to provide friendly service
column28: fresh foods
column29: and low prices
column30: every day. And this is what we will continue to do
column31: regardless of the external factors
column32: because its what our customers deserve and what we know ultimately that delivers shareholder value. These investments both maintain and enhance our position in our markets. And while it is still early in 2017
column33: we are starting to see some traction. We are happy with the better identical sales trend in the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter
column34: and we are pleased to see that our current identical sales trend is positive. The last nine weeks of the first quarter were positive
column35: and so is our second quarter to date. Our teams continue to innovate in new and exciting ways that reflect where our customers are going. Recognizing the demand for convenience
column36: high quality
column37: and best value
column38: Krogers Culinary Development Team launched an incredible collection of Prep+Pared meal kits that we are currently piloting in Cincinnati stores. We can hardly keep them on the shelves! And it's easy to see why as soon as you try them. Krogers Prep+Pared meal kits offer restaurant-quality meals that are easy to cook in about 20 minutes. We think customers will love knowing they are available in stores when they are wondering along about 2 o'clock in the afternoon whats for dinner. Our Brands are one of the primary means we have to differentiate ourselves from our competitors. Last year
column39: we commissioned an independent third-party to conduct research that would give us an objective view of how our customers view Our Brands. This included blind taste tests with national brands and other private label foods. Our research showed that the most-loved brands sold in our stores are Our Brands above even the national brands! And in the blind taste tests
column40: Our Brands outperformed competitive national brand and other private label products almost 100% of the time. Our products in Private Selection and Simple Truth and Simple Truth Organic brands rated significantly above their respective competitive offerings. Of course
column41: our journey is never done so our customers will continue to see rising quality and better value on Our Brand products in the future. By having brands our customers love that are only available from us
column42: we gain loyalty and advocacy from our customers. Our Brands represented approximately 28% of total units sold
column43: and 25.6% of sales dollars
column44: excluding fuel and pharmacy
column45: during the first quarter. Our customers needs are constantly changing. What doesnt change is their desire for a welcoming customer experience with an abundant variety of food
column46: available when and how they want it
column47: all at a great value. Thats why we regularly evolve the execution of our Customer 1st Strategy
column48: while the core strategy itself doesnt change. Too often
column49: American consumers have to make a choice between low prices and a great experience
column50: compromising one for the other. Kroger is uniquely situated to eliminate the need for that compromise; serving customers who are hungry for more than food
column51: who want to be nourished in ways that help them live their lives best. Krogers purpose is to Feed the Human Spirit and we are more confident than ever that by living our purpose and delivering our Customer 1st Promise
column52: well deliver long-term shareholder value that you can count on. We remain committed to delivering our long-term net earnings per diluted share growth rate of 8% to 11%
column53: plus a growing dividend. And here is Mike to go into more detail on our first quarter results. Mike?\nMichael Schlotman: Thanks
column54: Rodney
column55: and good morning
column56: everyone. Like Rodney said
column57: we were glad to see the better results compared to the fourth quarter for identical food store sales and for the second quarter-to-date
column58: our ID sales are positive. Tonnage continued to be positive during the first quarter. We continue to focus on the areas of highest growth like natural and organic products as well as areas where we are saving customers time
column59: such as ready-to-eat and ready-to-heat meal solutions. Visits per household were flat in the first quarter. Basket size and price per unit were down
column60: but those were offset by household growth. Loyal households grew 3.2% compared to last years first quarter and our loyal households had positive ID sales growth in the first quarter. In the first quarter
column61: our gross margin was down
column62: operating costs were up
column63: and FIFO operating profit was down. While this is not representative of our typical expectations
column64: it is important to keep in mind that we are making very deliberate and targeted investments in line with our Customer 1st Strategy. As Rodney outlined earlier weve made conscious decisions to increase starting wages in certain markets to improve associate engagement and retention that will create a better experience for our customers. We continued to invest and grow our digital business. Our digital revenue more than doubled in the first quarter compared to last year. This includes revenue from ClickList
column65: Harris Teeters ExpressLane and Vitacost.com. As we continued to invest in price
column66: we also remind you
column67: Krogers investment in price can be seen very clearly if you look at our gross margins in the early 2000s compare to today. Kroger has invested more than $3.8 billion to lower prices for our customers over that time period. We have no intention of giving up the momentum weve gained on low prices. These investments enable us to connect with our customers in a deeper way and increase our market share over time. We are pleased that Krogers market share
column68: as traditionally calculated
column69: was up in the first quarter. That said
column70: we recognize there is no perfect metric for capturing market share. We are doing a lot of work to better define or perhaps redefine the market as share of stomach rather than share among traditional grocery stores. We see food as a massive
column71: $1.5 trillion market
column72: and we have a substantial growth opportunity in that market. I also want to stress that we are committed to lowering costs as a rate of sales. Many of the things we are doing to pull costs out of the business today set us up for savings in the future. We will only further intensify our process improvement efforts. Now for an update on retail fuel. In the first quarter
column73: our cents per gallon fuel margin was approximately $0.171 compared to $0.143 in the same quarter last year. The average retail price of fuel was $2.28 versus $1.92 in the same quarter last year. Our net total debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio increased to 2.33 times compare to 2.12 during the same period last year. This result is due to the merger with ModernHEALTH and the repurchase of shares. Over the last four quarters
column74: Kroger has used free cash flow to repurchase $1.5 billion in common shares
column75: pay $438 million in dividends
column76: invest $3.4 billion in capital
column77: and merge with ModernHEALTH for approximately $390 million. The flexibility to return value to shareholders is a core strength of our financial strategy. We are committed to balancing the use of cash to maintain our current investment grade rating. Return on invested capital for the first quarter
column78: on a rolling four quarter basis
column79: was 12.75%. On the labor relations front
column80: we are currently negotiating agreements with UFCW for store associates in Atlanta
column81: Dallas and our Food 4 Less Warehouse Stores in Southern California. Our objective in every negotiation is to find a fair and reasonable balance between competitive costs and compensation packages that provide solid wages
column82: good quality
column83: affordable health care
column84: and retirement benefits for our associates. Krogers financial results continue to be pressured by rising health care and pension costs
column85: which some of our competitors do not face. Kroger continues to communicate with our local unions
column86: which represent many of our associates
column87: the importance of growing Krogers business and profitability
column88: which will help us create more jobs and career opportunities
column89: and enhance job security
column90: for our associates. Turning now to our guidance for fiscal 2017. We had previously indicated that the environment during the first half of this year would be similar to the back half of 2016
column91: and that is what were seeing. As Rodney said
column92: there is a lot of change in the retail food industry. That
column93: coupled with the transition from deflation to inflation creates a challenging operating environment. The deflationary environment was less severe in the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter
column94: coming in at 20 basis points deflationary without fuel. Grocery was essentially flat during the quarter but had fluctuations up and down during it. Meat continued its deflationary trends. And produce
column95: while deflationary for the quarter
column96: showed inflation in the last four weeks of the first quarter and pharmacy was inflationary. As a result we increased our expectations for LIFO to $80 million; a $55 million increase over our initial expectations. We have also made some incremental investments in price in certain markets that had very hot features on milk and eggs. While this affects gross margin in the short-term
column97: it is less expensive than regaining a customers loyalty. These two
column98: plus the incremental investments in hours and wages
column99: are the primary factors causing us to lower our guidance for the year. Our GAAP net earnings per diluted share guidance for 53 weeks is now $1.74 to $1.79. Our adjusted net earnings guidance range is $2 to $2.05. The previous adjusted net earnings guidance range was $2.21 to $2.25. See Form 8-K we filed this morning for additional information on guidance. Because this is an unusual year
column100: we are going to provide a quarterly cadence relative to last year rather than compared to our long-term guidance rate
column101: as weve done in the past. For net earnings per diluted share
column102: we expect the second quarter to be down compared to last year
column103: the third quarter to be up slightly compared to last year
column104: and the fourth quarter to be flat
column105: excluding the 53rd week. We continue to expect identical supermarket sales
column106: excluding fuel
column107: of flat to 1% growth for 2017. And we continue to expect capital investments excluding mergers
column108: acquisitions and purchases of leased facilities
column109: to be in the $3.2 billion to $3.5 billion range for 2017. Over the long term
column110: we remain committed to achieving net earnings per diluted share growth rate of 8% to 11%
column111: plus a growing dividend. Now

We spend a lot of time taking where we are today

We do feel good about the traction we are getting in ID sales that we think will help us support that ID guidance range. Relative to the operating cost reductions
column173: I think  I don't have any concern that we arent going to continue to get the operating cost reductions we're getting. We have made an independent decision to add some service hours to some departments as well as in some markets increase starting wages to try to reduce the turnover we have
column174: which hurts the customer experience as well as creates its own cost in friction when you are constantly hiring training people. We didnt do that across the country. It's in select markets
column175: but it's not an inexpensive proposition. So we try to factor all of those in. In fact

column177: Karen to  and Mike and I both mentioned that our identical sales continue to improve and we would expect that trend to continue. If you look at quarter-to-date and realize it's only three weeks plus a few days
column178: we would be higher than the midpoint of the range that we gave for the year and thats continued to improve over the first quarter and the first quarter was an improvement over the fourth quarter and it improved during the quarter. And then Mikes point on expenses
column179: there were some items where it's more of a one-time type of expense item. If you look at some of the changes in the logistics and some other places

column185: third and fourth?\nRodney McMullen: I would say we saw some in this quarter and what we have saved in the quarter and the run rate we have for the year is right in line with what our original expectation in our business plan is. There were other  as I said that the hours and the dollars investment in starting wages were something that was incremental to the plan

You gave us the basis point impact. But is there a way to think about the magnitude of the pricing change in that segment that you're seeing? Quantify that. I'm sorry.\nJohn H. Hammergren: Yeah
column285: I think James talked a little bit about the reduction in our expectations and how that split with a larger portion really coming from the price pressure we feel. And so that gives you a sense for the magnitude. And clearly

column287:
you should really get a sense directionally for the size of the challenge.

Lisa C. Gill: Thanks very much. John
column288: just looking at the industry

What are you seeing in that other 15% to 20%? Is that having a direct correlation on what you're seeing as far as the reduction in earnings as well?\nJohn H. Hammergren: Right. There really are two factors
column290: and I'll have James talk a little bit about the manufacturers in a minute. Because that obviously

column292: we do have some variability that resides in that part of our business. Clearly
column293: the manufacturers that play a very important role for us
column294: and we're constantly working with the manufacturers to make sure that we've identified the value that we deliver and that we're properly reimbursed for that value and we plan to continue to do so. On the customer side
column295: it's not unimportant I think to point out that we do have a nice and profitable relationship with customers on the generic portion of our business. And albeit we may not make much or any on the brand side
column296: the profit stream we get from generic participation as we've talked about before when we were picking up the Rite Aid generic business or the Target generic business. That generic business is a source of profitability
column297: and there is obviously flexibility in how we price those generics. And there's a market for generics. And we have to be responsive to how the market pricing plays for generics. James
column298: maybe you can talk a little bit about the manufacturer side.\nJames A. Beer: Yeah. In terms of when we came into the year
column299: we were assuming that the level of brand manufacturer or pricing inflation would be modestly below what we had seen in the previous fiscal year. And today
column300: we've updated that tight commentary to now being meaningfully below what we saw last year. To try to perhaps put a little bit more quantification around that
column301: I would say that the delta
column302: if you will
column303: between the rate of inflation that we expected and the one that we have seen thus far year-to-date is greater than a third reduction versus our original expectations. The other thing I would comment on in terms of the brand income
column304: why this inflation rate is important is that there is both a fixed component and a variable component of the income that we receive from branded manufacturers. Now
column305: a year or more ago
column306: we were talking about that being a roughly 80%
column307: 20% type split in terms of the fixed component of the equation versus the variable component. In part
column308: the contracts have evolved. But also in part as inflation rates have come down in the last few months
column309: I peg that split more at 90%
column310: 10%. 90% of our income is fixed
column311: 10% is variable. But obviously
column312: that 10 points is still being able to have a meaningful impact on the financials that we've been talking about today.\nLisa C. Gill: James
column313: can you help us understand what the actual rate of inflation was last year
column314: when you say you expected it to be down
column315: but now it's meaningfully down? Is there a number you can put around that?\nJames A. Beer: I wouldn't throw out a specific number
column316: but that's why I articulate
column317: the decline that we have seen in the inflation rate is greater than a third of the original expectation for the year. So it's a significant decline.\nLisa C. Gill: Okay. Great. Thank you.\nJohn H. Hammergren: I think
column318: Lisa
column319: also
column320: when we look at what we come up with from a calculation perspective on branded inflation
column321: it's plus or minus what you'll see from published sources of inflation. But it is also important to point out that those averages sometimes don't necessarily tell the whole story
column322: because of the mix
column323: or the relationship
column324:
or the individual products that are going up or going down in the portfolios can be materially different. And so I do think the economics aren't always necessarily driven with the direct correlation to the average price increases that everybody talks about.

Operator: Our next question comes from Robert Jones with Goldman Sachs.
Robert P. Jones: Thanks for the questions. Yeah
column367: John
column368: I guess like others I'm surprised to hear you highlight competitive pricing
column369: just given how rational the industry has been for so long. And I guess if I take a step back
column370: this year alone
column371: we've seen the negative impact to profitability from generic pricing
column372: moderating. Now
column373: we're talking about a slowdown in branded inflation. Is there any thought that those dynamics themselves are what are forcing your competitors to maybe go harder after market share to make up for what seemingly would have created a shortfall in profit? And then
column374: I guess more importantly
column375: how sustained do you think this competitive behavior could be? Do you think this is more of a one-off
column376: a few accounts that they went after harder
column377: or do you think this could potentially be a more lasting changing dynamic?\nJohn H. Hammergren: I think those are all good questions. I think that the best way for me to answer them would be the way we think at McKesson. I can't speak to how our competitors make their decisions or how they make their pricing calls in the industry. I can tell you that McKesson is focused on retaining our customer base and creating additional value for our customers as I talked about before
column378: and charging a fair price. And on that fair price idea
column379: there is plenty of headroom in terms of the value we deliver to the industry that we don't charge for. And as I've seen in the past when  we have faced pressures like this
column380: where there's been a reduction in product launches or other things happen
column381: with some of the profit pools become more difficult. What typically we would attempt to do is reduce the level of incremental discounts that we pass on to our customers when we're in those discussions. But clearly
column382: that conversation isn't successful if there are alternatives that are providing something that is even more significant. My best hope is that we demonstrate to our customers that they're going to always get a fair price from us
column383: and in return
column384: they're going to get superior service and tremendous focus on their success. And that's where we plan to stay. And I know at McKesson
column385: at least
column386: we think growing market share through a price-oriented approach ultimately will not be successful
column387: because customers don't want a change. Our customers
column388: when they get a better deal
column389: come to us and say
column390: hey
column391: listen
column392:
can you match this deal because I'd like to stay with you. And so that customer pressure to remain with us because they like us always provides McKesson an advantage when we're in these discussions.
Robert P. Jones: Understood. I'll leave it there. Thank you.
John H. Hammergren: Yeah.
Operator: Our next question comes from Charles Rhyee with Cowen & Co.
Charles Rhyee: Yeah. Hey. Thanks for taking the question. Just curious
column393: James or John
column394: when we think about the reduction in guidance for the year
column395: can you give us a split
column397: between how much you think is coming from the customer side
column398: versus how much is from the brand inflation side? Is it half and half or...?\nJames A. Beer: Yeah. So a couple of points. In terms of the negative effects
column399: I would say it's the competitive pricing having a greater impact than the brand manufacturer price inflation rate. But also
column400: remember that we offered $1.60 to $1.90 range for those two items. We're bringing the overall company range down by less than that because we've got tailwinds in our view around our tax rate
column402: around our interest expense and so forth. So that's going to drive the delta between the two ranges that we're offering today.\nCharles Rhyee: And then to just follow up on the brand inflation side. Obviously
column403: I think most people coming in would have thought
column405: the elections are a factor driving this. How are you guys thinking about it as we move into next year post-elections? Obviously
column406: a lot of spotlight on Congress right now on this topic. How are you at this point thinking about  do you think it bounces back
column407: or do you think this is maybe the new normal and we have to wait for the anniversary? Any thoughts there would be helpful. Thanks.\nJohn H. Hammergren: Well
column408: I think the view we have is sort of a year-to-date view. We have the same information that you have and probably the same visibility. And we're just guessing as to what manufacturers are likely to do going forward like everybody else. They control their pricing decisions
column409: and we don't have much visibility into anything
column410: other than their historic behavior. And their historic behavior
column412: has been rising over the last several years. And if you go back before the more recent years
column413: there's always been a level of  at least in our data
column414: always been a level of inflation that has occurred. And you do hear some manufacturers talking today about having a policy around how much inflation they think they should be able to provide to the industry over time. Some of them are making those statements more publicly than others. And clearly
column415: there might be some near-term changes in their behavior that will be different over the longer haul. We do think that innovation requires profitability. We think the lack of new product launches in the face of generic conversions causes pressure to branded manufacturers and that they ought to have the ability to raise price appropriately on branded drugs to help fund their R\u0026D requirements and their profitability requirements. And so I think that a common person's view would be that you'd still see inflation at some levels. I think that the outer bounds of inflation that had been experienced in the past by our industry
column416: that we've had conversations about in the past
column417: are probably likely to not exist anymore. So I just think those heavy outliers on both brand and generic
column419: which obviously will have an effect. But
column421: it's probably a little bit early to speculate. And I think as we get through the rest of this year
column422: we've given you some assumptions about directionally where we think it's going to be the balance of this year. As we get into the next fiscal year
column423: we'll give you a sense for where we think it's going to be.\nCharles Rhyee: Thanks. Is it possible to renegotiate these contracts on the fly
column424: or is it you have to wait as the terms come up? And I'll stop there. Thanks.\nJohn H. Hammergren: Well
column425: I think anything is possible. We typically have renegotiated the contracts when they come up as opposed to whenever we're under significant pressure. I think that we always have the opportunity to go back to manufacturers and demonstrate once again the value that we deliver. And in particular
column426: where manufacturer's behavior has changed dramatically from its previous behavior and we had come to depend on those mechanisms as part of our funding source with that manufacturer
column427: I think we have every right to go back to those manufacturers and say
column429: we need to open the dialog again because by your unilateral decision
column430:
you have significantly impacted our profitability on your particular product lines and we don't think that's fair and we want to recover that lost margin. So I think that that certainly is something we plan to pursue.
Charles Rhyee: Thank you.

Or could there be potentially more downside if in the second half of your fiscal year brand inflation decelerates even more?\nJohn H. Hammergren: James
column438: why don't you...\nJames A. Beer: Yeah. Ricky
column439: to answer your question very directly
column440:
what we've assumed for the back half of fiscal 2017 is a continuation of the inflation rate that we have experienced year-to-date.
Ricky R. Goldwasser: Okay. So basically the same type of price increases that we've seen year-to-date to continue for the next couple of quarters.
James A. Beer: Yes.
Ricky R. Goldwasser: Okay. And then when we think about the sell side pressure that you're talking about
column441: is that a number that we can take and annualize into next year? And I think my point being is that
column443: it's a (57:26) and when we think about the margin implication. Is it fair to assume that you just repriced that portion of the contracts that are perennial for this year
column444: or have you also gone proactively to your customers and locked in contracts that are going to come up in the next year or two at a new pricing level?\nJohn H. Hammergren: Well
column447: both good questions. I think to the point that James is making when he answered it a moment ago
column448: we typically see stronger price inflation as you get into our third and fourth quarters. And so when we say we're guiding on a year-to-date basis
column449: that already tells you that we believe there'll be some moderation in those quarters relative to previous behaviors. On the sell side
column450: it's a little bit more difficult to make projections because we're basically in a position where we are reacting to some extent and not being the people that are making the decision. I think that our view is that we have made a very significant change in our pricing practice to match where the market is today. And we
column451: like I said to answer another question that was asked
column452: we have seen this kind of event happen in the past as well and we didn't see a continuation of the event. And our objective is to continue to maintain our market share. So I think we believe we provided guidance that has reasonable expectations from that perspective and that you can count on the range. That's one of the reasons that the range is somewhat wider
column454: is it's somewhat dependent on what happens going forward.\nRicky R. Goldwasser: So I think that one of the things that we are all trying to get a better sense of is when we think about fiscal year 2018 and I fully understand that you're not guiding to 2018 and there are a lot of moving parts
column455: but is it reasonable for us to take that $1.60 to $1.90 in EPS impact that we're going to see in the second half of the year and just use it as a run rate for fiscal year 2018 just for these two components?\nJames A. Beer: Well
column458: it's really I don't think it's appropriate for us to try to make any predictions about FY 2018. So I think really we should leave that for closer to the start of that fiscal year. And we'll

column461: right? So if you're seeing the step-down in your sell side margin
column462: traffic to the EPS impact is going to just slow through...\nJames A. Beer: Yeah. No
column463:
I...

column464: I think it's a difficult question to answer. But I think  I did try to at least bound the conversation around customer pricing
