column29: President and Chief Executive Officer of Enphase Energy. Badri?\nBadri Kothandaraman -: Good afternoon and thanks you for joining us today to discuss our third quarter 2017 financial results. So
column30: we had a good quarter. Our 30
column32: 10 transformation is going very well. We were almost breakeven in non-GAAP operating income during the third quarter and we have stabilized our cash position. We reported revenue of $77 million for the third quarter of 2017
column33: an increase of 3% compared to the second quarter of 2017. We shipped approximately 231 megawatts or 790
column34: 000 microinverters. Our GAAP gross margin was 21.4% and non-GAAP gross margin was 21.8%. Our focus on operational excellence resulted in gross margin expansion
column35: lower OpEx and overall improvement to our financial position in the third quarter. We're laser focused on further gross margin improvement through supply chain optimization
column36: new product introduction and pricing management and are on track to reach our 30
column38: 10 target operating model by the fourth quarter of 2018. Bert will go into greater detail about our financial results later in the call. So
column39: turning to our market. The third quarter revenue in the U.S. was up 2% sequentially. We completed the transition to IQ 6 product for our U.S. and Latin American customers during the quarter and nearly all fourth quarter inverter shipments to these regions will be the IQ 6 products. Shipments for AC module product also increased sequentially. In the Latin American market
column40: the third quarter revenue was down 9% sequentially as a result of the devastating hurricane in Puerto Rico at the end of the quarter
column41: which impacted overall shipments to the region. We look forward to playing a key role in the future as the island rebuilds and diversifies its electrical infrastructure. Raghu
column42: our Chief Product Officer will provide details later in the call on a key technology that will be central to this effort. In the APAC region
column43: the revenue increased 35% sequentially as the demand for our products continued to grow. We established new partnerships with distributors
column44: installers and module manufacturers in India during the quarter resulting in our first shipments to the region. In Europe
column45: revenue was up 3% sequentially and 114% year-over-year. The third quarter was a record quarter for unit shipments and revenue in the region as we continue to grow our customer base. Moving on to products
column46: we believe the IQ 6 microinverter system and our AC modules will help drive profitable growth with new and existing partners
column47: thus increasing our share of market. We remain focused on operational blocking and tackling to achieve this goal. With the introduction of what IQ 7 product in the first quarter of 2018
column48: we expect to grow revenue by increasing out served available market. IQ 7 will be a single world-wide product skew that allows us to penetrate new markets in Europe
column49: Asia Pacific and Latin America
column50: while also helping to drive gross margin expansion. In summary
column51: we are pleased with our overall progress during the past three months. My top priorities over the next six months are to improve cash flow
column52: further expand gross margin with the introduction of IQ 7 worldwide and achieve sustained profitability
column53: creating a solid financial foundation. We will also continue to provide customers with the value
column54: quality and customer service theyve come to expect from Enphase. With that
column55: I would like to turn the call over to Raghu
column56: our Chief Product Officer to provide an expanded update on our products.\nRaghu Belur: Thanks
column57: Badri. As part of our commitment to deliver increased value to our customers
column58: we transitioned over the past few quarters from our M-series to our IQ series product. IQ is an integrated solar
column59: storage and energy management platform that enables self-consumption and delivers our core value proposition of yielding more energy
column60: simplifying design and installation and improving system availability uptime and reliability. In addition
column61: IQ provides advanced grid functions that are capable of meeting worldwide regulatory requirements. IQ also enables our AC module product further simplifying the installation process
column62: reducing installation time and streamlining logistics. IQ 6 delivers more power and higher efficiency
column63: while further reducing the balance of system cost due to its simplified wiring
column64: reduced size and weight. Much of IQ 6 performance was achieved by silicon integration with our new ASIC. With IQ 7 we will yet again offer greater power and a smaller
column65: lighter and easier to install product. What is unique about our IQ 7 is that it's a single worldwide skew
column66: achieved as a result of our software defined architecture. Similar to IQ 6
column67: we have developed a new ASIC for IQ 7 that enables greater semiconductor integration. Solar plus storage
column68: which includes our AC battery product is central to our product strategy. Our storage business continues to expand worldwide because of the unique features of our AC battery solution. We believe the storage market will continue to improve over the next 12 months as cost come down and as utilities better understand how to incorporate distributed storage on to the grid. Now let me talk about our next generation IQ 8 product expected to be introduced in 2019 based on our always on technology called Ensemble. One of solar's biggest challenges is that it is grid tied. What this means is that if the grid fails and the sun is still shining
column69: there will be no production out of your solar system. Most customers are unaware of this limitation with today's solar technology. So
column70: to address this limitation we have invented a microinverter technology that is completely grid agnostic. This means that even if the grid fails and there is sufficient sunlight
column71: the Enphase system will continue to produce energy and meet the demands of the home or business. The Enphase microinverter system's capabilities further enhanced when the Ensemble technology is incorporated into our AC battery storage solution. With IQ 8 you can have a system that will continuously produce energy
column72: regardless of the presence or absence of the grid that is storage during the day -- sorry
column73: solar during the day and storage at night. That is what we mean by always on and it can address challenges like those experienced in Puerto Rico
column74: other island nations and countries with weak grids. We also believe IQ 8 will grow our total addressable market worldwide. For example
column75: there are over 1.2 billion people with limited or no access to energy in regions such as India and Africa. IQ 8 is uniquely positioned to address the energy challenges inherent in these and other regions of the world. We'll continue to update you on IQ 8's progress over the coming quarters. Now I'll turn the call over to Bert for his review of our financial results.\nBert Garcia: Thanks Raghu. I'll provide more details related to our third quarter 2017 financial results as well as our business outlook for the fourth quarter. As a reminder
column76: the financial measures that I am going to provide are on a non-GAAP unless otherwise noted. Total revenue for the third quarter of 2017 was $77 million
column77: an increase of 3% sequentially. Total net revenue per DC watt was unchanged from the prior quarter
column78: reflecting relatively stable ASP's. On a year-over-year basis

column273: we take the next best alternative
column274: which is offered by our competition and then we think about what value does offer compared to the product next best alternative. For example
column275: in ECM it is installation time saving
column276: it is streamlined logistics
column277: it is improved quality
column278: it is enhanced power production. Then we say here is the value you ascribe to that and we tell the customers that look we'll share some of that value with you. So

column280: which means it's literally hundreds of lines item every quarter and in some cases the customers doesnt see the value
column281: then we go and look at what we should do on that case

Higher growth rates and lower rated export steam negatively impacted RPU despite improved pricing in our export markets. column553: so we can better serve our customers. So

column557: it's...\nPatrick Tyler Brown: Yeah.\nAlan H. Shaw: It's an ongoing process

column564: it's innovative service products that utilize and generate a return on our existing assets. Our balanced and successful approach focused on increasing efficiency and delivering a strong customer service product gives us confidence in our ability to achieve our goals and deliver sustainable value. Thank you.\nOperator: Thank you. This concludes today's teleconference. You may disconnect your lines at this time. Thank you for your participation."

column23: and our ability to effectively navigate this highly dynamic environment resulted in exceptional top and bottom line growth. For the quarter

column26: entertainment and marketing expenses across our segments. Earnings per share increased an outstanding 89%.\nJohn Sznewajs: Thank you

column33: John. Our markets remain strong and housing fundamentals are supportive of continued long-term growth. column114: we'll be  we'll temper that investment to ensure that it aligns with the growth that we're  that we expect to see.\nJohn Lovallo: Understood
column115: okay. And then maybe just on the raw mats freight headwind. I think you guys talked about mid-single-digit range for the full year and high single digits in 3Q and 4Q. Can you just help kind of parse out the difference between the freight inflation versus the actual raw mat inflation?\nJohn Sznewajs: So\nKeith Allman: Maybe I will start John and you can get into some of the specifics. In terms of  while we don't normally see this kind of significant commodity changes occurring this quickly
column116: we certainly are no strangers to commodity changes. And this is really part of our business of our business. And we've consistently communicated
column117: John
column118: and more importantly
column119: I think
column120: demonstrated our ability to reach price/cost neutrality through cycles. And this is included garden-variety sort of changes in costs related to the relationship between supply and demand. It's included force majeure kind of spikes in cost and as well as tariffs
column121: which was quite a spike that we were able to cover. So our price/cost neutrality capability is really underpinned by this consistent investment that we've had in our brands and innovation and customer programs and the like
column122: as well as our well-developed ability to drive total cost productivity and to ultimately deliver value to our customers and consumers that they recognize. So we're going to continue with this commitment
column123: and we will reach price/cost neutrality as we exit this year. Now in terms of specifics
column124: John
column125: maybe you want to hit a little bit on some of the commodities and the relative spikes that we're seeing?\nJohn Sznewajs: Yes
column126: sure. So John
column127: as you referenced
column128: we're seeing both inflation in our raw material baskets
column129: really across the enterprise as well as transportation and logistics. And if you think about this  how we're being impacted
column130: obviously
column131: copper
column132: zinc and the resins that go into paint and packaging have been up pretty significantly. As you  to get to your question specifically
column133: as you break apart the impacts on the financial statements from either raw materials or transportation and logistics
column134: the vast majority of impact comes from the raw material basket. If you think about distribution and logistics
column135: it's a relatively small part of our overall cost structure. That said  and I guess I can repeat your statement. We do continue to expect inflation to be up kind of mid-single digits for the full year in both segments and up high single digits in the second half of the year. And as Keith alluded to
column136: we've secured price increases across our product categories. We do have plans for further price increases to offset the persistent inflation that we've been experiencing. That said
column137: we're not going to shy away. We're going to continue to implement cost productivity improvements across the enterprise as well and then work with both our customers and suppliers to continue to try to offset this inflation. So as we said earlier in response to Stephen's question
column138: we do expect to be price/cost neutral as we exit 2021.\nJohn Lovallo: Okay
column139: thank you guys.\nOperator: Your next question will come from Michael Rehaut from J.P. Morgan. Your line is open.\nMichael Rehaut: Thanks. Good morning everyone. Thanks for taking my questions. I just wanted to make sure we're thinking about the  and I'm sorry to beat a dead horse here
column140: but I think it's top of mind with investors. And just trying to appreciate the timing differences around price/cost and make sure we're thinking about it right. Are you basically saying  because earlier
column141: you said
column142: okay
column143: the higher volume  from the margin side
column144: you have higher volumes that are offset by higher inflation? Are we to take that as kind of net inflation
column145: net of your incrementally expected cost increase  I'm sorry
column146: price increases? In other words
column147: it seems like in a perfect world
column148: if you had higher inflation
column149: but you're putting through price increases to offset that
column150: that should be a wash. So are we going to take this that there's this continued lag in price/cost that you're still  maybe chasing is the wrong word? And then potentially
column151: to the extent that you get a fuller benefit of the price increases in 2022
column152: that in and of itself
column153: to the extent that the inflation backdrop remains stable
column154: that could actually turn into an incremental tailwind as you fully catch up to the inflation? Is that a right way to think about it?\nJohn Sznewajs: Yes
column155: Mike
column156: I think you're thinking about it the right way.\nMichael Rehaut: All right
column157: perfect. And then just more on the overall top line environment. If you could kind of go into a little bit around point-of-sale and inventory levels

And is this something that you would expect to perhaps happen in the coming quarters to the extent that you're able to increase  continue to increase production?\nKeith Allman: Yes
column159: Michael
column160: the POS is strong. And as I mentioned
column161: it's strong through the quarter and exiting the quarter
column162: and we feel really good about the POS. And that's across really
column163: most
column164: if not all of our categories. With regards to the inventory position
column165: the supply chain has been tight. There's no question about it. We've had disruptions. And hats off
column166: frankly
column167: to our operation team and teams really across the world to be able to leverage our strengths and also our relationships to be  and to work around the clock to move production around and to match production to specific demand and those sorts of things. So they've done a phenomenal job. Having said that
column168: we're still working through some tightness. And I would say
column169: probably and think about it from a Q3 sort of perspective that we will catch up and then start to replenish the inventories because our inventories in the channel aren't where we'd like them to be. So yes
column170: I think upside to some inventory fill in the back half is the right way to think about it.\nMichael Rehaut: Okay
column171:
thank you.

Ken Zener: Good morning everybody.
Keith Allman: Good morning
column172: Ken.\nJohn Sznewajs: Good morning
column173: Ken.\nKen Zener: Wonder if we could talk about demand a little bit in the plumbing business relative to what you're seeing at retail versus the wholesale versus the new construction. If you could kind of parse that out

column178: of
column179: call it

column184: it really has been broad-based across all channels. Real good strength in e-commerce and continued strength in both plumbing wholesale as well as the retail

column191: it's nice and it's  to me
column192: you guys mentioned home prices
column193: which is really homeowners equity. It seems as though your sales are tracking with a very high rate of appreciation of homes.\nKeith Allman: Real strong correlation between home price and existing home sales
column194: no question about it.\nKen Zener: Right. And it seems to me that  could you maybe give us a little context
column195: Keith
column196: for  demand is high because prices are up. Assuming your guidance holds
column197: which is that you'll be cost-neutral by the end of the year

column200: do you usually give back costs? Otherwise
column201: it seems the higher volume growth perhaps lead to a margin adjustment as we look down the road higher.\nKeith Allman: Yes
column202: when you look longer-term through cycles of commodity increases and commodity decreases  and it varies depending on the nature of the cost. And we have inventory that needs to flow through before we get any sort of price change up or down to hit the P\u0026L. But fundamentally
column203: we've maintained and demonstrated neutrality as it relates to those fluctuations in raw material cost inputs and that neutrality comes from real solid total cost productivity improvements. It comes from us really watching our spend very closely. And of course
column204: price is part of that. Now
column205: in terms of the impact of how this could play out
column206: in future quarters or into next year
column207: it's a real volatile environment. What we're focused on is delivering on what we say we're going to deliver on and ensuring that we continue to drive on the exit of next year or this year rather to price cost neutrality and that's what we're committing to.\nKen Zener: Thank you.\nJohn Sznewajs: Ken
column208: one thing I would point out is
column209: given our international business

column211: over time
column212: that we're probably slightly price favorable in plumbing
column213:
just because HANSGROHE does a good job of going out annually with price increases.

Operator: Your next question will come from Keith Hughes from Truist. Your line is open.
Keith Hughes: Thank you. Question is on propane. I know it was weak in the quarter. If you could talk about what you think was going on and what's caused something in the quarter acceleration? And then any kind of April view on that would be helpful as well?
John Sznewajs: Yes. So Keith
column214: sorry about that

column225: second quarter
column226: third quarter

and we'll continue to update it that on our subsequent calls.

Phil Ng: Hey

column247:
and the structural cost alignments that we've talked about in past calls are bearing fruit and the team is doing a nice job.

Susan Maklari: Thank you. Good morning. My first question is

And how you're positioned there? And anything that you're taking to kind of increase your exposure to that channel and kind of drive those sales going forward?\nKeith Allman: Sure. We expect to continue to grow
column249: obviously
column250: as consumers become more and more comfortable with online purchases in our space. And we also continue to expect rather to continue to gain share. We believe that we're the leader in plumbing in the e-com market. And we've worked on a number of things to build and maintain that leadership
column251: Susan. Product offering
column252: obviously
column253: is one. We have put our best and brightest talent on this. We are working very hard across our business unit to leverage learnings quickly
column254: to leverage platform like product data management and IT space
column255: to leverage the sharing of ratings and reviews to really understand what it takes to be on that first page and to get that second and third click. We're working hard to understand how to drive digital content and 360-degree spends. We're doing a ton of stuff there. And also
column256: we're investing capital. We made an acquisition of one of the leading digitally-native brands in Kraus. And Kraus is a company that makes
column257: I would say
column258: more modern design sinks and faucets and the like. And we're learning a lot from them
column259: and we're helping them be all they can be as well. So a combination of capital deployment
column260: talent
column261: products
column262: IT
column263: leverage
column264: et cetera. This is important for us
column265: and it's paying off. And we've been working at this hard now for five years.\nSusan Maklari: Okay. Thats helpful color. My next question is
column266: when we think about the business
column267: you're obviously operating at margins that are ahead of those targets that you gave us at the Investor Day. Can you talk to just the longer-term sustainability of some of these trends that you're seeing? And how you think about the longer-term margin potential of the business?\nKeith Allman: Yes. We're really not changing our margin outlook for the long term. There's a lot of variability in these dynamic times. We think that our normal SG\u0026A spend of around 18% to 19% is where this business should be for maximizing value creation and continuing to invest in growth and our brands
column268: et cetera. So no change to our margin outlook at this point. But certainly
column269: we have demonstrated and will continue to demonstrate solid drop down on our incremental volume.\nJohn Sznewajs: Yes
column270: Susan
column271: and I would remind you that
column272: that our  the information that we gave out in our 2019 Investor Day had a lot of very different assumptions related to it. It was a very different environment. column273: too. I was talking about our margin guide this year.\nJohn Sznewajs: Yes. We  I think the way we think about it now
column274: Susan
column275: again
column276: we articulated this on our Q4 call is that
column277: continue to challenge our businesses to grow above market and continue to have our businesses expand margin every year. And again
column278: it's not hundreds of basis points of margin expansion
column279: but rather tens of basis points of margin expansion.\nSusan Maklari: Yes. Okay. John
column280: thank you. Thats helpful. Good luck.\nOperator: And your next question will come from Truman Patterson from Wolfe Research. Your line is open.\nTruman Patterson: Hi. Good morning

And we don't view the vaccine of the rollout as being necessarily a switch that is flipped as it relates from the work from home  relates to the work-from-home environment or the amount of time that people are spending in their homes. And clearly
column292: the millennial demographic and cohort has shown interest as we look at first time DIYers
column293: and we look at that cohort
column294: and we expect that to continue. So yes
column295: we have some tough comps coming up; no question about it
column296: but the demand remains strong.\nTruman Patterson: Okay. Okay. Thanks for that. And then also in the spa business

column298: so nice improvement there. But could you just discuss how the backlog  the order backlog is looking? And you all have mentioned supply chain constraints throughout Mexico. Could you just give us a time line when you somewhat expect that to be operating close or at full capacity?\nKeith Allman: Yes. We're getting better
column299: and we were starting to approach that capacity  that full capacity
column300: if you will
column301: as we were bringing in our Mexican labor force to a greater degree and getting more output from that. But then we had these issues around resin
column302: and there's tightness there. And we've missed some production on some selected units that require certain type of blended resins. But the demand there continues to be extremely robust
column303: and we have a very solid backlog. That has not changed. And as we get through this short-term blip here from the polar vortex in Texas and the resin tightness
column304:
this business will start to quickly approach stated production.
Truman Patterson: Alright. Thank you all and good luck on that quarter.
Keith Allman: Thank you.
Operator: The next question will come from Steven Ramsey from Thompson Research. Your line is open.
Steven Ramsey: Hi. Good morning. One quick follow-up on the spa business. In the full year guide
column305: do you have spas operating at full production and generating full margins for the year?\nKeith Allman: We're expecting strong double-digit growth for Watkins in 2021.\nSteven Ramsey: Okay. Great. And then thinking about price/cost and getting to neutral. I guess
column306: are surcharges a part of that? Is that being contemplated for pricing such as resins? And then for price/cost by product
column307: do you expect to be price/cost neutral on all products?\nKeith Allman: So we have a number of levers that we can and do pull to drive cost improvements and price/cost neutrality. We've used surcharges in the past
column308: and we're certainly contemplating in using some of those here as we sit today. In terms of saying that every product will be price/cost neutral

column311: and I won't say that. But when you look across our business
column312:
we will exit this year in price/cost neutrality.

Eric Bosshard: Good morning.
Keith Allman: Good morning
column313: Eric.\nEric Bosshard: Two things. First of all
column314: can you give us a little bit more insight? The deferred marketing spend
column315: I think
column316: $40 million you've talked about. What is that made up of? And also curious
column317: related to that or maybe a part of that is promotional investment on your part. And what you're seeing go on this year? What you're doing across your business

column319: Eric. So it's a big basket of things that go into marketing. Some of it is personnel. Some of it is investment in e-commerce that Keith referenced in response to an earlier question. So there's a variety of things that go into. And there's also some growth initiatives. To your point
column320: there's some promotional activity that goes into that bucket as well. So it's a big basket of things that go across the entire segment.\nEric Bosshard: Okay. And then just a follow-up. Your clarity on the propane path from here was helpful. On DIY

column322: and  which is great to hear. But in terms of the growth of the DIY business
column323: now that you're running against these tough comparisons
column324:
what should we be expecting in terms of the growth out of that business as we move forward?

Operator: And your final question for the day will be Mike Dahl
column325: RBC Capital Markets. Your line is open.\nMike Dahl: Hi. Thanks for squeezing me in. One more question on price productivity. I appreciate the sensitivity around the pricing side
column326: but anything around just qualitatively at a high level when you think about covering the cost. How much is price versus productivity? Is it a pretty balance? Is it steered more towards price? Just any color there. And the second part would be
column327: you've already talked about some of the ways you've continued to generate cost productivity
column328: but some costs are also eventually going through returns. So just  you've mentioned the levers that are left. Could you elaborate a little bit more on  you've obviously done a great job on productivity. Just where is the incremental productivity coming from?\nJohn Sznewajs: Sure. So Mike
column329: a couple of questions. As you think about the weighting of price versus productivity and offsetting inflation
column330: just given the nature of  and the rapid increase in the amount of inflation that we're seeing
column331: it's naturally going to be more price than productivity to offset that or to get to price/cost neutrality. In terms of our productivity measures
column332: I'll start and maybe kick it over to Keith to clarify. But our teams have done a great job over multiple years of driving productivity within our operations. And it's not just on the plant floor. It's also in the administrative part of the operations. And we challenge our teams every year to get more efficient in a variety of ways. And so we do have TCP goals for every  total cost productivity goals for each of our businesses. Keith
column333: do you want to give some examples?\nKeith Allman: Yes. I think from a dollars and cents perspective
column334: the greatest productivity comes from volume leverage. And when you look at our consistent and steady and repeatable drop down
column335: say it's 30%-ish in incremental volume for Plumbing and maybe closer to 25% in the Deco segment. That conversion efficiency is very helpful to us. Obviously
column336: there's direct labor productivity. We have hired a lot of people. And as those people become more familiar with our systems and how to work
column337: that naturally drives productivity. We're consistently and constantly looking for material substitution and value engineering where we can take a four-part assembly and make it a two- part machine or injection molding
column338: that sort of thing. So it's really a combination of shop floor and labor productivity
column339: working with our suppliers and making sure that we have the most cost-effective way to meet customer requirements
column340: so we don't want to mess or miss any customer requirements. So it's really all part and parcel of the Masco operating system with a good dose of volume leverage.\nMike Dahl: Thats great. Very helpful. Ill leave it there. Thanks.\nDavid Chaika: That concludes today's call. We'd like to thank all you for joining us this morning and for your continued interest in Masco. As always
column341: please feel free to contact me at (313) 792-5500 if you have any further questions. Thank you.\nOperator: Thank you
column342: everyone for joining us today. This will conclude today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

column5: you may begin.\nEvan Goldstein: Thanks
column6: Josh. Hello everyone

column8: Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Our results press release

column13: President and Chief Revenue Officer; and Amy Weaver

column22: including our most recent report on Form 10-K. With that
column23: let me hand the call over to Marc.\nMarc Benioff: Okay. Thanks so much Evan and we're thrilled to be on the call with you today and this has been such a challenging time. Our hearts have been broken we've heard so many stories of pain and distress across the world and for us this is really this moment is actually quite humbling
column24: quite bittersweet. It reminds us that at Salesforce this is a great platform for change that we're really here to be a great example of stakeholder capitalism to really show how we're able to deliver a phenomenal return for our shareholders as well as for our stakeholders. And in many ways this quarter really is a victory for stakeholder capitalism. It has been not only about our core values
column25: but also about our core products. It is about showing how our Customer 360 has been a platform for change for so many of our customers and I'm going to talk about that briefly before I turn it over to Mark
column26: but also our company has been a platform for change for the communities that have needed us most. And I am thrilled to deliver such a great return to our shareholders and also to our stakeholders. And certainly when we look at this quarter with more than $5.15 billion revenue and our highest operating margin ever that was 20% or when we look at simple aspects of our operational excellence like the 63% increase in seven figure deals from a year ago
column27: well really indicates to us one thing which is that values really bring value. It reminds me of a story that we really started last quarter with AT\u0026T. Now AT\u0026T is an amazing company
column28: a leader in the communications industry and they have a tremendous visionary with Jeff McElfresh who is the CEO of AT\u0026T Wireless. And I'll tell you the thing that's interesting about AT\u0026T is they have a huge vision and that vision is that every single customer touch point
column29: whether it is at their stores
column30: whether it is their e-commerce
column31: their app
column32: whether it is getting a message from them
column33: well and each and single customer touch point
column34: they want to know you as a customer. They want to single source the truth. And that's a deal that we signed obviously in February and I was thrilled that this quarter we've deployed now hundreds of stores and the first 35

column1: IPGP~2021~2~239~3685~8/3/2021~-.16065584~-.16165827~-.17826094~-.17505072~-4.4608159~-3.573874~-3.7698658~-3.9482589~1~Operator: Good morning and welcome to the IPG Photonics Second Quarter 2021 Conference Call and Webcast. Today's call is being recorded and webcast. At this time
column2: I'd like to turn the call over to Eugene Fedotoff
column3: IPG's Director of Investor Relations for introductions. Please
column4: go ahead
column5: sir. \nEugene Fedotoff: Thank you
column6: Ken
column7: and good morning
column8: everyone. With us today is IPG Photonics' Executive Chairman; Dr. Valentin Gapontsev; Chief Executive Officer
column9: Dr. Eugene Scherbakov; and Senior Vice President and CFO
column10: Tim Mammen.\nValentin Gapontsev: Good morning
column11: everyone. We are pleased to report another good quarter for IPG. Our second quarter revenue was significantly above the same period of last year and increased from strong results in the prior quarter
column12: driven by improved macroeconomic conditions in most major geographies
column13: growth in emerging products as well as
column14: excellent execution by the IPG team. We saw higher end market demand for our core material processing product
column15: where our fiber lasers are replacing traditional tools and handheld welders and continue to pursue the opportunities in emerging markets. We remain focused on growing sales in applications that require innovative solutions
column16: our expertise in fiber laser technology and superior quality of product
column17: such as advanced applications
column18: electric vehicle battery production
column19: medical and microprocessing. Our technologies are transforming the way products are created
column20: enabling production of smaller and more complex devices
column21: improving the product we use every day and bringing advanced manufacturing capabilities to electric vehicle and renewable energy industries
column22: helping to address climate change and sustainability initiatives. Our investment in new products and the applications are paying dividends.\nEugene Scherbakov: Thank you
column23: Valentin
column24: and good morning
column25: everyone. During the quarter we demonstrated excellent progress in our core material processing market
column26: across all major geographies
column27: with accelerated growth in high power and ultra-high power lasers for cutting applications in the U.S. and Europe and strong growth in welding in China and Europe. We also delivered robust growth in emerging products and applications. Revenue from material processing applications increased 27% year-over-year and contributed 93% of total revenue in the quarter. Sales in welding application grew significantly in the last several quarters due to increased sales of our AMB adjusted motor beam lasers for general manufacturing purposes and electric vehicle battery welding applications. Battery manufacturers are facing challenges welding together different type of materials such kind of copper
column28: sulfur and aluminum. These materials are extremely same reflective and need to be welded with high precision and reliability. Each battery model requires hundreds of welds and our AMB lasers can address these challenges
column29: offering superior speed and weld quality or competence solution this broad range of beam tunability and spotless welding. We also saw strong demand in emerging and micro material processing applications such as solar cell manufacturing and 3D printing. Sales of our green pulsed lasers
column30: which are used to improve solar efficiency more than tripled compared to the prior year and becoming a more meaningful part of IPG's revenue. We are taking advantage of opportunity created by increased focus on sustainability globally and expect future solar cell manufacturing capacity to grow driving additional sales in our green lasers. We are also increasing the pulse energy of the green lasers to enable next-generation applications in solar
column31: drilling and copper welding for consumer electronics. Revenue from our other applications increased by 5% year-over-year. Medical sales showed a good growth both year-over-year and sequentially
column32: as a result of improved demand of our surgical lasers. Advanced application sales improved year-over-year
column33: while telecom revenue declined compared to the same period in the prior year.\nTim Mammen: Thank you
column34: Eugene and good morning everyone. Revenue in the second quarter was $372 million
column35: which increased 25% year-over-year and 8% sequentially. Revenue from materials processing applications increased 27% year-over-year and revenue from other applications increased 5%. Sales of high-power CW lasers increased 20% year-over-year and represented approximately 51% of total revenue. Sales of ultra-high power lasers at six kilowatts or greater represented 51% of total high-power CW laser sales and increased 15% compared to the prior year. Medium power laser sales increased 70% on growth in cutting welding 3D printing and semiconductor applications. QCW laser sales increased 13% year-over-year on higher demand from welding applications. Pulsed laser sales increased 45% year-over-year with strong growth in green pulsed laser used in solar cell manufacturing and higher sales of our infrared lasers for marking and cleaning applications as well as foil cutting applications in the electric vehicle batteries manufacturing process. System sales increased 19% year-over-year with improved sales for Genesis and ILT. Other product sales decreased 4% year-over-year. We estimate that supply chain constraints impacted our revenue by $7 million to $10 million in the quarter.\nOperator: Great. We will now be conducting a question-and-answer session.  Our first question today is coming from Jim Ricchiuti from Needham \u0026 Company. Your line is now live.\nJim Ricchiuti: Hi. Good morning. Tim
column36: I think I heard you say
column37: the impact that you saw from supply constraints in Q2
column38: I think you said around $7 million to $10 million. So
column39: is that -- just to be clear
column40: is that a direct impact to you
column41: or is that what you're seeing from some of your -- what you're seeing from some customers? It seems like a fairly modest number. That's why I'm asking?\nTim Mammen: Yes. It was a fairly modest number. I'd agree with that. It's a variety of things. It's both the impact internally on the ability to supply some products and also an impact from slightly lighter demand from some customers because they can't get components for some of their systems
column42: and therefore delaying shipments of their systems and then they don't want to take the lasers at the same timeframe they did it. And the other thing is that it is across most geographies. So it's not just in one specific location. China was impacted a bit
column43: but also North America and even Europe as well.\nJim Ricchiuti: Do you anticipate that being a little worse this quarter?\nTim Mammen: No. It's probably going to be at a similar level. So in Q3
column44: it's a combination of that as well as some of the softness in the China cutting market that are really impacting guidance. It's not that that is specifically driving the guidance number down more significantly.\nJim Ricchiuti: Got it. And just my follow-up question. Just with respect to North America
column45: you showed strong year-over-year growth. And clearly that's an easier comparison relative to the pandemic last year. But on a sequential basis
column46: I'm just curious the decline there 10% or so sequentially is there -- are you seeing any signs of the US North American market either slowing down or potentially being impacted by some of these external factors that we're hearing about?\nTim Mammen: No. Not specifically. I think with North America it was more the timing of revenue. We had a very strong start to the year in Q1. We still had some backlog. For example
column47: I think one of those 100-kilowatt lasers was recognized as revenue in the first quarter. So that was a bit of a benefit
column48: slightly slower quarter in Q2. I will say that overall North American backlog continues to be very strong. And the guidance number we have with -- I can't remember -- sequentially I think it will be basically flat but again continuing to show growth on a year-over-year basis. So the backlog in North America remains pretty robust even though Q2 performance was a little bit later.\nJim Ricchiuti: Thank you Eugene
column49: and thank you Tim.\nOperator: Thank you. Next question today is coming from Nik Todorov from Longbow Research. Your line is now live.\nNik Todorov: Yeah. Thank you. I want to double-click on the China demand particularly in cutting. If we go back a quarter ago
column50: I think you were talking about macro indicators showing signs of weakness
column51: but I think your data points were strong. We were talking about strong freight agreements that were tied usually to high demand for ultra-high power lasers. If I look at the high-power sales and breaking down between ultra-high power and the low six-kilowatt we can see that ultra-high power lasers grew very incrementally on a sequential basis. Also on a year-over-year basis while below six-kilowatt lasers grew I think 24% or 25% year-over-year and about 10%
column52: 15% sequentially. So that implies that China sales should have been strong. So I just want to double click and see the reasons if you can give us more around the softness in China cutting?\nTim Mammen: So China sales in the second quarter were strong both on a sequential and even on a year-over-year basis okay. The growth on a year-over-year basis was a bit lower than some other geographies
column53: but don't forget that China had recovered already a significant round of revenue in the second quarter of 2020. So the comparison there is a bit more difficult. I wouldn't say I was not concerned about performance in China in Q2. In fact

column55: is that I think a couple of companies even that have announced in the last couple of days have pointed out a weaker macro environment in China and even the government being concerned about a potential a bit more of a slowdown. Yes
column56: we highlighted that on some of the PMI data that had initially come out I think in April. So there is a bit of a concern that China is a bit weaker than expected. And that's clearly driving some of our expectations in addition to the supply chain constraints in the third quarter. So I mean bookings are good
column57: but we expect those orders to be delivered over a slightly longer time than necessarily would have been if the demand environment had remained resilient or stronger. It's still resilient and stronger.\nNik Todorov: Okay. If I can click on the supply chain dynamics
column58: I think we heard that there were some challenges with delivering chillers that were causing some lead times extension. Maybe can you give us what components are impacting your lead times and when do you expect those to get resolved? And what are you doing to address that? \nEugene Scherbakov: Yes. Earlier there was some -- there were some components

column62: and I think we will deliver in time not only chillers

And as you point out total European sales continue to perform pretty strongly. I'd have to look at which customer was the change between Q1 and Q2.\nEugene Scherbakov: And from other side Germany
column66: again

demonstrated very high amount of orders for ultra-high power lasers and it was keeping 22-kilowatt and more as a first time.
Nik Todorov: Got it. Okay. Sounds good there. Thank you and good luck.

Tim Mammen: Thank you.
Operator: Thank you. Next question today is coming from Tom Diffely from D.A. Davidson. Your line is now live.
Tom Diffely: Yes. Good morning. Maybe one more question on China. You talked in your prepared remarks and said that pricing pressure remained. I'm curious if that has moved up into the high power region you had most of the pricing pressures at still at the low power?
Tim Mammen: No. Pricing -- some of the competitors are introducing product at higher power levels and trying to get into that ultra-high power market. So 12-kilowatt lasers even. And certainly the only way they can compete is on pricing. So what we call the low end of the market not just on power
column68: but really on pricing is moving up into higher power levels and impacting or reducing pricing there. Our strategy though is really as we articulated to continue to deliver behind the value proposition of IPG's product and not get drawn into what -- it would be a terrific victory on pricing in terms of trying to compete at that low end of the market
column69: which is just -- it's not focused on any kind of reliability or quality of devices using. I think so far our strategy has borne out pretty well with fairly robust China sales
column70: but good profitability on those And we're pleased with the way that gross margin and even total operating margin has continued to track in the second quarter Tom.\nTom Diffely: Okay. Yes. A year or so ago you talked about using your strong cost structure to maybe get more aggressive in the marketplace. And it sounds like you've been a little bit more disciplined than over the last year than I thought you may have been after some of those comments. But have you used pricing at all from your side
column71: or is it just in response to what you're seeing from the competitors?\nTim Mammen: No. We've introduced some of the lower cost rack-mounted lasers that's enabled us to reduce the selling price of those and make them a bit more competitive
column72: whilst maintaining margins on that
column73: but we're not using pricing as our strategy within the China market. It really would be a bit of a terrific victory in terms of gaining significant amount of share
column74: but at a significantly lower average price per watt. And then having to draw even more resources to building product that would have a lower profitability on it
column75: so
column76: we're focused on the high end of the market. And also outside of cutting very strong growth in some of the welding applications for EV
column77: the foil cutting applications for EV. Even some mid-power laser growth for some of the additive applications in China. And then surprisingly some of the pulse lasers even at lower power levels for marking applications
column78: where the quality of our product is recognized have actually held up quite well. So
column79: there's a number of different areas we're focused on trying to drive that value at the highest level possible.\nTom Diffely: Okay. That sounds great. Just one final housekeeping question. What's in your category of emerging products right now?\nTim Mammen: Anything really introduced in the last three-plus years. So it includes things like high-power pulse lasers

column220: have the flexibility to modify the cadence of repurchases in response to market conditions. Turning now to our updated outlook for 2021. We are very pleased with our year-to-date results through Q3 and are encouraged by the strong trends we've experienced so far in the fourth quarter. However
column221: we recognize we still have several significant sales weeks left in the holiday season and the operating environment continues to be dynamic. Despite these uncertainties
column222: we have increased our financial expectations for the year. We now expect net sales for the year will be between $8.5 billion and $8.6 billion with comp sales growth forecasted in the 36% to 37% range. This guidance reflects our expectation that fourth quarter comp growth will be between 15% and 20%. For the year
column223: we plan to open approximately 44 net new stores and remodel or relocate 17 stores. We now expect operating margin rate for fiscal 2021 will be between 14.3% and 14.5% of sales. We continue to believe the largest driver of our operating margin expansion will come from gross margin
column224: driven by leverage of fixed costs
column225: less headwind from channel shift
column226: improving merchandise margin and leverage of salon costs. Based on higher top line growth
column227: we now expect to leverage SG\u0026A more than previously expected as compared to fiscal 2020. Based on these assumptions
column228: we now expect diluted earnings per share will be between $16.70 and $17.10 per share
column229: including the impact of approximately $850 million in share repurchases. We now expect to spend between $200 million and $225 million in CapEx in fiscal 2021

column231: remodels and merchandise fixtures

column234: I'd like to address a few follow-up questions we received from our October Analyst Day event. First
column235: our longer-term financial targets. In October
column236: we shared targets for revenue and earnings growth which we are confident we can deliver through fiscal 2024 based on the limited visibility we have in the dynamic operating environment. As a reminder
column237: we are targeting net sales growth between 5% and 7% and diluted earnings per share growth in the low double-digit range on a compound annual growth basis using fiscal 2019 as base through fiscal 2024. In addition
column238: we are targeting operating profit margins in the 13% to 14% range over the next three years. Our operating margin expectations reflect a balanced and disciplined approach to strategic investments that will support our long-term growth aspirations and deliver strong shareholder returns. Regarding the timing of investments related to Project SOAR
column239: our multiyear effort to upgrade our enterprise resource planning or ERP platform. We expect to invest $160 million to $180 million in capital over the next three years
column240: with most of the investment planned for fiscal 2022 and 2023. As a reminder
column241: in addition to providing us with more flexible and scalable operating environment
column242: this new platform will support future growth and innovation. We expect to begin to see operational benefits from this investment in fiscal 2023. Lastly
column243: we are still finalizing our budget for fiscal 2022 and plan to provide financial guidance in line with our regular cadence on our March earnings call. However
column244: we wanted to share some initial thoughts to consider as you update your financial models. Comp sales growth in fiscal 2021 is expected to be significantly stronger than we initially planned but we remain confident we can deliver comp sales growth in fiscal 2022 within our longer-term targeted range of 3% to 5%. While we expect fiscal 2021 operating margin will be modestly above our longer-term target
column245: we expect operating margin in fiscal 2022 will be within our longer-term targeted range of 13% to 14%
column246: reflecting a more normalized pace of top line growth and capital and operational investment. We continue to target EPS growth in fiscal 2022 despite the challenge of cycling this year's stimulus payments and reopening of the economy but acknowledge the earnings growth rate next year will likely be lower than our longer-term target. And now
