column320: thats where we think we would organically be panning out at least around now. We also gave some color on whats happening during the quarter. So we said we had a strong January. And then we started to notice a sharp decel in February
column321: which would be timed approximately with when stimulus checks started to be coming and being distributed last year at this time. And we think March has an even stronger comp to beat. So I am not clearly disaggregating it for you
column322: but there is a blend of help tailwind that is no longer here now and the fact that we are seeing reopening happen and that people  there is this pent-up demand to go out
column323: to dine out
column324: to travel. Were looking at the mobility indices
column325: and were seeing that
column326: that indeed is increasing at the inverse rate to e-commerce declining. And  but were very
column327: very pleased that were hanging on to all the gains that we had from a year ago.\nDeb Wasser: Josh
column328: do you want to add anything on that?\nJosh Silverman: Nothing to add.\nDeb Wasser: Okay
column329: awesome. From Kunal Madhukar from UBS. This one is for Josh. Can you talk about the TAM
column330: especially in terms of how much of your market opportunity is handmade?\nJosh Silverman: Yes. I mean if you go look at the latest Q
column331: we put a lot of data in there. We estimate it to be about $2 trillion. And if the pandemic has taught us anything
column332: its that the distinction between online and off-line is arbitrary. And what do I mean by that? When you talk to buyers on their shopping mission
column333: they dont say
column334: Im looking for the best online place to buy this or Im looking for the best off-line place to buy that. Most of them
column335: they are looking for a gift for their mother or a throw pillow for their living room
column336: and they are going to go to online and off-line places. And what were seeing is Etsy can compete effectively against both online and off-line. Thats really one market in the minds of buyers. When we look at the categories in which Etsy participates
column337: we sell a great many things. We dont sell consumer electronics. We dont sell groceries
column338: to name two big ones. We dont sell travel
column339: but we sell most other things that consumers buy. And we really have seen that over the past 2 years. When home and living spiked
column340: we were there for you. When gardening spiked
column341: we were there for you. When pet supplies spiked
column342: we were there for you. When gifts spiked
column343: we were there for you. Who knew that the bread-making products were available on Etsy? I didnt
column344: shame on me
column345: until bread-making became a big thing. And all of a sudden
column346: we see it. So
column347: the variety  the versatility of the Etsy marketplace is quite remarkable. And then our global opportunity
column348: we have been investing in some key core markets
column349: but we think most markets make sense for Etsy. And if you look at the absolute explosion in demand on the buyer and the seller side in the UK
column350: its a great testament to  weve been planting seeds in the UK for many years. And holy cow
column351: did they grow. Great
column352: big forest almost overnight and we think that kind of opportunity exists in many
column353: many countries all around the world. So when you add it up
column354: its a $2 trillion TAM. An analogy I might paint is in a very different category. But if you look at  at Airbnb
column355: for example
column356: they talk about the hospitality industry writ large as their TAM. And if Im on a business trip in Chicago
column357: and Im going to  I need a bed for 7 hours
column358: Im going to fly in and fly out
column359: I might go to a Marriott or a Hilton. I dont really care. I just want it to be kind of cheap and commodity. If Im taking my family and I want a special experience
column360: Airbnb is a great opportunity. And so they are looking for the special of hospitality. Were the special of e-commerce. And I think that opportunity is massive. And obviously
column361: retail at writ large is a very
column362: very big TAM to be playing in.\nDeb Wasser: Okay. Great. Thanks
column363: Josh. This one is from Lauren Schenk from Morgan Stanley
column364: and Ill start with Rachel on this one. Is there any additional color you can share on how youre thinking about full year EBITDA margin given all of the moving pieces such as our M\u0026A
column365: our fee increase and incremental investments?\nRachel Glaser: Lauren
column366: thank you for the question. Weve said so many times that we love our marketplace model
column367: and I think our profits are one of the differentiating things that make Etsy special
column368: too. So its a great question
column369: and I love to talk about it. Why do we love our marketplace model so much? First of all
column370: we have said that our cost base is highly variable. We dont have distribution centers. We dont have retail stores. We dont even have very much capital investment. And so because its variable
column371: we are able to pull those levers as we want
column372: leaning into marketing and hiring of people and investing in product development. When we can
column373: like you saw us do in March of 2020
column374: when we first saw the pandemic starting where a lot of companies decided to pull back on those things
column375: we leaned into it
column376: and it was to our benefit. So Ill start with that fact
column377: putting that out there that we have a highly cash-generative model with a very high flow-through of top line to our bottom line. Secondly
column378: we did announce a transaction fee increase. And like we did on another transaction fee increase that we did in 2018
column379: we plan to reinvest a considerable portion of that incremental revenue back into the marketplace because we want to directly have that benefit the seller. So a lot of that will go into marketing and customer support and product development like we did before. The lever we can pull the fastest is in marketing. And that allows us to be able to spend more and still achieve the ROI threshold that we set for ourselves. So we plan to invest that at about the rate of our current EBITDA margins
column380: which means EBITDA dollars are going to grow. But with more top line
column381: we might see EBITDA margins stay about the same as where they are now. I want to talk about the take rate for a minute to make sure that people get that right in their model. So
column382: I am going to put a pin in the take rate question. I also want to talk about our subsidiaries. They do contract our EBITDA margins I think we said by about 300 basis points. Its another thing to think about when you think about EBITDA for the full year. Further
column383: we have lots of room to scale. Our revenue per headcount is considerably higher than peer benchmark. So
column384: you can go check that in your research
column385: but we have checked it. And that means we have a lot of room to invest not only in things that drive top line growth
column386: but in our infrastructure
column387: things that keep our marketplace safe that help ensure our trusted brand and help our developers do what they do in a much more agile way. So
column388: we are continuing to invest in those things. So
column389: real quick on take rate
column390: when you think about take rate for 2021
column391: the full year take rate was an effective 17.3% approximately. But before you add directly the take rate impact to  the 1.5% take rate impact to that
column392: you have to think about what that 17.3% was on a pro forma basis because we didnt have the subs in for that whole year. And so the pro forma number is more like 17%. So
column393: you would add that 1.5%
column394: but only to Q2
column396: because thats when the new transaction fee comes into effect. And that gets you to something around 18.5% when you add those things in for  on a full year basis for our take rate. So
column397: those are the comments I will make about full year EBITDA. Maybe Josh has something to add.\nJosh Silverman: No. I think we mean this is 18.5% for Q2
column400: for those quarters. I am sorry if I...\nJosh Silverman: That was great.\nDeb Wasser: Okay. Perfect. Alright. Next one
column401: I will start with Josh on this one
column402: from Victoria James at D.A. Davidson. How
column404: have you been impacted by consumers returning to physical stores as suggested by some of your e-commerce peers such as Wayfair?\nJosh Silverman: Well
column405: just to pick home and living for just a second
column406: because it is an interesting one. We have said that
column407: that has been our largest category. We saw an explosion in home and living during the pandemic. We saw an explosion in almost everything during the pandemic
column408: but home and living more than even most
column409: and it is now our number one category. Its a very large category for us. Home and living is running roughly flat right now
column410: just barely above zero in terms of growth rate. And I think thats kind of amazing given that
column413: there was stimulus and there was lockdowns and you had no other  few other places  obviously
column415: but a few other places to go to shop. So
column416: the fact that we are growing over that and still keeping that spend
column417: I think is kind of remarkable. Also true that there has been a lot of nesting thats gone on for the past 2 years. And its fair to assume that people might have spruced up their current place about as much as they want to spruce it up. And when interest rates rise
column419: and that tends to be a headwind to home furnishings. And so I wont be surprised to see home furnishings as a category face headwinds as we move through this year
column420: and it is our largest category. But what we hear from buyers is they love Etsy
column421: and they love the experience they have had on Etsy. And it feels different
column422: and it feels compelling to them. So
column424: we are prepared to compete with offline. We are compared to compete with come who may. We do see that
column426: our  we think that the category mix on Etsy is a real strength of ours. So for example
column427: home furnishings right now is roughly flat. Weddings is growing in the mid-20s
column428: mid-20%. And its a great example of we sell lots of things and lots of categories. And some of them are going to be headwinds
column429: and some of them are going to be tailwinds. Now weddings is a much smaller category than home furnishings at the moment. But over time
column430: that can change. What we are hearing from consumers
column432: is general concern with their spending overall. Inflation is a concern with them. They dont  arent getting stimulus checks now. By the way
column433: people have to repay their student loans. There is $1 trillion of student loan debt out there that people havent had to pay for a while. There has been a lot of rent forgiveness thats probably ending. So
column434: there is a lot more demands for their wallet. And oh
column437: and they want to dine out. And as Rachel said
column439: so do all of us. So
column440: we wont be surprised to see more competition for consumer wallets generally where discretionary spend in retail and e-tail is going to have to fight a little harder against some other categories. But we are certainly compared to fight for the share of dollars that are going to discretionary retail and e-tail. We are ready
column441: willing and able to fight for our share of that.\nDeb Wasser: Okay. Great. This one is from Anna Andreeva
column442: Needham. Marketing continues to be reined in for the past two quarters
column443: if thats not affecting demand. With GMS beating plan again in Q4 of 21
column444: what drove the decision to pull back during Q4? And how do you think about marketing in Q1 and for the full year? I am not sure which one of you want to take that one.\nRachel Glaser: I think Josh was going to start
column445: so I am going to follow-up.\nDeb Wasser: Josh
column446: you go.\nJosh Silverman: Great. Thanks for the question. We have said through the years that we are very disciplined at looking at the marginal return on the next dollar spend in marketing. And we do that with performance marketing. We do that above the line. And we are constantly testing in each channel PLA
column447: social and whatnot. When we spend a little deeper
column448: what do we get for it
column450: what do we get for it. Its also worth noting that
column451: that changes over time. Consumer behavior is changing. The competitive landscape is changing. The market rates for CPMs and whatnot are changing. And so we are constantly testing that. And when we find that the marginal return on the next dollar has maybe evolved and isnt as good as we thought
column452: we can pull back and be more efficient. And we are always looking to be as efficient as we can with spend. What we saw in the fourth quarter is we had a lot of tailwinds. Things were going very well. And the marginal returns on some of our spend
column455: meaning the incrementality was lower. If we hadnt spent that dollar
column456: we still would have gotten the sale. So
column457: we pull back. And thats adjustment that we are always doing. Its also worth noting that when we raise our take rate
column459: the lifetime value of each interaction
column460: each buyer we bring in or the repeat purchase goes up. And that allows us to spend deeper. And we think thats a great thing for our seller community and for our marketplace as a whole.\nDeb Wasser: Great. Okay. This one is from Seth Sigman at Guggenheim. Habitual buyers increased 9% of buyers from 8% in 2020 and to 45% of GMV
column461: up from 40% in the prior year. So
column462: not only is Etsy converting more habitual buyers
column463: but these habitual buyers are also spending more. What are the learnings from these buyers that are applicable to the broader buyer base? Thats a great question for you
column464: Josh.\nJosh Silverman: I think the big lesson is that we have an opportunity to be a starting point for commerce. I think that this period of time has caused all of us to be aware of the role we play in this global supply chain where things are mass produced at huge quantity far away to go on a boat
column467: to end up at your household
column468: to have you look and be just the same as all of your neighbors and then end up in a landfill two seconds later. And I think we are seeing a rise of conscious consumerism where people really want to maybe buy fewer things
column469: but have those things mean more
column470: express themselves in their sense of style and taste
column471: differentiate from others and maybe last longer and not end up in a landfill. And by the way
column472: if you can buy it from the person who made it and have it be within your own state or within your own country and feel like you are supporting your local community
column473: isnt that nice. And does it even have to cost more
column474: if you think about all the markups that happened from the time that product was mass produced until the time it ended up in your doorstep
column475: there are four or five people that took markups along the way. So
column476: when this maker makes it and sends it directly to you
column477: maybe shopping small can actually give you great value as well as a sense of style. I think we are beginning to realize that there is a different way to shop that is often a better way to shop. And I am not saying for everything all the time. You are still going to need those commodities of life that you dont care about at all. And you are going to use them
column479: and thats fine. But for a lot of purchases that we all make
column480: there is a different way to show up. As I said
column481: at least one package a week arrives from Etsy at my household just because we think to start at Etsy. As I said
column482: our habitual shoppers are shopping at least once a month  on average
column483: are shopping more than once a month on Etsy. And whats different about them
column484: I think its just that they have figured out that Etsy is a place where you can find many things. So
column485: our opportunity is to help educate the rest of the market and to help train that Etsy can be a starting point for their e-commerce. And I think the opportunity there is absolutely enormous.\nDeb Wasser: Rachel
column486: did you want to add?\nRachel Glaser: I was going to give some data
column487: and he gave it. There is great habitual  in fact
column489: you had a lot of the data in your question. And then the once per month is actually more than double what we are seeing from our  the average for our repeat buyers. So
column490: there is significant value to the habitual buyer segment.\nDeb Wasser: Perfect. Okay. I will move to one from Shweta Khajuria. Can you please provide details on Etsys initiatives this year
column492: to drive purchase frequency? Can you give us some examples of what those might be focused on
column494: efficiency or liability? Josh?\nJosh Silverman: Yes. So
column496: you are starting to see us do more to present you with recommendations of things you hadnt thought of or even things like continuous feeds of lean-back experiences where you can just see streams of all the really cool things on Etsy. So
column498: like video reels of things being made
column499: which is really addictive and compelling. And we are making great progress in our recommendation engine to be able to inspire you with things that you are likely to like
column500: but maybe hadnt even thought to come to Etsy for. And that understanding things like taste and style would have been impossible years ago. But with advances in machine learning
column501: we start to be able to intuit what your taste is and what of the 100 million things for sale on Etsy
column502: other things that are  meet that sense of style. In terms of efficiency
column505: and I shared some data on the dramatic gains we are making there
column506: but getting you to the right item quickly. So
column507: you feel like when you know what you want
column508: you can get in and out quickly
column509: thats also very important. And reliability is critical. And I shared some data about how
column511: 90% of items arrived on time. Another data point we didnt share
column512: but I think is a great one
column513: 98% of things that we said would arrive in time for the holidays arrived in time for the holidays. And thats really critical that we do what we say and that you learn to be able to trust Etsy. And that can move us from being the occasional purchase where maybe you can afford for things to go wrong to being something thats really your everyday tried and true. And we have made great strides there
column514: and you will see us continue to invest meaningfully this year to make sure that buyers really know that we have their back and that they can buy on Etsy in a really worry-free way. And I dont think its a silver bullet that all of a sudden changes things. But I think that over a period of months and years
column515: as people really learn how reliable Etsy can be
column516: I think it can dramatically change consumer behavior.\nDeb Wasser: Okay. Great. I know we went over
column517: but I do want to get in a concept about our subsidiaries. So
column518: we have gotten a couple of questions
column519: one from Ed Yruma of KeyBanc and one from Laura Champine at Loop that are  regarding our subs. So
column520: can we talk about the growth profiles for Depop
column521: Reverb and Elo7? And then specifically
column522: Laura asked about the marketing strategy for Depop in 2022. So Josh
column523: you want to take those?\nJosh Silverman: Sure. So I would say that broadly speaking
column524: Depop and Reverb are facing similar headwinds  reopening headwinds to Etsy. If we talk about Depop just for a second
column525: the UK  and Depop has a lot of their business in the UK. Teenagers in the UK were literally locked in their apartments for 2 years. The lockdowns there were quite extreme. And they are now allowed to go out
column526: and they are availing themselves of that
column527: and I dont blame them. I have got two teenagers in the home. I can relate. And so there are some reopening headwinds there that we have been expecting and arent surprised by and we think are going to be temporary. And then as teenagers get a chance to get outside again
column528: they are going to want to refresh their wardrobes and get back on Depop in levels at and above where they have been. And Reverb similarly
column529: there has been some reopening headwinds there
column530: but all expected. Elo7 a little different
column531: and that Elo7s business is very event-based. And so their business is really centered around things like baby showers
column532: and things like that. And the vaccinations have been more broadly spreading through Brazil. We think thats really encouraging. But people are not gathering together in numbers yet in Brazil. And so we think that
column533: that is going to come  hopefully going to come real soon
column534: and we will provide a real tailwind for Elo7. And so we will see what the coming months bring there. In terms of the marketing strategy
column536: we are leaning into above the line with Depop. We are testing that in the U.S. right now to really make their brand a little more front and center. We are also testing performance marketing for the first time with Depop. And so there will be some margin impact to that
column537: but we think its great investment over time. We think its the right thing to do. We have a lot of faith and confidence in Depop and are excited to invest to grow that business and that platform.\nDeb Wasser: Okay
column538: great. Thank you all for hanging with us. A little bit over time here. We really appreciate it
column539: and we will be here to answer all of your questions. So
column540: that ends the call for this evening. Thank you.\nRachel Glaser: Thank you everyone.

column1: NFLX~2021~4~324~4293~1/20/2022~-.26120725~-.27000633~~~-3.9835842~-4.0923843~-4.1719236~-4.1510143~1~Spencer Wang : Hello. And welcome to the Netflix Q4 2021 Earnings Interview. I'm Spencer Wang
column2: VP of IR and Corporate Development. Joining me today are Co-CEO
column3: Reed Hastings; Co-CEO and Chief Content Officer
column4: Ted Sarandos; COO and Chief Product Officer
column5: Greg Peters; and CFO
column6: Spence Neumann.  Our interviewer this quarter is Nidhi Gupta from Fidelity. As a reminder
column7: we'll be making forward-looking statements and actual results may vary.  Nidhi
column8: over to you now to kick off the Q\u0026A.\nQ - Nidhi Gupta : Thank you
column9: Spencer. Good to be with you all again. Great to see all the new content over the quarter. I've been a little less productive
column10: so I think I can blame you all for that. As usual
column11: I'd like to start with net adds during the quarter
column12: which came in a little bit later than you expected. Just help us understand the underperformance there.\nTed Sarandos : Nidhi
column13: 8.3 versus 8.5
column14: a little less\nReed Hastings: 222 million.\nSpencer Neumann : In fairness
column15: Nidhi said it was a little shy. So I'll take what Nidhi says. As she says
column16: we delivered -- first
column17: we're quite pleased with how the quarter played out. We delivered 8.3 million paid net adds. So it was just a bit shy about tenth of a percent on roughly 222 million paying members.  And overall
column18: we're quite pleased with how our titles performed. We had big viewing. We started the quarter with Squid Game becoming a global phenomenon
column19: and we ended the quarter in December with big TV series like the finale of La Casa de Papel
column20: a big returning show in The Witcher
column21: our two biggest movie releases of all time.  So overall
column22: the business was healthy. Retention was strong. Churn was down. Viewing was up. But on the margin
column23: we just -- we didn't grow acquisition quite as fast as we would have liked to see on our large subscriber base. A small change in acquisition can have a pretty big flow-through in paid net adds. And again
column24: our acquisition was growing
column25: just not growing quite as fast as we were perhaps hoping or forecasting.\nNidhi Gupta : Great. And as we look ahead to Q1
column26: the guidance was a bit below kind of what was expected and what you've done in previous Q1s. Maybe just help us understand what some of the key considerations were that went into the guidance? And does it raise any concerns for you about anything structural
column27: whether it's competition or saturation? Or does it give you any pause in terms of sort of your return on content spend?\nSpencer Neumann : Sure. No structural change in the business that we see. What's reflected in the guidance
column28: we guided to 2.5 million paid net adds in Q1. And what's reflected there is pretty much the same trends we saw in Q4. So healthy retention with churn down. Healthy viewing and engagement
column29: with viewing up.  And acquisition just growing but a bit slower than pre-COVID levels
column30: just hasn't fully recovered. And we're trying to pinpoint what that is. It's tough to say exactly why our acquisition hasn't kind of recovered to pre-COVID levels. It's probably a bit of just overall COVID overhang that's still happening after two years of a global pandemic that we're still unfortunately not fully out of
column31: some macroeconomic strain in some parts of the world
column32: like Latin America
column33: in particular.  While we can't pinpoint or point a straight line using when we look at the data on a competitive impact
column34: there may be some kind of more on the marginal kind of side of our growth
column35: some impact from competition. But which
column36: again
column37: we just don't see it specifically. So overall
column38: that's what's reflected in the guide. I'd say we -- our big titles are also landing
column39: at least our known big titles a little bit later in the quarter with Season 2 of Bridgerton in March
column40: The Adam Project also in March. As you know
column41: we also -- while we are taking -- changing prices in countries every quarter. In Q1 of this year
column42: it happens to be our largest country
column43: as we announced last week
column44: actually our largest region with Canada as well. So that's probably a little bit more impact than a typical quarter.\nReed Hastings : But Nidhi
column45: you're right to reflect on two years ago
column46: we were 10 million above plan
column47: which was a shock. Last year
column48: we were 10 million below or 9 million. And so the pull forward sort of makes it hard to read. In the prior years
column49: we are very steady
column50: so we can have confidence on incremental trends.  But as Spence said
column51: when we reflect of course
column52: hey
column53: thats a little guide and we think it will be accurate. Its not sand packed at all
column54: kind of that's what's going on. And there's a number of potential explanations with COVID
column55: but then we worry about having too much on that. There's more competition than there's ever been. But we have Hulu with Amazon for 14 years. So it doesn't feel like any qualitative change there. And overall
column56: confidence in streaming becomes all of entertainment. Linear dissipates over the next 10 to 20 years
column57: very high confidence in that thesis because everyone's coming into streaming. So like market size
column58: very large. Our execution is steady and getting better. So for now
column59: we're just like staying calm and trying to figure out
column60: again
column61: the COVID has introduced so much noise. It just wants us to give it some pause as we work on everything we've always worked on.\nTed Sarandos : And just to reiterate
column62: I'd say we took a big bet years ago on this. The people would move on to Netflix and Netflix-type offerings to consume movies and film. That was a big
column63: big bet that we've seen continue to go through.  We have no change in our confidence in that. And I think what's really been great about 2021
column64: even through all those conditions
column65: we were able to kind of prove out to other theses that we've bet on starting years ago one big one around our investment in international programming. We're glad that we started that 7 years ago with Club de Cuervos. And now we were betting that you could take films and series from anywhere in the world and entertain the entire world.  And we were getting more -- bigger and bigger milestones against that goal. And now we have proven to have kind of global sensations from France with Lupin
column66: from Spain with La Casa de Papel and Elite . And then in the biggest way possible in 2021 was Squid Game
column67: which has become our biggest series ever. And it is unapologetically and perfectly Korean. So it's not built to be this kind of global thing. It's proving that great storytelling from anywhere in the world can entertain the world. And our other big bet was our investment in big budget feature films. And our bet that we could effectively release them and compete with big theatrical releases for audience and for attention. And Red Notice this year
column68: of course and Don't Look Up have become our number 1 and number 2 most watched movies ever on Netflix. And if you look at the hours that we publish out
column69: you can do the math and back into it. They may be the most watched movies anywhere in the world this year.  So I think those 2 bets coming through. It kind of strengthens our confidence in the overall bet in the service
column70: and pleasing customers and leaning into consumer first business models
column71: I think we could succeed there.\nNidhi Gupta : Yeah. And I think that's part of the question
column72: right? I mean you -- this was probably the best content quarter you've had. And looking at sort of flattish subs versus previous Q4s
column73: obviously
column74: a great number
column75: but it's kind of in line with what you've done the last few Q4s. What do you read from that? Is the customers sort of hurdle just higher in terms of the amount and quality of content that you need to deliver to get the same number of net adds?\nTed Sarandos : Well
column76: I think what
column77: I guess
column78: Spence was saying
column79: we didn't see it -- we didn't see a hit to our engagement. We didn't see a hit to retention. All those things that would classically lead you to looking at competition.  But it's just do of all those things. Not only are we in a pandemic
column80: we've kind of come in and out of COVID at different levels in 2021 particularly the back half of 2021. So it's created a lot of bumpiness certainly and not steady linear growth
column81: which makes it a little tougher to predict
column82: but all the fundamentals of the business are pretty solid.\nNidhi Gupta : Got it. You announced a U.S. price increase last week. Maybe just help us understand kind of over what time frame you think this will flow through
column83: what kind of churn you might expect?\nGreg Peters : Yeah. I'd say you can anticipate it flowing through over the next quarter
column84: the quarter that we're in right now in Q1. And we largely are seeing in the price changes we've done most recently and for the earliest indications that we have in the U.S.
column85: which is still premature because we actually haven't actually rolled it out to any customers yet. What we've seen over the last couple of years
column86: which is that sort of core theory that we have that if we've done a good job investing
column87: the members subscription fees that they paid us into better stories
column88: more great storytelling
column89: bigger movies
column90: more variety.  Then when we come back and ask them occasionally for a little bit more to keep that sort of cycle going
column91: then they're generally willing to do that. And we don't see any significant disruption to the business otherwise in that regard. And I would say generally
column92: when we look at that sort of core theory and we look at also the competitors
column93: if you look at Disney+ as an example
column94: the other streaming services out there as well. And their ability to grow even as we've been growing as well
column95: I think it's really strong endorsement for the core idea that consumers around the world are willing to pay for great entertainment. And it encourages us to continue that investment and to try and deliver more entertainment value and earn more of that share.\nNidhi Gupta : Yeah. It's a good point about your streaming competitors. column341: just turning over to you on margins. Does the guidance for a lower level of margin -- and you gave a lot of explanation around that in the letter -- but outside of sort of the FX impact

column346: we lost about $1 billion of expected revenue in '22 through FX. That's about 2 points of margin. So if you just kind of look at our guide and add that back on
column347: we're right on our pace of adding about 3 points of margin per year. And I can't forget we were over delivering on margin in the last couple of years. column380: our top priority is to be responsible stewards of the business and our cash but to invest in the healthy growth of our business and strategically invest in the business
column381: first

column383: if there's been opportunistically that M\u0026A is not the strategy for us per se. M\u0026A is a tactic to accelerate our strategy

column386: TV and games as you've seen.  And what's left over after that
column387: we're not going to sit on excess cash as we've said. Our capital allocation plan is as it's been
column388: which is to have roughly 2 months of revenue in the form of cash on our balance sheet
column389: and excess beyond that
column390: we'll return to shareholders opportunistically as we have done. We did that through the tune of about $600 million last year in share repurchase. And we're authorized up to $5 billion share repurchase. So that's still our plan. In terms of when the -- those ratios converge and earnings and cash flow look the same
column391: I don't want to put a prediction out there. We're still in a very much in growth mode as a business. So it will continue to converge over time
column392: but I don't want to declare a specific peak. It's been going in the right direction over a multiyear period. And it will continue to do so.\nSpencer Wang : The only thing I would add to that
column393: Nidhi
column394: is just on the capital allocation part. Just to remind you
column395: our balance sheet target is for gross debt of about $10 billion to $15 billion. We ended the quarter slightly above the $15 billion mark. So as we said in the letter
column396: we will be paying down about $700 million in Q1.  But obviously delevering a bit is something you should anticipate in terms of use of cash. And then just lastly
column397: on the EPS free cash flow question. So I just want to remind you
column398: there are some below-the-line items like the non-cash remeasurement of our euro bonds that can skew EPS in any sort of given quarter
column399: so just a call out there. But thank you for your questions. I'm going to turn it over to Ted now to -- for his closing remarks and to take us home.\nTed Sarandos : Nidhi
column400: thank you so much for these and thanks for today. The love of film and TV and games has built big businesses for people who can figure out what people love
column401: build a creative environment that creators know how to feed it and then deliver it to fans with a value proposition that they appreciate.  I think those fans are positively moving from old linear models and transactional models to more fan-friendly subscription services that are with high-quality programming
column402: delivered well with great value. That's absolutely happening
column403: and it's happening all over the world. The pace of the migration may be a little hard to call from time to time when there are kind of very global events or even local conditions
column404: but it's absolutely happening. There's no question of that. Films that you love and series that you define yourself by and games that thrill you
column405: that's a pretty great business. We're thrilled to be in it. We're also planning to continue to improve what we're doing and to grow this by growing revenue
column406: by growing profits and by growing audience affinity around the world. So once again
